PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws attention to the Senate of their concern regarding proposed changes to the laws governing credit reporting, as suggested in the Bill `The Privacy Amendment Bill 1989'.
The proposed reforms will:
Restrict the legitimate use of credit checking by business who sell/supply goods and/or services to their customers on credit terms.

The proposals/reforms will prevent businesses from determining the solvency of their customers and will increase the financial risk of credit providers, leading to an increase in company liquidations and individual bankruptcies.

Additional costs to business from bad debts due to the lack of adequate credit checking information will result in increased prices/charges and will result in credit providers refusing credit facilities.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will call on the Government to refer these proposals restricting credit checking to a Senate Standing Committee for further consideration before proceeding with the matter.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws the attentions of the Senate to our opposition to any attempt to restrict access to the rebate for abortions under Medicare.

Medicare is a universal health care system and as such the availability of any schedule item should never be determined on the basis of the moral values of a minority of citizens. Equity and access within the present system should be the right of all Australian citizens and guaranteed to them.

The Webster Abortion Funding Abolition Bill would, if successful, severely limit the availability of rebates for items 6494, 274 and 275. The effect would be twofold-further discrimination against all women (particularly those who could not afford the full cost of this procedure) and an invasion of the confidentiality that exists between client and medical practitioner.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that:
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Parental Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned strongly object to the Legislation which is being recommended by Professor Duncan Chappel, Department of Criminology, that parental rights to discipline our children by spanking (if necessary), being taken from us.

If we are not allowed to discipline our children at home, in love and according to God's Word we fear that we will have a nation of completely rebellious children on our hands. God's Word says, ``Spare the rod and spoil the child'' and also that ``Foolishness is bound up in the heart of a child, but the rod of correction will drive it far from him''. We would therefore appreciate your consideration of our rights as parents to correctly and lovingly discipline our own children, and feel that if this right is taken from us we would lose the respect of our children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: The Last Temptation of Christ
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and senators in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the film ``The Last Temptation of Christ'' portrays Our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ in a blasphemous and offensive way and is calculated to outrage the feelings of Christians.

2. That the decision of the Film Censorship Board to allow the importation of the film and to classify the Film with an ``R'' classification, rather than banning it, shows that the Film Censorship Board has failed in its statutory duty.
3. That in failing to exercise his powers and ban the Film the Attorney General has, as with his failure to ban the Film Hail Mary in 1986, failed in his duty to the people of Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will express its lack of confidence in the Attorney General and the Film Censorship Board and pass laws which will ensure that no more blasphemous or offensive films will be permitted to be imported and/or screened in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Boswell (from 86 citizens), Cooney (from 101 citizens), McGauran (from 129 citizens), Patterson (from 142 citizens) and Bishop (from 162 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: States Grants Schools Assistance Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

That the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act, 1988 includes legislation, Part III-Changes to Non-Government Schools and new Non-Government Schools, designed to inhibit the establishment, growth and development of these schools in Australia by the imposition of restrictive provisions in the areas of funding, enrolments and approval criteria.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reconsider the application and implications of this legislation in the light of justice, equity and freedom of choice for parents and have the unfair sections (Section 8 (2), 8 (15) and (11) repealed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patents
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Australian Senate.

The undersigned citizens of Australia oppose the patenting of animals and the processes for genetically engineering them. Animal patents would *compromise animal welfare, *reduce biodiversity, *concentrate ownership of breeding stock and *allow companies to appropriate the fruits of centuries of selective breeding.
We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Patents Office and without your intervention may soon be approved.
Please take all possible steps immediately to ensure that:
1. The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and refuses to accept any more;
2. The Senate amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We urge all members of the Australian Senate to act upon this petition.

I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this case, the Committee was concerned with rights of review of adverse decisions made under discretions granted in the instrument itself. These discretions related to the right of full professional practice by general practitioners. An adverse decision could have important effects upon a person's financial position and professional reputation. In cases involving the right to practise a livelihood, the Committee is particularly vigilant, almost invariably insisting upon external review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of the merits of a decision.

SPEECH.PARA: However, this was one of the exceptional cases where the Committee accepted the explanation from the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) that existing review rights, although internal, were independent of control by the Minister or the Department of Community Services and Health. The Minister referred the Committee to the unanimous report of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance on the vocational registrations of general practitioners, which expressly addressed this issue. The regulations are in general conformance with the report on this point.

The Committee thanks the Minister for Community Services and Health for his cooperation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief description of the Committee's scrutiny and its correspondence for the information of honourable senators and others.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
HEALTH INSURANCE (VOCATIONAL REGISTRATION OF GP's) REGULATIONS STATUTORY RULES 1989 No. 270

The Committee's concerns with this instrument related to rights of review of adverse decisions made under discretions granted to the Minister and to various Committees. The provision of appropriate review rights is an important safeguard upon which the Committee insists. In this case, one of the two areas of discretion raised by the Committee related to the right of medical practitioners to practise with full professional rights. The Committee has reported (see Eighty-third Report, April 1988, paragraph 4.38) that there are few more important rights than the right to earn a living. The Committee recognises that delegated legislation may suitably limit that right to ensure standards of competence and behaviour. Where, however, these supervisory procedures confer power on Ministers or others to exercise discretions which could result in the loss of the right to practice a livelihood then the Committee carefully scrutinises those provisions to ensure that decision making is objectively and not subjectively formulated, that criteria inform both the decision maker and the citizen of their respective responsibilities, that there is a right of external review of the merits of a decision with provision for substitution of a fresh decision, and that the person affected must be informed promptly of the decision, the reasons for the decision and appeal rights.

The Committee believes that generally such right of review can only be carried out effectively by an external, independent body. Only in exceptional cases will the Committee be persuaded that a right of internal review by the Minister, or by an internal tribunal effectively appointed by the Minister or the department, is acceptable. In almost all cases the Committee expresses a preference for such external, independent review on the merits to be conducted by the AAT.

The present case was particularly interesting in that although the review procedures established by the delegated legislation were internal, in that they were entirely provided for by the instrument itself and by other portfolio practices, the Committee was persuaded that the procedures were sufficiently independent to satisfy its requirements. The composition of the review body, for example, is not determined exclusively or even predominantly by the Minister and the peak body of the profession which is affected is represented strongly.

The other area of discretion related to lack of external merits review of the power of the Minister to remove a person from a Committee for misbehaviour or for mental or physical incapacity. Although membership of the Committee would have little financial value, removal would affect a person's personal and professional reputation. The reply to the Committee's letter pointed out that similar provisions in other legislation did not provide for the type of review. The Committee does not regard this by itself as an adequate response. The principles of the Committee are not static, but rather evolve and expand to meet changing situations. What may have been acceptable previously in the area of personal rights may have evolved under the direction of the Committee into more stringent requirements. In this case, however, taking into account all the circumstances, the Committee accepted the explanation provided.

Similarly, the reply to the Committee's concerns mentioned the Administrative Decision (Judicial Review) Act. While this statute is a keystone of the comprehensive system of Commonwealth administrative law it is not concerned with review of the policy merits of decisions and also applies generally to decisions made under enactments.
The Committee thanks the Minister for Community Services and Health, the Hon Neal Blewett MP, for his co-operation.
22 November 1989
The Hon Peter Staples MP
Minister for Housing and Aged Care
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Health Insurance (Vocational Registration of GP's) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1989 No. 270, considered by the Committee at its Meeting of 2 November 1989.

The Committee noted that r.14 provides that ``The Minister may terminate the appointment of a member (of an Eligibility Committee or an Appeal Committee) for misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity''. Each of these grounds requires subjective judgment and there appears to be no provision for review of a decision to terminate an appointment. The Committee accepts that membership of one of these Committees may not be of commercial value, but points out the loss of personal reputation which could have a serious effect on a person's future livelihood. In cases of such a decision, which could have a disastrous impact upon an individual, the Committee normally expects to see a right of external review of its merits. The Committee has also expressed a preference that such review be the function of the Administrative Review Tribunal, an independent, expert body which places itself in the position of the original decision maker.

Similarly, the Committee noted that the entire review process in relation to entry on, or removal from, the Register, appears to be internal. Medical practitioners who are on the Vocational Register have substantial and valuable professional rights and prestige. In situations like the present the Committee would expect to see external review of the merits of decisions as a matter of course.

The Committee does not appear to have been supplied with a copy of the document referred to in r.2 (2), ``Criteria for Vocational Registration of General Practitioners''. It would be appreciated if you could send a copy.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman
6 December 1989
Dear Chairman

I refer to your letter of 22 November 1989 to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care regarding the Health Insurance (Vocational Registration of GP's) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1989 No. 270. I regret the delay in replying.

The Committee raised concerns in its letter regarding regulation 14, namely the fact that there was no external review regarding such regulation. Further the Committee raised similar concerns regarding the review process in relation to entry on, or removal from, the Vocational Register.

As regards regulation 14 discussions with Attorney-Generals indicates that no previous legislation regarding termination of appointments has been made reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). The appropriate mechanism for review of this type of decision is that of the Administrative Review (Judicial Review) Act.

The committee also raised concerns regarding the review process in relation to entry on or removal from the Vocational Register. The structure on which these regulations were based is that of the Specialist Recognition Advisory Committees and Appeal Committees (SRAC). The Specialist Recognition and the Vocational Registration Eligibility Committees are expert committees which look at criteria set by peers in the medical profession. In the case of the SRAC Committees review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal was not considered appropriate. In consid9ring the Vocational Registration decision making process the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance in the report ``Vocational Registration of General Practitioners''-(August 1989) at paragraph 2.25 stated ``that AAT review of decisions taken by an independent professional body about the professional standing of a doctor would not be appropriate''. Attorneys-General support this view.

Your Committee's concerns regarding the rights of external review are met by the fact that any person aggrieved may apply through the Administrative Review (Judicial Review) Act where the person believes they have not been accorded natural justice. Similarly the person can take out interim injunctions to stop any detriment which may be alleged would occur.
I believe the Administrative Review (Judicial Review) Act mechanism provides an appropriate external review and trust this removes any concerns the Committee may have.
As to your request for a copy of the document referred to in Regulation 2 (2) please find included herein a copy of ``Criteria for Vocational Registration of General Practitioners''.
Yours sincerely
Neal Blewett
12 December 1989
The Hon. Neal Blewett MP
Minister for Community Services and Health

Dear Minister,

I refer to your letter of 6 December 1989 concerning aspects raised by the Committee of the Health Insurance (Vocational Registration of GP's) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1989 No. 270. The Committee considered your reply at its Meeting of 7 December 1989.
After discussion, the Committee agreed that your advice met its concerns and is grateful for your explanation. The Committee, however, offers the following comments on your letter.

Firstly, in response to the inquiry about the discretion granted to the Minister to remove a member of an Eligibility Committee or an Appeal Committee for misbehaviour or for physical or mental incapacity, your letter mentioned that no previous legislation contained provisions suggested by the Committee. Such a reply is not considered, by itself, an adequate response. It is, of course, one relevant factor to be considered. The principles of the Committee, however, are not static but are constantly being developed and expanded. The committee has been responsible for numbers of advances in the area of personal rights, which had no precedent in existing legislation. Nevertheless, the Committee agreed to accept your advice after taking into account all the surrounding circumstances.

Secondly, in relation to paragraphs 5 and 6 of your letter, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, while one of the most important elements in the system of Commonwealth administrative law, is not concerned with the review of merits of decisions, in connection with which the Committee raised its original concerns. In addition, that Act relates generally to decisions made under enactments. The committee respectfully points out to your departmental officers that it is familiar with the provisions of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Law) Act and with the various procedures for injunctive relief. It may be assumed in correspondence initiated by the Committee that the provisions of that Act have been taken into account.

The Committee, however, agreed to accept the advice contained in paragraph 4 of the letter. It is unusual for the Committee in such an important matter to agree to an internal merits review procedure rather than reference to the AAT, but in this case the Committee was convinced that the procedure was independent of final ministerial or departmental control. The Committee was also influenced by the Report of the Senate Select committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, ``Vocational Registration of General Practitioners'', to which you helpfully referred us, and to the copy of the Criteria for Vocational registration of General Practitioners which you furnished to the Committee.
The Committee appreciates your co-operation.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Defence Force Regulations (Amendment) as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 290 made under the Defence Act 1903 be disallowed.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement of the Committee's concerns.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Defence Force Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1989 No. 290

The principal Regulations already provide for defence operations and practices where it is necessary to exclude members of the public from certain areas. A practice area is first declared, and an operation or practice is then authorised and notified to the public.

These procedures have been generally satisfactory, although there is now a new Navy requirement which is not adequately covered. To test mine detecting equipment it is necessary for objects to be left undisturbed on the sea-bed for up to two years. To avoid disturbance of the object it is necessary to prohibit certain activities such as bottom trawling for the whole of the period the objects are in place.

These Regulations provide for the installation for a specified period of up to two years of equipment in a declared area of sea, on the sea-bed or in the subsoil beneath that area or in the superjacent waters. Reasonable notice must be given of the installation of the equipment and of activities which may interfere with its operation. Criteria are set out for the way in which notice is to be given and the Committee does not raise any aspects of these provisions.

The Regulations forbid a person from disturbing such equipment or interfering with its operation, except with the permission of a Chief of Staff or an officer participating in a defence operation or practice in relation to which the equipment was installed. This prohibition is, however, a strict liability offence punishable not only by a fine of $500 but by imprisonment for three months, or both. The Committee always requires full justification for strict liability offences, which it will accept only in the most unusual circumstances. In the present case, where the penalty includes possible imprisonment, the Committee is even more reluctant to agree to such provisions. As the installations are on the sea bed or nearby waters it may not be possible to provide adequate notice, despite the criteria in the Regulations, to all persons who may be affected.

The Explanatory Statement does not address the reasons why it is necessary to provide for a strict liability offence punishable by imprisonment. The Committee has written to the Minister asking for advice on whether the Regulations could be amended to provide for an element of knowledge in the offence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I seek an extension of time of the same length as was granted to Senator Teague to enable me to complete my remarks on the package of seven education Bills before the Senate. (Extension of time granted) Last night before the adjournment I was discussing the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1989. I made comment that the Government's emphasis with regard to overseas students has switched from a foreign policy direction with humanitarian and development objectives to a purely financial direction with our own local economic difficulties as the main focus.

SPEECH.PARA: We must ask whether or not the new policy direction will contribute to assisting our local economic difficulties. It is interesting to note that many educational commentators believe that in attempting to gain extra capital, we may actually be pricing ourselves out of the market. It cannot be denied that the market in terms of the overseas student demand is extremely large and potentially very lucrative. Naturally, due to the demand and the money involved, the market is becoming increasingly competitive. To assume that the elasticity of demand for places in this country is so low that we continue to squeeze more and more out of overseas students is fallacious. At present the fees for courses offered in both the United States and the United Kingdom are declining, and in many Canadian provinces subsidies are now being used to snare a larger slice of the overseas student market.

We must not lose sight of the fact that the increased demand for places in Australia over the last decade was largely due to moves in the United Kingdom to impose full fees on its overseas students. Even on short term economic grounds, the benefits of the new scheme will remain to be proven. While the institutions may gain somewhat from the direct payment of full fees by overseas students, it is likely that the smaller number of students which will now come to Australia will provide significantly less in the way of incremental financial benefits-for example, in terms of rental payments, transport costs, travel expenses and the like.

The disadvantages of the new system are further compounded when one considers the likely effect on enrolment profiles. Clearly, given the high tertiary fees, the majority of our overseas students will come from more prosperous countries, perhaps reinforcing the view that we can continue to charge higher and higher fees. This means not only that we lose some of the cultural diversity which has characterised this particular area of our educational endeavour but also that we are limiting the range of countries able to avail themselves of our educational facilities. We are also looking at a move to short term informal courses, particularly English language courses. Unfortunately, the benefits to Australians from these types of courses will be strictly financial. The cultural exchange which occurs from long term formal courses is almost non-existent. We are looking at a situation which is short-sighted, which will damage our long term foreign affairs interests in this region, and which will eventually lead this Government, or a coalition government if it take its place in the next election, to reversing this trend and moving back, as other countries are currently doing, to a more open and more developmental based policy in this regard.

The last Bill that I wish to address today is the University of Canberra Bill, which is at the second reading stage. The Bill to establish the University of Canberra goes back quite some time, and the Australian Democrats welcome the move to change the old Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE) in order to establish the University of Canberra. Indeed, I made the first response to the Government's move to amalgamate the Australian National University (ANU) and CCAE quite some time ago. In fact I think it was early last year or possibly in the year before. The notion of amalgamation of these two institutions, from our point of view, made no sense whatsoever. However, as is still undoubtedly the case, the Minister is interested in some type of amalgamation and would dearly have loved to have seen his original Bill, which sought to bring about that amalgamation, passed by the Parliament.

The two institutions that we are now dealing with, the ANU and the CCAE as it is currently constituted, have two quite different missions. They are missions which are both necessary in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). There is the national mission, which the ANU, unfortunately, has not pursued with the type of vigour which I believe it should have done, and there is a local and territorial imperative that ought to be infusing the mission of the CCAE. Given the CCAE's excellent contacts in the local area, it seemed to us that it was a quite silly and disruptive move to attempt an amalgamation, either to dilute the national focus of the Australian National University or to try to run down the local focus of the CCAE. We now have a far better move, one with which I believe the people of the Territory will be well pleased. I think that in years to come it will be seen to have been the most sensible decision that could have been made with regard to this matter.

There are a number of problems in the Bill that I wish to raise in the committee stage. However, because any amendment, or even any attempted amendment, to this Bill could very well see its demise, we have no intention of moving amendments to those bits of the Bill which really ought to have been improved, but I wish to address those in the committee stage. However, I want to make one further comment about the Canberra University. It is entirely appropriate and ought to be on the agenda as soon as possible. The Canberra University should move under the control of the Australian Capital Territory Government. The reasons for that are overwhelming.

First, as I have already mentioned, the CCAE in its current constitution has already got a strong postgraduate body and, in fact, has extremely good links with the local community. The ACT Administration currently enrols students in the Territory's primary and secondary schools and the technical and further education (TAFE) sector. I believe that for any rational operation of educational policy within the Territory it is necessary that not only does the administration have people sitting on a board, but also that it has under its legislative control the main representatives from each sector of education.

Secondly, the college has already developed very close links with the ACT schools office, the TAFE colleges, the Canberra Institute of the Arts, Australian Capital Territory industry and the broader community. The CCAE has been extremely successful in developing and establishing courses which closely reflect identifiable local needs. The principal of the college has enthusiastically participated in various local organisations: the ACT Education and Training Council, the employment agency heads meetings and the former ACT Administration coordination committee. Members of the college staff participate actively in the ACT Heritage Committee and are involved with the Canberra Development Board.

All of those reasons are topped off by the fact that the Federal Parliament really has, or ought to have a national scope. One of the reasons for the establishment of the ACT Government was to allow the Commonwealth Government to concentrate on broader national issues, with a Territory government directed at the needs of the local community. It should not always be assumed-in fact, Senator Reid, who is in the chamber, has pointed this out on a number of occasions-that what the Commonwealth sees to be in the national interest is what the local people of the Territory see to be in their interests. That is part and parcel of the notion of a federation. It is one of the very good reasons why the legislation governing our tertiary institutions resides, currently, under all the States and under the Northern Territory Administration. That is what ought to occur here. This point has already been supported by the Australian Capital Territory Select Committee on Tertiary Amalgamations. I hope that in a short space of time we will be able to move towards the Australian Capital Territory Government being the body responsible for the legislation for the University of Canberra.

I wish the university well. I think it will take its place amongst other State and Territory universities as an organisation which will contribute fruitfully to the people of the Territory. Over the years I have had the opportunity of meeting both with teaching and administration staff, and I believe that they are more than capable of taking their place within what is, in Australia, a very viable, strong and fruitful university sector. I believe that the matters that have now been resolved with regard to funding have been conducted in the proper way. At the beginning of this matter, we felt that there was going to be some attempt, because of the Government's thwarted policy direction, to penalise the institutions. In my mind, I never really thought that was on because of the political implausibility of any government seeking to penalise any particular sector. Indeed, I think we will see some ramifications of that objective when, at a later stage, there will undoubtedly be some discussions with regard to the proposed amalgamation in Western Australia.

We have here what is certainly the best and most progressive view that could be taken, and I hope that the people of the Australian Capital Territory find in their university a university responsive to their needs and, on the other hand, that the ANU will more aggressively pursue its national goals and seek to take its undergraduate and post-graduate student bodies from the whole of Australia, rather than the unfortunate situation that has grown up in recent years whereby, in terms of its faculties, at the current time some 60 per cent of its students come from the Australian Capital Territory. A national university ought to be national in scope, construction and composition. The establishment of the University of Canberra and its proper funding now provide the people of the Territory with their own university access. We should now see an aggressive exercise by the ANU towards its legislative mission which was put down in the original legislation and which is still there, that is, to pursue national goals which are not always able to be pursued and, in fact, currently are not being pursued in a number of areas by State universities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of the package of Bills we are discussing, I wish to refer specifically to the University of Canberra Bill 1989. It has been a turbulent year for higher education, particularly so for two institutions in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT)-the Australian National University (ANU) and the Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE). They have lived throughout this year with the threat of amalgamation and funding withdrawals if the Government and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) did not get their own way. This Bill is really a triumph over the adversity of the difficult year that I have referred to. Many people at the CCAE who saw benefits and advantages to the institution from amalgamation have never got answers to their questions about how amalgamation would come about and what the relationship between the two institutions would be.

SPEECH.PARA: A report on amalgamation commissioned by the Minister does not, in any way, answer the questions about why the institutions should be amalgamated. A decision was taken to amalgamate the two institutions no matter what, and no matter what the cost. Many people in the institutions who were very worried about amalgamation could not get answers to the questions they wanted, the key question being: what benefit would it be to students? That question has never been answered.

We come to the end of the year with the CCAE in a situation where it will shortly become the University of Canberra. I think that is something we all welcome. This institution has proved its academic ability and it has been extremely successful in many areas. The CCAE has attracted people from overseas and it has, undoubtedly, an overseas reputation which will continue into the future. It has acquired that reputation in its own right. The ANU also has a splendid reputation. However, the two institutions are quite different. The CCAE has been extremely successful over the years in training people for careers in which they can obtain employment. It has been outstandingly successful in this respect, even during times of difficulty.

The opposition to the Government's plan stemmed from an inability to show that any educational or economic benefits to the institutions or the students could be gained from amalgamation. Presumably, if the Government had been able to show that there was merit, the amalgamation might have gone ahead. But the Government seemed to be arguing that big is beautiful. I think most people believed that the two institutions would stay as they were and that there would just be another layer of administration to bring them together. If there was anything else to it, it certainly was not made apparent to those of us who are interested in the future of Canberra.

I think the underlying fallacy of the amalgamation argument was made even more apparent when it become clear that threats were being made to try to force institutions to come together. There may be institutions in other places that can amalgamate quite satisfactorily, but this process did not seem to be appropriate across the board. The Federal Government has control over both the ANU and the CCAE in the ACT and because of this it was able to hold a gun at their heads in an attempt to make them bow to its will. The Government took a different course only when it realised that the Senate would not go along with an enforced amalgamation. This was not just a local reaction-academics and others in Australia had the same reservations. I think it is worth reviewing some of the views that were held.

In August 1988 the Chancellor of the University of Sydney, Sir Helmann Black, said that the Government's attitudes were `authoritarian, particularly dangerously vague and open-ended as to how they may be interpreted and utterly unnecessary'. Professor Nichol said that the Government `contradicted its own promise of deregulation with its detailed agenda for the way universities should be run, including areas of traditional university autonomy'. He referred to the `potentially burdensome government framework'.

In July 1988, the Dean of the Victorian College of Pharmacy accused the Government of social engineering in the plan which would put non-science and technology courses on a second rung. Melbourne University's Professor David Penington referred to `very serious flaws in Mr Dawkins' proposals'. In the Age of 6 August 1988, Professor Penington is reported as saying that the Government's White Paper heralded `a period of unprecedented political interference and central regulatory control virtually unknown elsewhere in the Western world'. I think these comments added considerably to the concerns that many people had about what was going on and why the amalgamation was being pushed. Certainly, no answers were ever given in the Parliament.
The Australian Financial Review in July 1988 also made an editorial comment on the Government's policies. It stated:

By proposing to turn the Government funded higher education system into a gigantic bureaucratic shemozzle designed to suppress originality or research and initiative, Mr Dawkins has ensured that a flourishing private sector university system will come into being.
In one fell blow the Government will have succeeded in worsening the conditions for the best university staff and worsening the average quality of the staff of the new Dawkins mega-universities.

They are very serious comments indeed. People in Canberra were concerned that the character of the CCAE would be lost if it were absorbed into the ANU. I think the ANU likewise felt that its intrinsic character, which has been referred to by Senator Macklin, would be lost if it were absorbed into the CCAE and no benefits were apparent.

The CCAE is not against change and had already sought to become a university of technology in its own right. This was rejected by the Federal Government in spite of the quite strong merits of the case which were put forward by the college. As I said, since it became clear that the Government would face defeat in the Senate if it were to attempt to force a merger, the college has gone about strengthening its position. It has come to a conclusion, which the Government has now accepted-I believe that this will be best for the college and best for Canberra-that it should become the University of Canberra. This Bill provides for that under the tutelage of Monash University. There are similarities here with the way in which the ANU began life in 1946 as the Canberra University College, a branch of the University of Melbourne. I think all of us welcome the relationship which will exist over the next three years between the University of Canberra and Monash University. Benefits will be available from developing graduate programs, academic exchanges and joint research projects.

Senator Macklin and Senator Teague referred to the question of the University of Canberra coming under the Australian Capital Territory Government. I think all of us see that as something which will occur and we will discuss it when we are in government. These institutions will create many benefits for Canberra. They will attract people to Canberra. Students will want to come here. Tertiary sector growth is very significant and important in the development of this region, economic and otherwise.

The second reading speech of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training commits the Government to maintaining the vital role which the CCAE presently plays in the Australian Capital Territory and the surrounding community in terms of vocational training. That is important to the people of the Australian Capital Territory. The excellent institution that we now have will become the University of Canberra. I certainly support the Bill. I wish the University well. I hope that the necessary steps will be taken to see that this change takes place before the end of this year.

Senator Alston has asked me to refer to the Overseas Students Charge Bill, in which he has an interest. In view of time constraints, he said that he would not speak on the Bill today. He has asked me to indicate that the Opposition will not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 and allied Bills. In particular I wish to refer to the Bill which provides for the rural hostels program and the extension of eligibility for the funding under the capital grants program to rural hostels. This will allow government and non-government organisations providing accommodation for rural students to apply for funding under the general element of the capital grants program. It also provides for the establishment of a rural hostels program to provide assistance to hostels with an initial allocation in 1990 of $1m. The Government's April rural education and training strategy entitled A Fair Go stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The needs of young people undertaking secondary education in country areas and young people required to move from remote communities to undertake secondary education deserve priority attention.
This cannot be disputed. According to the Isolated Children's Parents Association, only 30 per cent of rural students complete year 12 compared to the national average of 60 per cent.

The main difficulty facing rural students is the distances between institutions offering various courses, usually due to a lack of resources at schools with small student numbers. One way of improving access for rural students is the provision of hostels at government and non-government schools. A category of rural student hostels has been established and $1m will be made available in 1990. I would have thought that a preferable avenue to increasing the provision of hostels for rural students, hence increasing access to secondary education, would be to improve their affordability. Schools would not hesitate to provide greater boarding facilities if the families of their students could meet the costs of these facilities. Boarding allowance is provided under the assistance for isolated children's (AIC) scheme. The $1m allocated to the rural hostel program in the Government's so-called `priority attention' to the needs of children from remote communities pales into insignificance compared to the decline in the value of the AIC allowances under this Government.

I shall contrast the 1983 scheme with the 1989 scheme to show the deterioration in the value of benefits provided to students. Under the 1989 scheme $989 is the guaranteed minimum payment, free of the assets test and the means test. There is a maximum allowance of $2,513. It is means tested from an income base of $16,950, being reduced by $2.50 for each $10 earned thereafter. The minimum is reached when the maximum income of $23,050 is arrived at. Under the 1983 scheme there was a base grant of $866, irrespective of levels of income or assets, plus a maximum additional allowance of $1,066, which declined at a rate of $2.50 for each additional $10 of income in excess of $10,200. That provided a total maximum benefit of $1,932. That cut out at an additional income of $4,270 of a total income of $14,464.

In terms of today's dollars if we compare the consumer price index for 1983 to the consumer price index of 1989 and use 1981 as a base of 100, the figure for 1983 was 127.3. That figure would now stand at 197.8. The 1983 dollars have to be multiplied by 1.55 to put them into present dollar figures. There has been a very significant decline in the value provided to students over that period. There is a very significant fall-off-in fact, the decline is something like 26.3 per cent-in the level of the benefits provided to children. With the indulgence of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), whose attention is rivetted to this speech, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table of the comparison of benefits to students under the 1983 program and students under the 1989 program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. When the scheme was introduced in 1973 the Government provided a subsidy of 55 per cent of the cost of the boarding fees. That level has not been maintained with inflation, so students and parents are very significantly disadvantaged. I continue to wonder why this Government takes such a cynical approach towards people in the country, parents in isolated areas, who are seeking to provide an education for their children that is comparable with that in metropolitan areas. I see the very significant disadvantage these children are under. I ask myself why the Government does not address the problems-why it allows, for instance, in the case of the AIC a 26.3 per cent deterioration in the value of the dollar over the period 1983 to 1989. I can only put it down to political pragmatism on the part of this Government. I recognise that the poorest 27 per cent of seats are held by the Liberal and National parties. If we are looking at hard votes, I suppose that explains it. I record my disappointment at the fact that the Government, which under this scheme is saving itself many millions of dollars, has chosen not to increase the allowance for children living in isolated areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give honourable senators an idea of the aggregate decline in support for rural students. In 1984 there were 21,651 students receiving a total of $22.9m under the AIC. That equates to $1,058 per recipient, or $1,583 in present dollar terms. In 1989-90 there are expected to be 16,500 AIC recipients. If the funding levels had remained constant there would be an allocation of $26.12m for these children. Instead, the Budget forecast is $17.34, almost $9m less. The shortfall would have been even greater if the 4,500 children being transferred from AIC to Austudy were included. The maximum Austudy allowance for children aged 16 and 17 is $2,792 compared with the 1983 maximum AIC allowance of $3,725-or $2,403 when adjusted for inflation.

So through the decline of the AIC scheme under this Government, millions of dollars which would have been available to fund rural hostels and other boarding accommodation have been withdrawn-at least $9m this year in comparison with 1983. With it the opportunity for country children to complete their secondary education is being withdrawn. In return, the families of isolated children are being given a rural hostels program with an initial funding in 1990 of $1m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the package of education Bills. It will be no surprise to honourable senators that I want to talk principally about the University of Canberra Bill. Before I do, I will comment on two of the contributions made in the debate, express some disappointment about the nature of some of the comments made in one instance, and perhaps provide some balancing comment in the other. In Senator Teague's long and interesting contribution, some of which I agree with and which was, I accept, a thoughtful and comprehensive contribution, one point was not up to the standard of the remainder.
—That usually means you disagree with him.

—I think it was arithmetically in error; that is somewhat more fundamental. He made an apparently profound point about the declining value of contributions per student in tertiary education. I thought he overlooked the fairly fundamental point that, as the number of students increases, in the normal course of events it is likely that the dollar expenditure per student will fall. It would be very easy to increase the dollar contribution per student. We could have only one and then there would be an enormous contribution per student, but it would not be a very substantial contribution to education. It is a fairly standard economic analysis that fixed and variable costs must be looked at. As the number of students increases, the relationship of fixed costs per student will fall and, even if variable costs per student-for staff, for example-are rising, the total expenditure per student is likely to fall. I thought Senator Teague's point in that respect was a bit more simplistic than the rest of his contribution and I qualify it in those terms.
—The vice-chancellors of Australia would not agree with you, Bob.

—They would agree with me. They would not agree that they do not need more money. I have never met anybody who ran any institution who did, and I am not necessarily making an argument for whether they need more money; I am simply saying that that argument is invalid. It needs to be analysed much further. Of course, the heads of institutions would like more money and they can always think of valid and important things they could do with it. That is why they run institutions. Other people have the responsibility in running the Government to make hard choices about distribution of revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: I want not so much to disagree with the things Senator Macklin said as to add a point. He spoke at some length about the nature of the educational relationship between Australia and countries in our region. In so far as I was able to hear all that he said-telephones and other things interrupted a little-my understanding was that he overlooked one substantial initiative which has been beneficial in that relationship. I refer to the initiation of the equity and merit scholarship scheme under the aid program. I think it is the best education program that has developed between Australia and not exclusively, but principally, neighbouring countries. It makes a substantial and beneficial contribution and ought to be considered in conjunction with the other comments that Senator Macklin made. I do not want to debate those points. I would rather concentrate on the University of Canberra Bill.

In supporting the Bill, I welcome the establishment of this new institution and congratulate those who have done so much work to lead to the point where the Bill can be introduced. I am confident that a smooth transition can be made from the Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE) to the University of Canberra. The people of Australia, in particular the people of Canberra, will be very proud of the institution that emerges under the new title, as they have had cause to be proud of the CCAE, which has done so much good work in the region up to now.

The sponsorship arrangement with Monash University is an appropriate mechanism for the transition in the context of higher education in Australia and the way in which the transition is being managed nationally. From discussions I have had so far with people at what is now the CCAE and what will soon be the University of Canberra, I think that until now the relationship has been beneficial and that the signs are that it will continue to be so. It is possible to argue that we could have established a very worthwhile, substantial university without the Monash connection. I think that is true, but we may establish a better university with the Monash connection. After the three years it will be very interesting to see whether there is a prevailing view that that sponsorship needs to continue.

I have a preliminary view that the conclusion drawn at that time will be that it will not need to continue and that the University of Canberra will be in a position to stand on its own two feet, but that is a judgment for three years hence. It may be that the relationship is so beneficial and future developments in it may be such that we will wish to continue it in the long term. That will be a debate in which I will be pleased to join at the time. But the sponsorship arrangement and the way in which it has been integrated into the Council of the university and the academic board of the university seem to me to be structured well. I expect that it can work both administratively and in terms of educational outcome.

The other controversial question relates to the relationship between the university and the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and its Government, as compared to the Federal Government. The most important thing is that clause 6 of the Bill quite explicitly and appropriately states that special attention is to be given to the needs of the Australian Capital Territory and the surrounding regions. Although my constituent responsibility relates only to the Capital Territory, I would be very concerned to think that the University of Canberra and the Australian National University (ANU) in the faculties in which it operates as an undergraduate university failed to see themselves as significant regional institutions rather than merely ACT institutions. They have not done so up to now.

In discussing this Bill, I will concentrate on the role of the CCAE, the prospective University of Canberra, in this matter. However, both institutions have been effectively and consciously regional institutions and that is to their credit. It is necessary for people in Canberra who sometimes see the University of Canberra, as it will be, as theirs to be encouraged in this attitude that it is ours. It is, firstly, a national institution and, secondly, one that has particular responsibility to the wider region.

In the short term, we have struck a fair compromise in the constitution of the Council and in terms of the respective roles of the Federal Government and the ACT Government, and I believe that is the view of the people of Canberra. It would be reasonable to say that the people of Canberra do not have the same confidence in the contribution that a government of the ACT might make to the management of this institution as they currently have in the Federal Government. I am confident that, after the next ACT election, a more stable government will develop, one which will develop a high standing in the eyes of the people of Canberra, as high as that which the Follett Government developed in its seven months in office. It may be that we will see a transition in that matter as well, but it may also be that the proper recognition that Canberra has a dual role as a city of 250,000 people and as the national capital, which is so much the driving force in areas like planning in Canberra, will also be a factor in determining the composition of the Council of the University of Canberra in a way that says there should be a continuing national interest, as there is at the ANU with the parliamentary representatives on its Council. There will also at some stage be a change in the Monash University representation if the sponsorship changes.

The other point I make in this debate is one about the relationship between the University of Canberra and the ANU. It is very important for those of us with children growing up in Canberra who hope that our children will have successful tertiary education opportunities here that the ANU and the University of Canberra work cooperatively and effectively on behalf of the potential students from all of Australia whom I hope the institutions will attract-but particularly, from my point of view, from the ACT. Therefore, I welcome the agreement that has been reached between the two universities, as I might call them, but it is a bit precipitate, as it relates to the University of Canberra, concerning the development of engineering education here in Canberra and in the region. I think both sides made some compromises. It may not be the perfect document, but it gives some certainty and confidence to people and encourages us to believe that that cooperative relationship can be enhanced.

So in supporting this package of legislation, and in particular the University of Canberra Bill, I express once again my enthusiasm for the emergence of this institution and my confidence that the University of Canberra will be held in high regard by the people of Canberra and by its peers in the tertiary education sector. I congratulate the Principal of the Canberra College of Advanced Education, Roger Scott, for his outstanding contribution to this transition. He has managed the political exercise so skilfully that I can only be envious. It has also been a very competent administrative task, and Roger Scott deserves to be congratulated. But no one person can make these transitions successful on their own. Although he has done a good job, its success is an indication of the support and capacity of all the people in the institution-academic staff, other staff and students. It reflects well on all of them, and it gives me confidence that the University of Canberra will be the success that I hope it will be. I support the Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, after clause 4, insert the following new clause:
Student fees
``4a. Section 13 of the Principal Act is amended:
(a) by inserting in subsection (2) ``, payable annually in 4 equal instalments,'' after ``may be charged fees''.
(b) by adding after subsection (2) the following subsection:

`(3) The Minister is to refer to the National Board of Employment, Education and Training established under section 6 of the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988, for annual inquiry, information and advice:
(a) the practice by institutions of charging fees for post-graduate courses of the kind described in subsection (2); and
(b) the effects of charging such fees on the profile of postgraduate enrolments.'.''.

The Australian Democrats have circulated a number of amendments to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2), the first of which is with regard to the instalment plan. The first amendment seeks to make payable in four equal instalments the fees which are required of students. The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1987 first gave tertiary institutions the power to charge fees with regard to a number of their postgraduate courses. At the time of the second reading debate on that Bill I indicated the opposition of the Australian Democrats to this imposition of fees on our postgraduate students. I also devoted some time to explaining why I believe the skills and capacities particularly of that group of people, who already represent a significant investment on behalf of the community in their education, really deserve the additional support. It is a simple economic proposition in many ways, in that if a student has the capacity-and, of course, the capacity of postgraduate students is estimated by the institution in which they are studying-he is accepted into a course quite specifically upon his previous academic qualifications and his capacity to undertake that particular work.

I also pointed out in that debate some of the difficulties that were emerging with regard to the exemption operation. In particular, I raised the issue of postgraduate course work programs which have proved extremely useful for teachers to upgrade their qualifications, to enable them to seek advancement within their own profession and to seek an additional academic base to their professional activities in schools. The vast bulk of people in postgraduate course-work programs operating in Australia are teachers. Unfortunately, many tertiary institutions have made quite deliberate attempts to exclude course-work programs from the ability to undertake the exemptions.

The other problem that I have alluded to in the past is that when Senator Ryan, who was then the Minister for Education, raised the issue of fees in terms of institutions which are charging these fees at the postgraduate level, we had a guarantee on behalf of the Government that the situation would be very closely monitored. I have endeavoured over this year to find out what precisely that monitoring exercise we were promised amounts to. It is still shrouded in mystery: we are still not getting information from the Government about what is happening with those postgraduate course-work fee structures. One of the risks in the development of fee-paying courses is that it will lead some institutions in the tight economic context that they all operate in at the moment to divert more of their already thinly spread resources towards these particular kinds. That may be a risk and, indeed, if one looks at some of the course offerings currently there, one will find that a major risk is turning into an actuality with regard to a number of those particular institutions. Clearly, the charging of an up-front fee of $1,800 for post-graduate courses will have an adverse effect on access to those courses, and there is no provision in the current legislation which would ameliorate this.

The amendment I am moving today is designed to allow students enrolled on fee-paying post-graduate courses to pay their fees in four equal instalments throughout the years. The beginning of the year is a particularly tough time for students, as many of them are moving house, having to pay bonds, having to pay additional travel expenses and having to purchase extremely expensive textbooks, stationery and other types of equipment. When all those things are added together at the beginning of the year, the pressure on the limited available resources of students or the resources available from their families is certainly stretched to breaking point. The ability to spread the payment-and that is all we are talking about here; we are not talking about the principle of whether there should be one or not-enables students to cope better and be in a financial position whereby they are able to pay as they go along.

I think that the introduction of this instalment plan will alleviate much of the financial hardship faced by students in a large variety of tertiary institutions. Within each tertiary institution, of course, there is generally a specialised body dealing with the question of financial hardship for students. It is their view that an instalment plan would certainly alleviate that pressure on students and that it would eliminate to a very large extent the adverse effect on participation of the up-front fee that exists. I urge the Senate to consider this proposition of ameliorating the difficulties that people face and to put in place a more reasonable method by which people can pay the required fees.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 7 after clause 16, add the following new clause:
Liability of students during enrolment
``17. The Principal Act is amended by adding the following section after section 68 in Division 3 of Part 4.4:
Liability of students during enrolment

68A. In spite of any other provisions of this Act, a student to whom paragraphs 68 (1) (a) and (b) apply, is not obliged to make payments in accordance with this Part until the student has, for whatever reason, ceased to be enrolled as a contributing student in the designated course of study with respect to which liability to make such payments arises.'.''.

This amendment seeks to add a new clause to deal with the situation of part time students. In the current situation, full time students have an option. Either they or their parents are able to pay up-front in most cases or they may delay their payment, which then becomes a tax liability which is paid off over time. I have pointed to the problem with the second arrangement in respect of people in income brackets that reach the threshold but do not go much higher than that. I do not wish to go into that matter at this time but I want to look at the position of part time students.

All part time students earning in excess of $22,000 are required to pay up-front. The main argument that I put forward on this is similar to the one that I made in relation to the previous amendment, which was just defeated: whether one is studying full time or part time, there are very many considerable course-related costs-textbooks, transport, meals and stationery. Many part time students also face significant add-on costs. For example, many women going back to studies would need to pay significant fees for child minding. Part time students would have to find a not inconsiderable amount of money that they would not normally have to find if they were not studying. So there is a major disincentive for a certain class of part time student-females with dependent children on low to moderate household incomes.

Obviously this does not affect all part time students. In the same way that full time students with resources have a capacity to pay up-front and get a discount, people in full time employment doing part time studies who have the income would pay up-front because they would save by doing so. I am not referring to those people but to the other group of people-basically female students on low incomes with dependent children.

It is useful to recall that in 1987 the higher education contribution monitoring committee recommended that part time and external students with family incomes of less than $27,024 should be exempt. This is the only outside inquiry that has been undertaken. The members of the body which undertook that inquiry made a unanimous decision that the matter should be dealt with in that way. It is interesting that this non-government group that actually looked at the effects of this matter made that recommendation. Of course, that was $27,000 in 1987 dollar terms. Under the current scheme, part time students earning a salary above $22,000 are required to pay. If they earn over $25,000 they have to make a higher payment of $220 on the first level and $450 on the second level. It will be recalled that the higher education administrative charge that had such a marked adverse effect on part time enrolments was just $263 in its final year of operation.

Typically, a person undertaking part time study is earning only an average wage. In these times, particularly with high interest rates on mortgages, that wage must be spread extremely thinly to cover all living expenses. Upon graduation, however, this person is likely to gain significant financial benefit in the form of increased salary. That also is a matter of statistical fact. Therefore, after graduation the person's ability to pay the fee rises significantly.

As in the previous amendment, I am suggesting here a rearrangement of the methods that we currently use to assist students, and particularly a certain class of student, to meet the payments. This amendment does not go to the principle of whether there should be a payment or not. It goes to the way in which that repayment is to be made so that we can best alleviate the financial pressure at the point when it occurs, and that is when one is undertaking study, particularly part time study, either to upgrade or to enhance one's capacity to earn a higher income.

The ability of part time students to pay afterwards when their course related expenses have disappeared and their income is likely to have increased as a result of a successful course of study means that after graduation from a particular course such students are in a position to pay off that debt much more rapidly than a student undertaking a three year full time course. The rearrangement would not be significant in cash flow terms to the Government. There would be a delay-I acknowledge that-of a certain amount of money coming back from these part time students. But, since it is likely to come back much more rapidly after a student's graduation, the overall effect will not greatly disturb the current income projections for the ensuing financial years. It is on that basis that I recommend this amendment to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not support the Australian Democrats' amendment. Indeed, I ask the Democrats to put that whole question to the taxpayers of Australia. It is tantamount to saying this: under this Labor Government's higher education contribution scheme, or HECS, which the Opposition will abolish, no student is required to make any current year contribution unless his or her income exceeds $22,000. Do the taxpayers of Australia want to give an interest free loan to students on high incomes in order to ease their mortgage repayment problems or whatever else while they undertake some studies?

SPEECH.PARA: In the case directly cited by Senator Macklin, a full time student with an income of $27,000 a year would be required to pay $540 in that year. Do the Democrats seriously want to put it to the taxpayers of Australia that it is reasonable for a student on an income of $27,000 not to be required to make a payment of $540 when undertaking a full time course worth $10,000 provided by the taxpayer? I believe that it is unreasonable. The Democrats may well be trying to win some marginal votes from mature age entry students in higher education, but it is not reasonable for us to give a blanket exemption to all students making up-front payments during any year in which they are enrolled.

In any event, 20 per cent of all students are choosing to pay up-front and are gaining the 15 per cent discount that the present Government offers to students who do so rather than accumulating a tax liability to be paid some time in the future. The Opposition will go a long way better than that. We will cut the annual tuition cost to a student not just by 15 per cent but by one third, so that the maximum payable by any student in any year will be reduced from $1,800 to $1,200. Students with high incomes-that is, higher than average weekly earnings-are likely to be part time students. Therefore, the costs that they will incur in that year of part time study will be short of the full tuition charges under the present Government or the much reduced charge which will apply when the Opposition comes to government, I trust after the March or May election next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had an interesting proposition from the Opposition. It objects in very strong terms to what it calls a $500 free loan. However, Senator Teague explained that the Liberals will be dropping the fee from $1,800 to $1,200, which, in my accounting, is $600 free. The Opposition has a most extraordinary proposition: it objects to assisting low income earners, yet it wants to give people $600 free.
