TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, after clause 6, insert the following new clause:
Benefits under AUSTUDY Scheme
``6a. Section 10 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting the following subsection after subsection (1a):

`(1b) In specifying circumstances in which benefits are not payable under this Part, the regulations must not have the effect of excluding from eligibility to be granted Education Assistance a student who is less than 16 years of age if the student is pursuing a non-compulsory course, or a prescribed part of a non-compulsory course, of study or instruction at an education institution for the purpose of completing the student's secondary education.'.''.

This amendment looks at an item that we discussed some time ago with regard to the ability to provide education assistance to a student who is less than 16 years old. That student is undertaking a course of study in a secondary school-the post-compulsory years of schooling-or in a tertiary institution. We need to look back to 1986 with regard to this, because at that time and in the following year the Government put the tertiary education assistance scheme in the place of the secondary allowance scheme and the adult secondary education assistance scheme. I think this was an important move because it was based on the Government's view, which I think was shared by all political parties, that there needed to be a close alignment between the level of student assistance and the unemployment benefit.

This increase in the value of student assistance was necessary to encourage young people to continue their education and training rather than go onto the dole. However, an unfortunate side effect of the legislation was the withdrawal of Austudy support to those students in senior years at school who were not yet 16 years old. As we pointed out in 1986, a considerable number of students fall into this category. The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures for 1989 are not currently available, but I think the 1988 figures give a very good indication of the number of students aged 15 or less who are likely to be in post-compulsory education this year, and who are thus ineligible for Austudy. In government schools there were approximately 31,800 students aged 15 years or less. This represented about 10 per cent of students in their post-compulsory years of schooling who were ineligible to receive any form of student assistance. In non-government schools there were approximately 13,000 students, or about 9 per cent, who fell below that age limit. So the discrimination that is operating on the basis of age affects about 44,000 students, on ABS figuring.

This discrimination was highlighted last year when the parents of a particularly gifted 12-year-old student who was planning to undertake tertiary studies were informed that, due to age requirements, their child would not qualify for student assistance. Here was a child who, due to her exceptional ability, had managed to complete her secondary schooling ahead of schedule and wanted to go ahead with her education. One would imagine that this was exactly the type of student that the country would be bending over backwards to support. Of course, had this child not been so exceptional and gone through her schooling at a regular pace, we would have been happy to support her, but because she was exceptional the Government said that it would not assist her.

At the time that issue arose, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) wrote to the Australian newspaper on 6 December 1988, defending his Department's decision. He stated that the offering of Austudy to only those students aged 16 years or older was essential in order to ensure that substantial income support should become available to students at the point at which the attraction of the dole might put them at the risk of leaving school. I have already recognised the valuable role that the payment of student assistance plays in this regard. However, I believe that the purpose of the student assistance scheme should be more than merely offering an alternative to unemployment benefit. It is my belief, and the belief of my party, that the scheme should be designed to assist the development of our young people.

Surely the attraction of the dole is not the sole motivation of students who leave post-compulsory education. The high costs involved with post-compulsory education and tertiary education often mean that parents are unable to continue to provide education for their children. If their children are aged 16 years or older, the Government is, quite rightly, prepared to meet some of these costs. However, if they are 15 years old, the Government says that the parents must pay. Clearly, the costs involved in advanced education do not suddenly arise as soon as a child becomes 16. Yet the current legislation presents it as though costs suddenly appear, out of the blue, when a student is 16 years of age. But the costs are the same for a 15-year-old as for a 16-year-old doing exactly the same course. What the Government is essentially saying to these people is, `Sure you have made it to post-secondary schooling, but you are different. You are only 15, so we are not going to help you. If you had come through like everybody else and were 16, that would be fine, but you are not, so we will discriminate against you'. So parents of 15-year-olds are trying to meet the high cost of secondary education with virtually no support from the Government.

In the letter that the Minister wrote about the costs for those under 16 in this scheme, he also said that the costs would be prohibitive. Yet he provides no evidence to show why these students are less deserving than 16-year-olds. I believe that the age limit is a purely arbitrary criterion, imposed simply to reduce the number of students eligible for assistance, and thereby reduce the cost. So, rather than encouraging gifted students to progress through schooling at a rate that suits them, this Government will punish them if they have ability. Rather than make it easier for those students to develop, it will quash them by placing disincentives in the way of their progress.

I readily admit that this is not a problem for a large number of senators representing various States here. But it is an interesting problem for Senator Teague, who is leading the debate for the Opposition. I have State distribution figures showing the percentages of 15-year-olds in year 11. They reveal some interesting facts. I am referring to government schools. The figures for non-government schools are almost identical. As I have said, the overall rate was 9.8 per cent in government schools and 9 per cent in non-government schools; so I will take government schools. In New South Wales the percentage of 15-year-olds that we are talking about is 2 per cent; in Victoria it is 1.1 per cent; in Tasmania it is one per cent; and in the Australian Capital Territory it is one per cent. However, in the Northern Territory it is 21 per cent; in Queensland it is 22 per cent; in Western Australia it is 23 per cent; and in South Australia-the State that Senator Teague comes from-it is 26 per cent. We are not dealing with a small number of people; we are dealing with a substantial number of people.

I believe that there is no rational, ethical basis for this discrimination against those 15-year-olds. They are as entitled to this allowance as are 16-year-olds. Those percentages obviously reveal something. They reveal something about the organisation and admittance criteria in those States, the age at which children begin primary school and the way in which they progress through. It is fairly obvious that Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory have a structure such that children are able to find themselves in year 11 at age 15. That is what the law of the land provides. That is what parents accept. Having complied with State law with regard to the admittance of their children to primary and secondary school, they are now to be penalised by Federal law. It is not the fault of the parents that the children are in this position, and I hope it will not be suggested here that it is the fault of the students. The fault lies with the differentiation between what we have done in this place with our legislation and what State governments have done in their legislation. It is no good our waving our arms around and saying, `That is their problem'. It is not. We have created the difficulty. We have created the discrimination, based on nothing more than that the parents and children have--
Senator Haines interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines reminds me that the Government and the Liberal Opposition voted together on this matter last time it went through. They have created a context of discrimination against those 15-year-olds in those States and the Northern Territory. There can be no justification for the continuation of this discrimination. As it results from discrepancies between our legislation and State legislation, it cannot be overcome by State legislation. The reason for that is simple: these children have been in school for 10 years. It will take another 15 years to resolve the discrimination if we change State legislation. However, we can remove that discrimination now, today, by changing the Federal legislation. It is reasonable, rational and certainly moral to do so. I hope that this time around-not in the heat of the debate as happened when a similar Bill was here the first time-the Committee will see that this is a reasonable proposition with regard to those 15-year-old students.

—The Opposition does not support the Australian Democrats' amendment. I well recall the debate in 1986 when then Senator Susan Ryan was Minister for Education. In the Budget of that year there was a response to a thorough review by the present Government of all student assistance, youth assistance, assistance for dependent children, the family allowance and other measures whereby the Commonwealth assisted families. At that time the Opposition was critical of the denial of Austudy benefits to year 11 students, particularly in my State of South Australia, in the Northern Territory and in Western Australia, where students enrol at a younger age in grade one and where there is thus a higher incidence of 15-year-old students undertaking year 11 studies than is the case in the eastern States. So I acknowledge the facts to which Senator Macklin referred. The proportions and discrepancies are exactly the same as those that we in the Opposition were critical of in the Government's decisions of 1986. Senator Macklin is right to remember that debate. But what he failed to refer to in his speech just now was that the cost of this reform at that time was $30m, and that that $30m cannot be taken on the run by a responsible Opposition and--
—We think it is $40m now.

—The Minister interjects that he thinks it is $40m now, and I am not surprised. This Opposition is a responsible Opposition that has set forth its tax and expenditure policies and its education policies. It accepts that, unless there are extraordinary circumstances, we will not upset the Budget of the elected Government. Through this amendment in the committee stage of the Student Assistance Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Democrats are trying, without any reference whatsoever to cost or to the comprehensive picture of the Government's Budget, to redress a decision that was taken two years ago. The more responsible way ahead is that which the Opposition has announced in its education policy, which is that the Liberal and National parties will, in government, thoroughly review the rules and administration of Austudy to ensure that they are fair to all. That review will be one of our urgent tasks on coming to government, hopefully after the March or May election next year. The question of 15- and 16-year-olds in years 11 and 12 of our schools, particularly in the States to which I referred earlier, will be one of the aspects of fairness to be examined in that review. In the meantime, the Opposition does not believe that an extra cost of $30m or $40m should be taken on the run in this fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find Senator Teague's explanation quite extraordinary. The Opposition was prepared to support the Government's original legislation when it was introduced, presumably after some consideration. Now it says that on the run $30m is too much to knock off a Bill. If that is the case, one needs to ask why the Opposition saw it as perfectly acceptable on Monday of this week to knock off, yet again, between $50m and $550m-depending on who one happens to be talking to at the time-from some Government tax legislation. We must ask why the Opposition saw it as being quite appropriate to vote against the Government's capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax and gold tax legislation-worth over $1 billion to Government revenue-when it is not prepared to remove possibly up to $30m worth of revenue in this case.

SPEECH.PARA: The good senator said that it would take some extraordinary circumstance for the Opposition to be able to make a decision of this kind. I suggest that we have an extraordinary circumstance in this legislation. As Senator Macklin has pointed out, this legislation is grossly discriminatory from State to State. It makes precious little difference in some States-predominantly the two main eastern States of New South Wales and Victoria-where very few students will be affected by the legislation or have been affected by the fact that the legislation exists. The reason is that in those States very few students who are 15 years of age are in those final two non-compulsory years of school. Yet their brother and sister students, if you like, in a number of other States-South Australia, Queensland and Western Australia being the main ones-are grossly discriminated against by the legislation. If those students were in New South Wales and Victoria, there would be no penalty imposed on the families and parents. However, the fact that they happen to live in Queensland, South Australia or Western Australia means that they face additional cost.

Maybe we ought to define and recognise the students and families we are talking about here. We are not talking about all families of all 15-year-olds who are in either of the last two years of school in any State in Australia. We are talking specifically about low income families-families who are entitled to Austudy under some pretty severe income test criteria. This is not something that is handed out willy-nilly to families no matter what their income is; it is handed out on a means-tested basis to low income families. I seem to recall that the maximum payment is about $40 per week. What the Opposition is saying, by and large, is that it does not care: `If low income families cannot afford to keep their 15-year-olds in school in South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland, well tough luck'. The Opposition has bigger and more important fish to fry-in particular, making sure that people on half a million dollars a year and over are no longer forced to contribute to Consolidated Revenue by way of paying capital gains tax, which is its proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why be so arrogant? Why think that you have a monopoly on virtue? You haven't.

—Talk is cheap practically anywhere, but it is particularly cheap in this place, where it is the actions that count. On Monday of this week we were concerned enough about the additional problems facing deficit-funded institutions such as public hospitals, tertiary institutions and some benevolent institutions to support an Opposition amendment to allow them to continue paying their tax monthly instead of fortnightly. We saw that as a valuable means of maintaining the already precarious financial viability of public hospitals, tertiary institutions and some benevolent agencies. We agreed with the Opposition that it was worth while cutting $50m, or whatever it was, off the likely revenue raised this year by the Government by amending its proposal. If it was good enough on Monday for $50m-or whatever the current figure happens to be-to be taken from the Government to keep public hospitals and tertiary institutions operating, it ought to be appropriate for us to spend some $30m in order to keep 15-year-olds from low income families at school in the last couple of years of their education so as to maximise their employment prospects.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not make any bones about this. Most honourable senators come from a generation in which if they left school at 15 they stood a pretty good chance of getting a job. If they worked their way up, they could do fairly nicely. However, in some cases that goes back 30 or more years. In case some honourable senators have not noticed, times have changed. Very few employers will take on 15-year-olds who have not completed at least their second to last school year. Very few will take them on in a permanent capacity in the sort of job where, when they get to be 20 or 22 and seek to marry and have a family, they are in a position to be able to keep that family with its head above water financially. So do not come the pious, mealy-mouthed proponent of social justice and equity on me, Senator Teague. You have shown no evidence in your actions of believing a word that you said. To argue that we cannot do on Wednesday for low income families with 15-year-olds trying to finish their education what we did on Monday for hard-up public institutions is, to put it mildly, a load of rubbish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The financial consequences have been mentioned. I should put a couple of points on the record. We have not sought definite legal opinion on this, but it is very likely that there are technical problems with the drafting of the amendment in that the reference to a `non-compulsory course' is probably technically inadequate.

SPEECH.PARA: What is conveniently overlooked by the Australian Democrats is that these payments are age related, just as an employment benefit is age related. In every State, leaving family allowances aside, parents are expected to accept the financial responsibility for their children until they are 16 years of age. That applies throughout Australia. The Democrats have misunderstood, or chosen not to understand, the basis of these payments-that is, that they are age related payments and not education related payments per se.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the Minister's intervention absolutely extraordinary. I have moved an amendment that specifically relates to age. Yet the Minister said that I do not realise that it is age related. That must go down as one of the most facile and stupid comments made by the Minister for a long time. Of course I understand that it is age related. I would not have moved the amendment otherwise.
—The conceptual basis, you clown.

—If Senator Walsh wants to have a debate about this, I am quite happy to have a debate. Senator Walsh knows nothing about education-he has never bothered to inform himself of his ministerial responsibilities concerning it-but he is pretty good at the abusive word. That passes, in Senator Walsh's terminology, for an education debate. I am not happy to involve myself in that particular debate, but I am happy to involve myself in a debate on the substantive issues. If Senator Walsh wants to get involved in that, good; if he wants to keep his filthy mouth to himself on other matters, that is also good.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the point he raised-which, I presume, is the reason why the Government will not accept this amendment-which is that I did not know it was age related. He obviously has not even looked at this. Why would I be moving an amendment to change the age if I did not understand it was age related? The fact of the matter is that a particular group of people is caught within a particular situation as a result of State legislation which does not line up with Federal legislation. The point I am making is that we are out of kilter. Children come in at a certain age and may find themselves in those non-compulsory years of secondary schooling, yet still at the age of 15. As I have already said, it does not happen in a number of States but it does happen in others. We are discriminating between the States in what we do with the support schemes we have in place.

It is interesting that both Senator Teague and Senator Walsh discussed the issue of money. That is important, and it should be discussed. There is a considerable cost to revenue-of course there is. Every one of these programs is a costly program. The program for 16-year-olds and upwards is costly to revenue. Presumably we consider that the cost of 16-year-olds' study is worth it. If we did not, the Government would not have introduced the legislation and, presumably, the Opposition would not have supported it. If we did not think that providing that support to a family with a 16-year-old in those circumstances was worth it, then the money would not have been provided. But I have not yet heard why it is worth it for a 16-year-old and not for a 15-year-old in identical circumstances. If it is worth it for a 16-year-old, it is worth it for a 15-year-old in exactly the same circumstances.

The difficulty is that we are dealing with a large number of people and a significant number of families. This discrimination has now gone on for two years. It will not lessen if we ignore it; in fact, it will continue. I hope the review that Senator Teague referred to, which would be put in place if a conservative government came to power, overturns the remarks that he has just made. If it does not, the review will be useless. If that review is going to mean anything it will have to look at the merits of the situation. I have suggested that the merits of a 15-year-old studying are identical to the merits of a 16-year-old studying. If the review that Senator Teague is talking about is going to say, `It will cost us that amount for 15-year-olds hence we will exclude them', I do not think that will be any review at all. If it is not going to say that, presumably it will overturn the comments Senator Teague has just made, and I would welcome that.

That the amendment (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: -I seek the Minister's response to a problem which has arisen since the Bills were last dealt with in 1988. I refer to Austudy being granted to students who attend private business colleges. The Minister will remember that at the end of last year the Senate held up States grants technical and further education assistance legislation, which was passed at the beginning of this year. At that time a number of private business colleges had government support and, thereby, their students were eligible to receive the allowance under the tertiary education assistance scheme (TEAS). At that time the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, gave a commitment that the Government would undertake to review these matters with a view to putting in place for 1990 a system to support students who attend private educational institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts of the matter are that that review, as I understand it, has not been concluded; hence, we do not have any arrangement of a comprehensive nature in place. I also understand that the Government now intends to decouple the previous policy arrangement of support to private business colleges and the provision of TEAS to their students. Next year, on an ongoing basis, the Government will continue to allow those students to be eligible for allowances under TEAS. I wish to raise a difficulty in respect of that decoupling. For those institutions which, by and large, are profit making institutions and, hence, do not receive any support from the Government-the non-business definition in the Act refers to non-profit organisations-the profit exercise is now irrelevant. We are now dealing with simply a continuation of TEAS to students but not the other side-that is, money going to a profit making institution which, quite rightly, the Government will not take on and which I am not suggesting it should.

However, I am not at all sure that equity is being served-I am sure it is not-between the non-profit making private business colleges with regard to their students. Some of these colleges have been in existence for a very long time-in a number of cases that I have documentation of they have been operating for upwards of 12 years. Oddly enough, some of these institutions have been able to partake of other government schemes such as English language intensive courses for overseas students. It is not that these other institutions whose students are not eligible to receive allowances under TEAS are not acceptable to the Government. In fact, the reverse is the case. In some cases the Government has made a choice in favour of their high quality courses being acceptable for the purposes of other programs. I ask the Minister: What consideration is being given for 1990 to enable students who attend those colleges to be eligible for TEAS allowances on the same basis as students who attend other private business colleges and who, over the years, have been eligible? If the Government is not intending to do anything in this respect next year, can the Minister explain why that is the case?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember having had some correspondence with Mr Dawkins on this matter. I do not remember all of the contents but I have some notes from the officials on this matter. The Austudy subsidy for the individual student continues for those who were enrolled at 23 August 1988. The original proposal was softened to allow colleges time to adjust to the loss of the pre-existing subsidy. The Government provided 25 per cent of the total payments made for 1988 to colleges in 1989. That scheme was terminated on 30 July.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the broader question of Austudy for students in this group, I am advised that Austudy is being paid for all students at non-government business colleges which were recognised for Austudy. Austudy for students at non-government business colleges generally is under review. It would be premature to foreshadow the arrangements for Austudy next year. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I thank the Minister for his response. In fact, the points he has just made I made in the statement I made to him. However, what I want to know is how the Government is seeking to treat the disparity that has arisen, having decoupled the grants and the student assistance. How is the Government intending to treat those business colleges which have been out in the cold on both accounts? I do not know whether the Minister has seen this in his correspondence, but those other colleges are active advertising for students to come to them, because if they come to them rather than to the college which is next to them, the students will be able to get assistance. SPEECH.PARA: The Government, by not having completed its review-the results of which the Minister openly promised, at the beginning of the year would be in place next year-has built a commercial disparity between private business colleges, which seems to me to be grossly inequitable. It may be that at a later stage the Government intends to remove all assistance. I am not seeking to canvass any issues with regard to that. I am not seeking a response with regard to that. All I am seeking is that there should be at least some possibility-and this is a matter of regulation; it is not a matter of legislation-for reputable colleges, which have been operating in the field for a reasonable period of time and which are acceptable to the Government under other programs to be put on the same commercial footing as those other colleges. In other words their courses have been vetted. I am trying to elicit from the Minister some response on the commercial inequity that is now built into the system as a result of the review not being complete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the answer was implicit in what I said earlier. The Government realises that there are some anomalous cases, and Senator Macklin is probably right in saying that. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FUTURE OF INVESTMENT AND MINING ACTIVITY IN AUSTRALIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and Minister representing the Prime Minister been drawn to the reported comments of Minister Kerin regarding the future of investment and mining activity in Australia? Does he agree with Mr Kerin's stated views that `trendy environmentalists'-and they are Mr Kerin's words-would lose Australia valuable income? He is reported to have said:

QUESTION.PARA: Mining companies aren't exploring any more and most of the manufacturing and value adding companies are going offshore.

He is also reported to have said that there is some doubt that Australia can afford to pursue the sorts of policies currently in place. In view of Mr Kerin's comments, can the Minister also say whether Senator Richardson's latest frontal attack on the Australian mining industry represents a statement of official Government policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the reported comments of Mr Kerin. I do not know to which comments Senator Parer is referring. I do not know whether the comments were made some time ago or recently.
—Today's papers.

—I have not seen those comments. I am getting to sound like a previous incumbent of this position, former Senator Reg Withers, who as a matter of principle never read newspapers. I do not decline to read them as a matter of principle, but sometimes I decline to read some of them as a matter of taste. I certainly have not failed to read that on principle this morning.

ANSWER.PARA: There are plenty of trendy environmentalists about and there are plenty of redneck industrialists about. We are about trying to achieve some sensible balance in the debate between those two extremist views, which is the most important thing for this country. There is no doubt that the Government has that view. I am unable to comment on Mr Kerin's specific allegations about particular industries, particularly the mining industry.

In terms of the long term future of this country we have to be about industry development; we also have to be about environmental protection and arriving at a balance between those two things. I think that is recognised by most civilised countries and I think we cannot be an exception to that. There are extreme views on both sides, between which a balance has to be found. I do not know what Mr Kerin specifically said about the sorts of policies in place, but I think it is agreed amongst Government Ministers that we have to reach, work towards, a balanced view on these issues-not only in government; we have to encourage that in Australian society as a whole.

In so far as I read the reports of Senator Richardson's statement, I did not see them as being a statement of policy; I saw them as a statement expressing a concern about the way some people approach this debate. Senator Richardson has received his fair share of criticism from people on the other side of the debate. I must say that some of it has been justified from time to time. On the other hand, he is entitled to hand it out occasionally, I would have thought, because there are people on the other side of the debate who need to have these sorts of things drawn to their attention. I think this is what Senator Richardson was attempting to do in the speech he made last night. I do not think Senator Richardson, although I have not discussed it with him, would claim it as a statement of policy. I think he would claim it as a statement which indicates the sorts of considerations people should take into account in looking at the concept of sustainable development. That is all I believe it amounts to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In view of Senator Button's response in respect of his inability to comment on Mr Kerin's remarks, I go back to the question I asked in regard to Senator Richardson's frontal attack on the Australian Mining Industry Council, in particular his comment as reported in the newspaper-which Senator Button said he had noted-that one of the policies Senator Richardson would pursue would be making industry pay higher prices for resources such as timber and minerals. How does the Government believe it can influence the world market prices of minerals?

—That only reflects an expression of view which is quite respectable in most countries around the world. If Senator Parer wants to live in some sort of neanderthal society where nobody considers these issues, that is his privilege. The honourable senator is a Queenslander and he has been living in a society like that for 30 years. It suddenly changed last week and he will have to adjust to a bit of that. The answer to this question might help him in the process of adjustment. Throughout the world the debate about industry takes into account the need for industry to have regard to environmental issues, and it has got to happen here too. If Senator Parer does not like it, he will continue to do what he is doing now-talk to a receding section of the community, a little group, which understands what he is talking about and gives him some comfort. I am inviting him to broaden his horizons and think a little about these issues without necessarily reaching redneck conclusions about them.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Justice been drawn to a reported comment of a retiring senior Australian Federal Police (AFP) officer, Commander `Doc' Gillespie, that `fraud on the Australian Government is costing the nation millions of dollars a year'? Does the Government agree with Commander Gillespie's estimation of the amount it loses due to fraud? What action can be taken to reduce, if not eliminate, this massive loss of public funds to criminal elements in the Australian community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is, of course, fully aware of the seriousness of fraud against its various programs. Given the nature of those programs and their very extensive reach, it is impossible to arrive at a precise figure on the total losses that might be experienced in any one year. The Government certainly has directed agencies to put their energy into actually preventing fraud against their programs, believing that it is better if the upstream agencies prevent the occurrence of fraud rather than burdening the Australian Federal Police and the court system with the results of their failure to fully protect their programs against the fraudulent activity of either their employees or other members of the community.

ANSWER.PARA: To that end, in September 1987 the Government accepted the majority of the recommendations of the review of systems for dealing with fraud on the Commonwealth. The review recommended that managers of Commonwealth programs ensure that the risk of fraud is assessed, that appropriate fraud control programs be put in place, and that procedures for the detection and prosecution of fraud be coordinated. It established the fraud control committee, made up of senior officials, to monitor the implementation of the Government's decisions. They have worked for two years doing just that. To date, 78 agencies have completed the crucial stage of submitting fraud risk assessments. Those assessments cover over 90 per cent of Commonwealth administration affected by the Government's directive on fraud control. The majority of agencies required to prepare fraud control plans have done so, and these plans are currently being implemented. Substantial progress has obviously been made in that regard.

Investigation of fraud against the Commonwealth is a major priority of the Australian Federal Police. Within the resources available to it, the AFP investigates a broad range of activity across the entire spectrum of fraud perpetrated against Commonwealth agencies. To facilitate the investigation of fraud, the AFP has concluded a series of administrative arrangements with agencies which are subject to fraud. These are viewed as essential for cooperative law enforcement at the Commonwealth level and for ensuring that fraud matters are appropriately handled. I believe that the Government has taken those necessary steps which were outlined in the report of the committee on fraud control and that we are well advanced in ensuring that the various programs of the Government are protected against this type of criminal activity, which reduces the effectiveness of those programs and leads to a loss of revenue and loss of confidence in those organisations which are funded by the taxpayer for the service of the whole Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the strong support given last night by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories for the concept of sustainable development, as envisaged in the Brundtland report. Was the Minister speaking for the Government as a whole in endorsing a concept which he says means or could mean, among other things, restricting internal population growth and/or immigration, making industry pay proper-presumably for that read `higher'-prices for resources, and cutting military spending?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two or three months ago the Prime Minister made a statement on environmental issues. In that statement he said that the Government was committed to the concept of sustainable development.
—Whatever that might mean.

—Precisely. Senator Lewis has been helpful and has made a thoughtful interjection for once. I was just going on to that point. The Government has determined to put out a discussion paper on sustainable development as a concept. We have asked for various contributions to that statement. That will help people to focus on the question in a sensible way. I believe that will happen.
—Preferably not before the election.

—I am not worried about the election. Senator Stone is worried stiff about the election. Everyday he makes these nervous interjections about it. He is almost hysterical, and I understand why. Senator Stone has decided to chance his arm in a House of Representatives seat-not too safe a seat for the National Party, if any seat in Queensland is safe for the National Party any more. Joh will intervene in Senator Stone's attempt to win that seat in the House of Representatives. He will intervene because he knows a stab in the back when he sees one and he will want to give one back, so Senator Stone has problems. I understand why he is nervous about the coming election. I am not worried about the election.
—You should be.

—Senator Boswell would know! Senator Boswell, Joh Bjelke-Petersen's right-hand man for years, was in here the week before the Queensland election psyching himself up to believe that the Nationals would win. He would know all about elections!

ANSWER.PARA: The point of the question was about a definition of sustainable development. Of course, there will be various views about what sustainable development means. We have to arrive at a sensible definition of it and all the issues referred to have to be taken into account. The issues which confront Australians-whether they are talking about sustainable development in Australia and the Australian environment, trying to have in Australia a regime which is environmentally very sound, or considering matters which adversely affect environments in other countries-have to be fronted up to by environmentalists and others. In the process of arriving at a conceptual definition of sustainable development, those issues have to be thrashed out. It is no good running away from them by asking questions here and pretending that there are no real issues; there are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am grateful to the Minister for some elaboration, but Senator Richardson was presumably not just running off at the mouth in canvassing a range of possible options. —I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to a report in the Australian on Monday, 11 December, which quoted a report by the United Nations Association of Australia which suggested that Australia's human rights record was deteriorating. Can the Minister comment on the report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of a report apparently produced by the United Nations Association of Australia which claims that Australia's human rights record at home and overseas has deteriorated since 1985. I find this a quite incredible charge and though I must admit I have not had the opportunity to consider the report itself, I have certainly seen various media reports and the press release issued by the United Nations Association of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: It is quite clear that in international circles Australia continues to be widely regarded as one of the most active countries on the question of human rights. Indeed, I believe Australia enjoys a record of concern for the protection and promotion of human rights which is second to none. For instance, in the period between July 1987 and June 1989, the Australian Government raised 780 cases of alleged human rights abuse with over 70 foreign governments. I am sure that members of Amnesty International in the Senate would recognise that those figures, which are on the public record, and those sorts of activities are quite often founded in representations made by Amnesty International itself or, at least, by the members of parliament who are members of Amnesty International's branch in this Parliament. It is very surprising, therefore, that the United Nations Association report does not refer to those specific international human rights issues where Australia has taken a leading role and has been outspoken in its condemnation of human rights abuses.

Out of some 22 existing human rights instruments, Australia is a party to 16, and amongst this number are all the major instruments dealing with human rights violations such as the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, the Convention against Torture or other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment and the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. Australia is a party to four conventions dealing with slavery. It must also be remembered that the majority of these human rights conventions came into effect prior to 1985. They were ratified by Australia at those earlier dates. It is, therefore, both irrelevant and misleading to suggest that the fact that Australia has not ratified more instruments in the recent past is in itself suggestive of a decline in Australia's interests in those areas.

Australia has also taken a leading role in preparing and progressing a new convention on the rights of the child which has been the subject of extensive discussion in this chamber. I also know that honourable senators will recall the passage through this chamber of the privacy legislation which had been on the agenda of the political parties of Australia for many years. In fact, it received the wholehearted support of all parties and senators when its passage was obtained late last year. The appointment of a Privacy Commissioner-a very practical step to protect that important human right, privacy-has also been achieved in the very recent past. I find it quite incredible that the United Nations Association of Australia should be so ignorant of or wilfully fail to give credence to the various activities, both internationally and domestically, that the Australian Government has undertaken in the protection of human rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health been drawn to a report in the Australian Financial Review of 12 December 1989 detailing the attitude of the Business Council of Australia towards the allocation of Federal funding of child-care in Australia? —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. That is a gross misrepresentation of anything I have ever said. I ask you to rule the question out of order. It contains a gross misstatement of fact, and I object to it being included in the question.
—On the point of order: I am referring to a media report this morning. Perhaps Senator Chaney would like to make a statement about that media report.

—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable senator is able to ask the question. If there has been a misrepresentation, there are Standing Orders which will enable Senator Chaney to deal with the situation later.
—I have an answer for Senator Powell from the Minister for Community Services and Health. In the same way as anyone on the other side gives some notice as a matter of decency--

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen figures issued earlier today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) showing that commencements of private dwelling units in the September quarter this year fell, in seasonally adjusted terms, by 17.6 per cent from their June quarter level? Having in mind that commencement figures are what the Leader of the Government in the Senate recently described as a `lagging indicator' of trends in the economy, is the Minister aware that, during the September quarter, private dwelling approvals-that is the step earlier in the chain-fell by 20.7 per cent, seasonally adjusted, on June quarter approvals and that finance approvals in the September quarter, which is a step further back again, fell by 19.9 per cent, seasonally adjusted, on the June quarter level? Given these movements, does the Minister expect to see private dwelling commencements fall further in the current, that is December, quarter from their sharply reduced September level? When does the Minister expect to see these developments impacting upon the level of employment and unemployment in the dwelling construction industry?

—I had a quick look at the ABS bulletin and it did show a decline in commencements over the previous quarter of 17 per cent and, if I remember correctly, about the same percentage decline in regard to commencements in the same quarter of the previous year. So it is unequivocal evidence of a slowing down in building activity. Let me make two points about that. Firstly, housing commencements had been running at a level which I would suggest was unsustainably high. For a variety of reasons they needed to come down. Indeed, It has been part of the Government's overall economic management policy that there needed to be a slow-down in housing commencements, along with a lot of other things. However, the work which is already under way, I would expect, would maintain employment levels in the building industry for a considerable time yet, probably for six or nine months.
—Not in Tasmania.

—I do not know about that. The other point that I want to make is that in the earlier part of Senator Stone's question-he did not specifically refer to Senator Button, but his comment appeared to refer to Senator Button-he referred to what is a lagged indicator or a leading indicator. What Senator Button said a couple of days ago was that employment levels are lagged behind the leading indicators of the economy-not building commencements.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am glad to have the Minister giving us at least one definition of unsustainable development, as distinct from sustainable development. But I would like to press him a little further on his expectations, which I thought I understood him to say were that employment in the dwelling construction industry could be expected now to hold up for the next six to nine months. I would like the Minister to confirm that view. If that is the case, and given the pipeline effects both of the very sharp fall in finance approvals and local authority permits that are coming through behind these falls in dwelling commencement figures, does he then accept that the implication of his own forecast is a very sharp fall at the edge of that cliff?

—Firstly, six to nine months was my recollection of the sorts of lags that could be expected. I have not checked as to whether my memory is correct. Secondly, I think the last financial year figure for building commencements was something like 160,000, although I will not guarantee that figure. It was extraordinarily high and it needed to come down. There have been occasions in the past when residential buildings has been overheated, the resources were not available to meet the demand and demand fell to sub-optimal levels. The most recent example of that happened in 1982-83. If I remember correctly, commencements in that year fell to about 102,000, which was certainly well below the optimum level of commencements. The level of building activity, although linked to commencements in a particular period, is not necessarily linked in a one to one ratio because it takes a considerable time to complete the construction of a house. I do not believe that there is the slightest chance that building activity will fall to the disastrously low levels of 1982-83.

What are honourable senators opposite all going on about? We live in the real world in Australia, not in some spooky 1960 vintage land. Always in this country there is a sort of movement back to the 1960s by some people. It is sad that the coalition forces are leading it at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you telling Australian women there is no inflation?

Did Senator Newman not notice it all that time? Did she sit here and not notice what was going on? Does she not notice what is going on in the rest of the world? TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, in that capacity and representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, would be aware of the forced return from Hong Kong of Vietnamese refugees to the country from which they have recently escaped. In view of past reports of repression of its citizens by the Government of Vietnam, I ask: Is the Government satisfied that those repatriated will not be in danger of loss of life or liberty on return to Vietnam? If it is satisfied, how is it so satisfied?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the administrative orders this falls more in the immigration area than in the foreign affairs area but, by happy coincidence, I can put on either hat. The first point is that Australia fully endorses the comprehensive plan of action which was agreed to by 35 countries at the June international conference. It is an integrated package of measures which aims to address the continuing high outflow of boat people from Vietnam. The package is based on the following principles: asylum seekers must be screened to establish their refugee claims; countries must provide first asylum while that process is undertaken; it offers resettlement for people who are refugees; and it provides for the return to the country of origin of people who are not. I interpolate there that the last point was not as specific as many people required, and I will come back to it.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the group who returned yesterday have been through the screening process, including an appeal procedure, and have been found not to be refugees. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) has participated fully in this process, endorsing the procedures as fair and objective. Counselling and legal assistance have also been provided by UNHCR-funded lawyers. Whilst I am not aware of the full circumstances of the arrangement for the return of this group, I have asked for further information on it, firstly, to ensure that the return arrangement was carried out under acceptable humanitarian conditions and, secondly, to ensure that arrangements for post-return monitoring will ensure safety and security. I have some disquiet about the timing of the removal, reported to have occurred at 3 a.m. The Government remains firmly of the view that the refugee solution should be preserved for bona fide refugees. By continuing to talk simply in terms of resettlement we are only encouraging more people to leave Vietnam.

Senator Chaney asked whether I personally or the Government could guarantee this. I do not have enough information available to do so. It does raise what has been for the last year a terrible dilemma that no-one has a solution to. I have had hardly anyone, either in an international forum or elsewhere, argue with me, that people leaving Vietnam should be automatically resettled. Most people argue for voluntary return. When that is no further an option, one is left in a terrible dilemma-whether to pursue mandatory return, as opposed to forced return, or whether to simply leave people in camps for ever, encouraging push-offs from countries of first asylum. No-one has yet found an answer. The Vietnamese Government and the United States have virtually stood in one corner of the international forum arguing one view and the rest of the countries have argued another view. Whilst these meetings have continued since Geneva, they have failed to resolve the matter. We are left with the ultimate dilemma that one series of nations is arguing for return, either voluntary or mandatory, and the others are saying no to that but are not willing to resettle them themselves and are simply leaving people in camps to rot.

There are other specific problems in terms of Hong Kong. Its capacity to absorb people is limited. It returns virtually all People's Republic of China illegals, many of whom have relatives in Hong Kong. Their claims having been screened, they are returned to the mainland. The position in Hong Kong will be exacerbated once the monsoon season has passed. The winds change in February and there will be another large influx. I do not have any absolute solutions to these particular problems. I wish I did. I am now most particularly concerned about reports of push-off. We do not want to get back to the 1979 situation when people were deliberately pushed off and deliberately drowned and left to the prey of pirates, et cetera.

In conclusion-and before Senator Chaney's supplementary question-the base problem with this is the Vietnam Government's policies, which have produced virtually a negative economic growth rate. Vietnam has an authoritarian regime. People argue that we should resettle everyone coming out of Vietnam, but there has to be consistency. There are other similar countries-not many, but a few-with similar economic conditions, with hundreds of millions of people, with similarly repressive regimes and with similar rates of economic growth. What do we do with the people in those countries when they want to relocate? I do not have a full answer to these dilemmas. I am not really confident that we will resolve them in the next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question, which is prefaced by my saying that I do not have the answers either. There are genuine dilemmas in the matters addressed by Senator Robert Ray. I thank him for his answer. However, he did slightly overstate my question in his answer when he said that I sought a guarantee, which I do not think I did. I asked whether the Government was satisfied that the people were not in danger of loss of life or liberty. What is the Government's assessment of the prospects of those people being returned to Vietnam without their being put at very personal significant risk?
