DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Alston proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's abject failure to deliver on its promise that micro-economic reform would be the centre piece of its third-term of Government with the inevitable consequences of declining living standards and increased social stresses for all Australians.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Micro-economic reform is certainly not just an arid economic term. In many ways it is the key to unlocking the quality of life for many Australians. Indeed, if we were serious about it we would acknowledge that employment is perhaps the most sought after aspiration for the vast majority of Australians. The quality of that employment is equally important, particularly where the denial of the freedom to operate constructively and to contribute successfully and efficiently to the workings of an employer enterprise are deliberately frustrated by government policy. In that situation we have a less than optimum result from which not only the nation but all Australians suffer.

SPEECH.PARA: It is therefore particularly disappointing that after the last election the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made such a great point about the significance of micro-economic reform. It is indeed the key to international competitiveness and the efficiency of Australian industry. In many ways it is the key to improved standards of living for all Australians, and that, of course, flows on not just in material terms but also in relation to the options that are available to us all.

There are not many Australians who appreciate high taxes. There are those who want taxes reduced simply because, whatever level they are at, they believe they are too high. But there are many others who rightly deplore the waste and extravagance and the dissipation of resources that they see as a result of deliberate Government decisions or indecisions. We should all sympathise with those aspirations because, quite clearly, there are people in the community who want the freedom to spend their own money in a way that suits them whilst acknowledging that they have an obligation to contribute to the public purse. But they certainly want to see governments using their funds efficiently. That is why this Government's tragic failure to deliver the goods in terms of micro-economic reform is particularly depressing for the health of the economy.

I go back to what the Prime Minister said on 26 August 1987-in other words, more than two years ago. It was described at the time by Gregory Hywood in the Australian Financial Review as `his first major speech on the economy since the July 11 election'. He was addressing a very important conference of economists in Brisbane and he told that group that the Government's efficiency agenda would grow as the task proceeded He specified a number of areas as deserving `early attention'. They included transport, aviation, the communications and information industries, government owned business enterprises, education, industrial relations and industry assistance. What a magnificent agenda! If the Government were able to deliver on the bulk of that, it would be well on the way to getting the country back into shape. The Prime Minister has been acutely conscious of the fact that under his administration we have been going backwards. The standard of living is declining to the point at which it somehow seems to be a boast of this Government that it has been instrumental in reducing living standards and presiding over a fall in real wages. I will come to the concomitant result, which is declining productivity throughout the period.

Clearly, if we are interested in competing-as I think Senator Button is from time to time, but perhaps not so much in a pre-election environment-and if we are interested in going offshore and mixing with the four tigers and all those others who are leaving us for dead, quite obviously the key is to reduce the cost of our inputs. If we can tackle those micro-economic infrastructure areas, we will be well on the way. The tragedy is that we have not done that. Those things have all been put in the too-hard basket and, as a result, the Government is hoist on its own petard. The Prime Minister said in that landmark speech that efficiency is the key. He was talking then about possible asset sales and said that this was `not some ideological debate about appropriate levels of public ownership'. In other words, he was rising above the ideology. He knew what was needed and he was going to deliver. He went on to say, in running through his agenda for reform, that past transport policy and practice had not kept costs down and that this had exacerbated the disadvantages of Australia's isolation. He said:
Accordingly, one of the major items on the agenda of this term of government is a sweeping reform of the nation's transport infrastructure.
They are brave words. He went on to say what I think even blind Freddy knows, which is that in the communications field we have a potentially major growth sector. He said:
Legislation and the dominance of government business enterprises mean that Government decisions, or the lack of them,-
how prophetic-
will have a major influence on the future of this sector.
We will need to examine ways to improve the performance of these enterprises.

Who could quarrel with any of that? That is precisely what is required. For a period of 18 months or so that was the major agenda item. Senator Evans, before he was rolled by the Telecom Australia monopoly preservation society in May 1988, which managed to head off all the brave new world which would have allowed real competition with Telecom and which would have opened up that sector in such a way that we would have been able to compete with the rest of the world, in tabling the May statement, said in his foreword:

In describing the Government's third-term agenda, the Prime Minister has given greatest emphasis to micro-economic policy: the structural adjustment of key industries, and the relationships between them, with a view to establishing and sustaining longer term growth.

That was a mere 18 months ago. The primacy of micro-economic reform was apparent. Senator Evans knew it. Those in the Government interested in improving the efficiency of the economy, and therefore passing on those real achievements to ordinary Australians and thereby improving both their material and spiritual aspirations to life, realised that this was crucial if the economy was to be got right. They knew that if exports were to exceed imports, they had to get a micro-economic reform agenda in place. But, unfortunately, what has happened is that this Government, this Prime Minister-all the big talkers-have been rolled, comprehensively and frequently, by the left wing, by the Public Service trade unions, by the anti-privateers, to the point at which we have had humiliating examples of Mr Hawke putting up his hand one day and Mr Willis tentatively supporting him, but both being chopped off and both going to ground. We have had other examples. Senator Walsh's frustration has shown through from time to time. A clutch of Ministers, Senator Button amongst them, know what is required.

But what has happened? What about that greatest economic advocate, the man who is held up, as he was by commentators until fairly recently, as somehow the acme of economic achievement-the Treasurer (Mr Keating). What did he have to say about micro-economic reform? On 20 November it was all dismissed as small beer. Micro-economic reform was small beer, said Mr Keating. It is pathetic because, quite clearly, this was the Government's own self-proclaimed agenda. It set the hurdle. It said that it was prepared to jump it; but it has not even bothered to try to run through it. It has simply baulked and is now trying to wish it away. It attempts to deny the obvious, which fools no-one and which has to be regarded as a monumental concession of failure. This is not just some cheap debating point. By the Government's own standards, micro-economic reform was to be the key to unlocking the revolution. That is why it is so tragic that we have seen what we have seen, which is virtually no progress at all in this important range of areas.

Senator Archer will deal with coastal shipping and the waterfront, I trust. He provided me with some very illuminating comments from a recent transcript. They show quite clearly some of the real problems that are still dramatically in place on the waterfront. Indeed, one of the participants in that discussion described the waterfront not as the gateway but as the barrier to exports. Anyone who realises that it costs about $30,000 a day to keep a ship in port, and then realises that sometimes ships have to wait up to a week in turnaround time when this is accomplished in a matter of hours in comparable ports overseas, will have some idea of the dimensions of the problem. The comparison between Rotterdam and Melbourne or Sydney is perhaps also apposite. Rotterdam was rebuilt from the ground up. It was completely devastated in the Second World War and is now perhaps the most efficient port in the world. It is said about Rotterdam that one can do twice the work for half the cost. That was said about Sydney. I do not need to labour the point because the descriptions of the difficulties of Sydney are legendary. We all know what they are and that the Government has pretended to do something about them. But it simply will not bite the bullet and allow foreign competition to come in. Presumably it will pander to the Tas Bulls of this world who think the solution has something to do with providing financial incentives to change the culture of the waterfront. Again, it is tragically irrelevant to think that somehow we need to bribe people in that way. We all know what they would do: they would put the money in their pockets and ask for more.

Perhaps the best objective indication of the Government's throwing in of the towel in this whole area was the Industry Commission Bill, which was recently dealt with in the Senate and which effectively abolishes the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). The Government's greatest achievement is that it has put the IAC out of business, parked it into some new restructured body and pretended to be on the way to micro-economic reform. We do not hear much criticism of the IAC; it is really all about it being too hard to deliver, certainly in the run up to an election. In debate in this chamber on that Bill, Senator Walsh was, as usual, full of bile but did not have much criticism to make of the IAC or its reports. It was really just a matter of his trying to justify this new Industry Commission-a mickey mouse solution to a very real problem. An editorial in the Australian of 10 November said this of the IAC:
Of 14 completed IAC inquiries, the recommendations of only three have been substantially implemented by the Government.

That spells out in very stark terms precisely what it is that has not been delivered on. We all know that the failure to open up the waterfront to foreign competition is costing us about $500m a year. Senator Knowles will deal with the personal costs to Australians of that failure to grasp the nettle, but this year's annual report of the IAC, which was released recently, notes that key micro-economic reforms could increase gross domestic product by around $16 billion and average household income by more than $1,600 per year. We all understand what the average Australian could do with an extra $30 in the pocket especially when, since 1983, the value of real wages has declined by about $60 a week. This is not a discussion about economics; it is a discussion about what is happening to the purchasing power of ordinary Australians.

Some classic examples of why there is an urgent need for micro-economic reform are contained in the IAC's annual report. For example, in Queensland a scrap metal exporter is forced to pay $14 per tonne to get scrap metal on board, compared with $1.70 in the United Kingdom and $2.50 in the United States. The exporter which the IAC quoted estimates that he could do it himself for $1 per tonne. In other words, it would be cheaper for him to pay the waterside workers to stay away.

The Inter-State Commission found that wharf labourers' wages have been about 40 per cent above the national average for the past decade. Currently they earn about $800 for a nominal 35-hour week, although in practice, with all the pooling arrangements and other excuses for work, it works out at about 28 hours a week. That is a scandalous state of affairs. It is one which the Government is clearly aware of but unable to do anything about. The tragedy is that the Government is union driven. Despite the fact that only about one-third of the private sector is unionised, 75 per cent of the public sector is very much in the trade union movement and wields a great deal of power in the Australian Council of Trade Unions. As a result, there are legion examples of where there ought to be significant reforms but no-one is prepared to tackle them.

Telecommunications is an area in which I have taken a particular interest and now have responsibility for. That is probably the best example one can find. For a long time we have sheltered behind this smokescreen of community service obligations (CSOs) as justification for maintaining such extensive monopoly practices which are clearly inefficient, to the point where the IAC says that we are about 20 per cent less efficient than our Canadian counterparts. Telecommunications cost the average business about $30 a week by way of input. We could easily carve hundreds of millions of dollars a year from the nation's telephone bill. We could reduce subscriber trunk dialling rates by half and we could get local call charges down significantly. We could do all that we need to do in a fully competitive environment, yet the Government has allowed the telecommunications Telecom unions to hoodwink the public into believing that these so-called community service obligations need to be justified by extensive monopoly practices.

Again, the IAC blows that out of the water. It says that CSOs could be supplied in a competitive market environment if the way in which they are financed were changed. For example, their costs could be covered by a levy on all users of the service or by direct government funding. That simple proposition has been blindingly apparent for some years. The Government has had seven years in which to tackle the problem and is still deferring it. After sitting on the report for nearly three months, Mr Willis released it last week. The report confirmed what we all knew-that is, the cost of Telecom Australia's community service obligations is of the order of $240m a year, which is equivalent to about 1c per local call and about 5c per international call which, to quote Mr Keating's term, is certainly very small beer. It is something which Telecom could probably withstand in an open and competitive environment, but it could certainly be funded with a minimum of pain through other mechanisms. I have no doubt that in a competitive environment the efficiencies that would flow through to the system would leave Telecom in a much stronger position, better able to compete internationally and better able to deliver the quality of service that Australians expect from a national telecommunications carrier. Yet the Government will limp through to the next election having done virtually nothing in that and other very important areas.

I do not think that one can do more than hark back to Mr Hawke's heroic terms and look at how abjectly he has failed. In many ways it is a sad sight to see a rapidly ageing political leader who knows what needs to be done but simply does not have the political clout or perhaps the intestinal fortitude to try to bring it about.

TALK.START.PARA: —No facelift yet.

—Senator Button should not get too personal about the Prime Minister's family. The reality is that Mr Hawke knows what needs to be done, as does Senator Button and as do a number of his colleagues. However, they are unable to deliver the goods. We would all be much better off if we were able to achieve micro-economic reform. Although the Government has our wholehearted support, it is not prepared to tackle that. The reason is abundantly obvious: it will embarrass some of its political allies who are clearly lead in the saddlebags and wilfully ignorant of what is required to get Australia back on the track. However, they are determined to frustrate those very necessary changes to achieve their own political agendas. That is tragic. The Government has had seven years to do something about it, but clearly it is not interested in pursuing the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Micro-economic reform has many direct implications for Australian society and for the way in which we can work efficiently. I believe that one of the most satisfying things in life is to do a job constructively-not to try to protect one's own patch and worry about how one can screw even more rights and entitlements out of the boss, but to be part of a team and to start delivering constructively. If these enterprises were opened up to competition there is no doubt that that is what would flow. The IAC said that that is the key, that competition is the secret. Perhaps even more importantly for left wing members of the Australian Labor Party who think that this is all irrelevant, that it is just an ideological debate, the IAC says that the employment gains which would flow from long term micro-economic reforms would be equivalent to about 35,000 extra jobs.

There it is. Does the Government want it or not? Does the Government want to deliver the goods or not, or will the position continue to be as the Macquarie Bank sets out-that as a result of the 4 per cent second tier increase, 90 per cent of the work force will get the wage increases without delivering the productivity gains? What a damning indictment. What a pathetic state of affairs. All we have is talk and the Government's caving in as it is not prepared to tackle the hard issues. Look at the pathetic cry for help yesterday by Ted Harris, one of the Prime Minister's great mates, that Australian Airlines Ltd, despite its good profit result, faces some critical issues. By direct implication he was critical of the Government. He said that to do nothing or to introduce ad hoc measures that do not properly address the capital injection and constraint issues may put at risk a very valuable public asset. He said that resolution of these issues is critical to the future progress of the airline.

Aviation, transport, the waterfront, telecommunications-all these are areas in which the Government has not been prepared to provide the necessary funds, to open up the environment and to let the work force contribute and achieve, but rather has stultified and undoubtedly will pay the penalty in due course. As a result, we are going backwards. Senator Button knows it and the economists in the Cabinet know it, but unfortunately they do not have the political will to do anything about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston, who proposed the matter of public importance, spent a lot of time discussing what he sees as instances of inefficiency in his particular bete noires-the waterfront, Telecom Australia and the airlines. However, he failed to address his own matter of public importance, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's abject failure to deliver on its promise that micro-economic reform would be the centrepiece of its third term of Government with the inevitable consequences of declining living standards and increased social stresses for all Australians.

I was delighted to hear Senator Alston refer to quality of life and standards of living, but he gave us no indication that he has any interest whatsoever in the effects of what he says is the Government's abject failure. He managed to ignore the palpable overall gains of the Government and its policies over the last seven years.

Senator Barney Cooney will deal with the details of micro-economic reform, of which there is a substantial record. I would like to deal more directly with the actual effects. It is interesting that Senator Alston's proposal talks about not only declining living standards-which is obviously incorrect, as I will show in a moment-but also increased social stresses for all Australians. There is a very respectable body of academic writing which proves quite conclusively that social stress is never greater than when unemployment is high and increasing. When this Government came to power in 1983 the unemployment rate was almost 11 per cent-in fact, in the middle of that year it reached 11 per cent. The unemployment rate is now 6 per cent. There is no doubt at all that one of the greatest ways in which social stress can be reduced is by the policies that this Government has introduced-policies that have greatly increased the employment participation rate in Australia.

The principal effect of a greatly improved employment participation rate is greatly improved real disposable household incomes. Figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics show quite clearly that over the last six years there has been an average increase in real disposable household incomes-deflated by the implicit price deflater for private final consumption expenditure-of very close to 3 per cent. In every one of those six years, except for one-1986-87, when there was a small reduction of 0.2 per cent-there has been an increase, on average, of around 3 per cent. That is a very substantial increase in household incomes. This increase is easily traced back to the fact that there has been a substantial increase in the labour force participation rate for women during that period.

There was a little exchange or two during Question Time today about the attitude that is taken by so many people in the Federal Liberal Party, that women are being conscripted into the work force, as if they have no minds of their own and as if somebody is telling them they must go to work. I think most of us recognise these days that women work for exactly the same reasons that men work-in order to earn their living and pay for rent, food and clothing.
I would like to quote a line or two from a newspaper article which reported something said by Mr John Howard. I am amazed by his male chauvinism, which comes through very clearly. Having said:
If you live in Sydney-
he is clearly addressing a male, or notionally male, audience-
. . . in particular and you're earning $27,000 . . . and you want to start a family and you want your wife to stop work, you're not in the hunt, you haven't got a hope.

I suggest that men who adopt that role within families these days certainly do not have a hope if they do not recognise the fact that their wives have skills, talents, needs and the right and the capacity to make their own decisions. I do not think I can do better than quote Senator Amanda Vanstone who said, extremely perspicaciously:
These women in the workforce aren't shells on the beach simply brought in by a bad economy. They represent change in the beach head itself.

They represent the fact that there is a greatly increased demand for female employment. There is a greatly increased capacity for part-time employment, considerably more access to affordable child-care and considerable growth in the service industries where women are employed in substantial numbers.

The employment participation rate to which I referred has increased-not only for women, but generally-during the seven years of the Hawke Labor Government, from 60.8 per cent in 1983-84 to 62.6 per cent. That represents a considerable number of jobs, as this chamber has been reminded consistently over the last few years. For example, in the last 12 months the increase in the number of jobs was 219,000. One may believe that many of those new jobs are part-time jobs-particularly the ones in which women are inclined to be employed-but, interestingly enough, that does not necessarily follow. The increase in full-time employment for females in the age group of 25 to 34 is nearly 10 per cent. Even in age groups older than that, the increases are 7.8 per cent for those up to the age of 54 and 2.9 per cent for those between the ages of 55 and 59. This is an extremely interesting phenomenon. Even for the group aged 60 to 64, there was an increase of 2.9 per cent between 1982 and 1988 in the number of women in full time employment.

As far as part time employment is concerned, the greatest increases are amongst those who are very young. That clearly indicates the phenomenon of young women working part time while continuing in the education system or training so that they can get better opportunities. We are seeing the social phenomenon of a greatly increased range of opportunities for women in the work force, many of which are a direct result of the policies that have been adopted by the Hawke Government, and I have detailed just a few of them.

Amongst the other remarks that he made in this debate, Senator Alston was extremely critical of the fact that there are such close ties between this Government and the trade union movement. Senator Alston might be interested to know that the corporate gross operating surplus share-which is, in effect, profit-over the years of the Hawke Government has increased from 13.4 per cent in 1983-84 to 18.5 per cent in 1988-89. This is one of the deliberate effects of the accord. The trade union movement, in conjunction with the Government, consciously set out to improve profit share in order that profits should go into the restructuring of Australian industry-into the purchase of new technology; the upgrading of outmoded machinery, which has been such a bugbear as far as our manufacturing sector is concerned; better software and better hardware for computerisation; and, of course, almost more importantly than anything else, better training and retraining.

The majority of Australian workers are not members of unions and, regrettably, the proportion is falling. However, I remind the Senate that whether or not people are members of unions, the vast majority of them are getting the benefits of the work that is being done by trade unions to improve their working conditions. The trade unions have maintained a close contact with the Government in overall policy development which has led-and I go back to the figures I gave before-to a substantial increase in real household disposable income. The Opposition may not want to talk about that but it is this figure which determines the way in which families are able to operate. Many Australian families are in a vastly better situation now than they were six or seven years ago for the very reason that there are more incomes in households-they may not all be full time incomes but they have made a great difference to the expectations of Australian families.

Senator Alston said that he wants to see substantial changes in a whole range of industrial policies. He is managing to avoid looking at the substantial changes that have already occurred in the form of productivity increases; a better educated work force; the fact that we are able to encourage young people to stay at school and to increase their opportunities quite substantially; and the fact, which I come back to, that so many women feel that they are now able, in addition to what ever domestic responsibilities they have, to join the work force, to expand their skills, to contribute economically to their own families, in some cases to become independent and in many cases to improve their families' standard of living.

The demand for the sort of work that many women are employed to do has been growing over the last few years. A shortage is now developing to the point where it is realised in Australia and in similar countries such as the United States that there will be opportunities for the vast majority of women to join the paid work force, probably for most of their adult working lives. I do not know what sort of a model Czechoslovakia is for Australia, but 82 per cent of Czechoslovakian women are in the paid work force, in a country that is very highly industrialised. This opportunity must be accompanied by all the others that make it possible for women to work, such as increased access to children's services.

It is not so long since an employment consultant in the United States, speaking to a group of businessmen, told them that the majority of women who were employed would be taking maternity leave once, twice or perhaps three times during their working lives. The employers to whom she was speaking said, `Well, we shan't employ them, then'. They were reminded that they would have no choice, that unless they were prepared to employ women they would be short of workers and that it was a matter that they would have to come to grips with. Similarly we in Australia have had to come to grips with the fact that, unless we provide benefits such as maternity leave for our workers, we will lose good trained workers, mature women, who are amongst the most sought after in the work force and who have every entitlement, we believe, for some time off for the purpose of bearing and caring for their children. Madam Acting Deputy President, you may be aware that a case has just been completed in the Industrial Relations Commission seeking parental leave for fathers so that they also may have unpaid leave in order to be available to participate in parenting.

There have been very many social improvements of this nature over the years, adding to the quality of life about which we were reminded by Senator Alston but which he has managed to avoid discussing. I come back to the fact that the retention rate of young people in secondary schools has greatly expanded. This will clearly have long term, highly advantageous effects for the Australian economy. I doubt very much that this would have been the case had we not had a Hawke Government, one that was absolutely committed to ensuring that young people were able to stay in the education system. Having made that decision, the Government then worked on a range of measures which would make that possible. Austudy, providing an allowance for 16- and 17-year-olds still in the education system, has been one of the most important.

Besides this, the climate has been changed so that there is not the feeling of desperation and social stress-to quote from Senator Alston's motion-which led so many young people to believe that there was simply no future for them. This stress has been lifted from the shoulders of very many of our young people. Their opportunities, their hopes for the future, have been greatly expanded as a result. Their family's expectations also have changed. I recall very clearly that three or four years ago, with the memories of the very high unemployment rates in 1982-83, young people were quite desperate about their opportunities for the future. It is not the case now. I do not call this an abject failure by the Government; I call it a considerable achievement by the Government and probably one of the greatest achievements, if one could look to the future and to the long term implications of any particular policy.

Since Senator Vanstone has come back into the chamber, I just mention that I quoted her very accurately and attributed to her what I thought was an extremely intelligent comment. I would like to give a little gratuitous assistance to the Liberal Party of Australia, which seems to find quite a deal of difficulty in describing its front bench people accurately. According to an article by Pilita Clark, it is hard for Liberal Party members to use any term other than `spokesman'. In the cause of accuracy I make two or three suggestions: Opposition members could refer to them as people speaking on behalf of the coalition on this, that, or the other issue; or perhaps the coalition or shadow commentators on this, that, or the other issue. It is not a minor matter.

We on the Government side are very proud of our women Ministers. We are also very proud that we have women who can speak on behalf of our Party and our policies and we are glad to identify them as women who have already made a contribution not only to the Australian Labor Party but also to policy-making and, by extension, to the government and well-being, the quality of life, of the people of this country. I suggest that the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia follow suit and make it clear to the community when a women is speaking on its behalf that she speaks on behalf of their party and, we hope, on behalf of women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, we have before us a fairly extraordinary matter of public importance put forward by the Opposition complaining about the economic performance of the Government-in essence in this case its slowness in implementing Opposition policies on deregulation and privatisation. It is yet another attempt to draw a picture of the Government and the Opposition as being markedly different in the run-up to an election. Those opposite do not want the voters to realise how very closely the actions of the Hawke Government match the policies of the Opposition. I would say that it is a vain hope.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, the regular polls and the South Australian election result demonstrate that more and more people are seeing that the Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party resemble the Tweedle brothers. There are slight nuances of difference but basically the Opposition and the Government are going down similar tracks. Even the media is acknowledging that fact at this point. Where once only the Democrats would have referred to the Opposition and the Government as Tweedledum and Tweedledee, we are now seeing that in the popular press. As I said, this is a complaint by the Opposition about the Government's economic performance with particular reference to micro-economic reform along a policy track on which the Opposition would want to push this country. We need to look at the performance so far and at the results. We agree with that part of the wording of the matter of public importance which expresses concern about living standards and social stress extended to problems concerning the quality of life of all Australians.

Let us look at deregulation and the privatisation push and let us see what has happened under this Government and what complaint the Opposition might have. I want to express complaints that the Democrats have on both counts-the Government's performance and the Opposition's policies. I will start with the deregulated position of Australia in the world trade scene because we have a major problem with our deficit on current account, and we have been told that we have to trade our way out of it. Since the floating of the Australian dollar, our net foreign debt has increased from 6 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) under the Fraser Government to 30 per cent of GDP today. Our markets have been flung open for overseas access at the same time as genuine support for Australian industry has been reduced in a number of areas, especially in the research area, to the extent that we are now operating as the most unassisted free market economy amongst Western industrial nations. By way of comparison, we can look at West Germany and Japan, whose economies are still highly regulated and shielded, to a large extent, from overseas competition. Yet the Australian people are the ones who continue to pay the cost of this aspect of deregulation.

The Opposition, by this motion, a number of previous motions and, I am sure, some subsequent ones, wants to continue to urge the Federal Government to go blindly down this path in spite of its obvious failure to do anything for the people of Australia. Financial deregulation is an area in which the Opposition has concurred wholeheartedly, except perhaps inasmuch as it had to sit here and watch the Hawke Government deregulate the financial system and to acknowledge that it was not able to do that under Malcolm Fraser. Of course, John Howard would have wanted to do so, but he was not able to have his will prevail. So if the Opposition has a problem about financial deregulation, it is only the `green with envy' problem.

Financial deregulation has not, as we were promised, increased competition in the Australian banking system. Since the introduction of foreign banks and the deregulation of the banking system, the number of banks actively involved in the lending of money to ordinary Australians for housing loans, for instance, has reduced significantly and further amalgamations appear likely. Neither we, nor the average Australian consumer, can see any benefit gained by the people of Australia out of this exercise. Rather, we have seen interest rates reach record levels, bank profits soar and bankruptcies increase. On top of this, the Federal Government has given the banks an additional $200m. I noticed, looking through my files this morning, that the announcement of that was made on 29 September, which happens to be my birthday. I wish I had got such a good birthday present as the banks have had in recent years from this deregulationist government.

A major feature of concern in this area for the people of Australia is interest rates, so let us look for a moment at that issue. It is a blunt instrument which the Government is using to beat ordinary Australian families around the head on the basis that it is their responsibility-the responsibility of ordinary Australian families-to fix up the economic mess that this deregulationist approach has created. Families are hard-pressed to feed and clothe themselves while they pay the ever rising mortgages; families are not able to meet the payments and are therefore, losing their homes; and other families give up all hope of ever owning a home, the Australian dream. It is certainly affecting living standards, and it is certainly increasing social stress.

But at that point, we have to ask what the Opposition would do-after all, deregulation is its policy. We have a motion before us today on that matter. From the Opposition members' own mouths, including no less a person than the spokesperson for finance, Senator Stone, we have been told that we may not necessarily expect any relief on interest rates should the Government fall. Indeed, there has been no action, where the opportunities have arisen, by the Opposition in Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not been told that at all.

—I normally do not respond to interjections when I am giving a speech, but I am happy to have Senator Vanstone's interjection on the record because I refer Senator Vanstone to several matters of public importance in recent weeks mounted by Senator Stone in which, in his speeches, he made it quite clear that the Australian people should not expect interest rates to come down at the time of the change of government and within any short space of time thereafter. As I said, nor have we had any action in this chamber on the question of interest rates where the opportunity has been afforded by the Australian Democrats, namely, by Senator Haines, both by potential amendment to legislation and through private members legislation, for action on measures to encourage savings, to provide affordable housing finance to Australians and, in particular, tax deductions for interest payments which have to be made on mortgages. No, what we see is an adherence to the great god of market forces.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look a bit more at what has come from deregulated banking. Just last week, a recent report, which was put together by the Australian Financial Counselling and Credit Reform Association, was released. It found that Australian banks were the most profitable amongst major Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries and that consumers are subsidising them. That report has made it clear that the success of foreign banks in the retail market has not matched the predictions which were made at the time of the entry of those foreign banks, an entry opposed only by the Australian Democrats at the time. After significant losses, many of those foreign banks have withdrawn leaving the major banks in a very powerful market position, despite the increase in the number of players initially. The very disturbing aspect revealed by this report is that the subsidisation by people over 55 years in our community amounts to more than $87m a year, and by lower-income groups to $98m a year.

So we fail to see how that aspect of the deregulation policy can be seen to be of benefit to the Australian people, a policy supported by the Opposition and promoted by this matter of public importance. Another area destined for increased deregulation is the labour markets, should the Opposition's policies be in place or should the Government move faster down the track of the Opposition's policies, as this matter of public importance would have it do. Kenneth Davidson in the Age newspaper on 27 November said:
. . . credibility on interest rates boils down to credibility on wages policy.

Here we can see why we are cautioned about any prospect of lowering interest rates upon a change of government. Clearly the deregulated labour market system of the Opposition is destined to have a disastrous effect on our economy. I am not the only one who is making this proposition. Again I refer to Kenneth Davidson's comments. He said that such policies are destined, in all probability, to force interest rates even higher. In this area, we see that the Government has not deregulated to the extent that the Opposition would like. Therefore, through the accord, the Government has been able to reduce the average unit cost of labour in Australia. But, indeed, Australia's workers have not had a real increase in their average rate of pay as they might have done without the accord. Support for the industrial relations deregulation policies of the Opposition would have to be based on expectations by workers that they would achieve higher real wages. This is likely to occur perhaps for some people in that system, those attached to strong unions, and those with compliant employers, for whom their own individual profits mean a great deal more than the general economic well-being of the community. As far as we are concerned, the labour market policy must be based on a basic minimum income for workers, adequacy of income and appropriate reward for labour.

We are concerned at the Government's talk about enterprise bargaining unless it is underpinned by a centralised structure and one which acknowledges the need for an adequate and appropriate reward. Clearly, we do have in our economy and, therefore, in our community the kind of stress which is being caused by that economic pressure, which in turn, we pose, is put through this deregulationist policy and the outright use of market forces. For that reason I certainly welcome, two days after my call for it, a summit on poverty which has been announced today by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), although I do think he could have at least involved the community groups. Nevertheless, I think that, if the Government were to go further down the micro-economic track, which is being urged on it by the Opposition's matter of public importance today, in the area of transport, communications, health, education, child-care, or whatever one would like to name, then the stress would be even worse. Surely that is one of the messages that would come out of the summit proposed by the Prime Minister.

According to the Opposition, the Government is too slow to act-too slow for the Opposition, anyway. I think we can see what further mayhem, deprivation and poverty would be caused by continuing further down that track. It is reasonably clear now that the Government probably would have moved faster in a great many of the areas-which the Opposition would have liked it to do-were it not for the fact that there has been resistance in the community, that that community resistance has been brought into this place by the Australian Democrats and that, therefore, it has not been able to be ignored. It has been a cautionary note, and we have been proud to be a part of the delivery of that cautionary note to this Government. I will conclude by quoting the editorial from the Melbourne Herald on 30 November 1989. The article states:

The Democrats are successfully carving a niche among electors who suspect the motives of politicians from both the major parties . . . They are not swayed by a set of expedients cut to suit the campaigning needs of a particular day.
That is exactly the reason this matter of public importance is before us today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a matter of public importance which I will read because, unfortunately, the last two speakers really have not referred to it at all. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's abject failure to deliver on its promise that micro-economic reform would be the centrepiece of its third term of Government with the inevitable consequences of declining living standards and increased social stresses for all Australians.

As I say, I read that just to remind the Senate what we are actually debating, because Senator Giles's contribution, although a cute little speech, contained nothing really about the subject. Clearly she is like the rest of the Government senators and members-she does not understand what micro-economic reform means and what benefits can be derived by Australians when a government has the courage actually to implement it.

Then, of course, we heard Senator Powell. There was nothing unusual about Senator Powell's contribution because it was simply the Australian Democrats further being apologists for the Government. They want to prove that there is absolutely no difference between the Democrats and the Government or that they are further to the left than the Government. Having listened very carefully to Senator Powell's contribution, I really do feel that probably the better place for her this afternoon would have been as the clown at the front of Parliament House in the Ashton's Circus demonstration. She too obviously does not know what micro-economic reform is all about. We all wait very patiently to see whether Senator Powell, before she leaves, will deliver in this place a speech that makes some sort of sense or actually demonstrates some sort of logic.

The real thrust of this debate this afternoon is this: the Treasurer (Mr Keating) may express the view of the Hawke Labor Government that micro-economic reform is `small beer', as he did on 28 November, but I rise in support of this matter of public importance precisely because Australia must win this battle if ordinary Australians are to enjoy an adequate standard of living. Many Australians, I suppose, really do not have the faintest idea of what micro-economic reform is, let alone how such reform will be of benefit to them. What we must do today is clearly demonstrate to the people of Australia what it really does mean to them at the end of the day.

What we are talking about is a type of reform that will attempt to create greater efficiency, and thereby competitiveness, for both the public and private sectors. This means that the huge current account deficit and foreign debt that have been amassed by the Hawke-Keating Government will be reduced. As our foreign debt is now totally out of control, thanks to Mr Keating, a repayment bill of $7,000 has been lumped on every man, woman and child which is rising at the rate of $108 every month. If Australians believe that they have enough debts of their own, how often do they stop and consider that this Government is amassing debts on their behalf? That is something that we simply cannot allow to continue, because the interest payment alone on this debt is costing every man, woman and child $625 this year-that is purely and simply the interest. Micro-economic reform is, therefore, essential if that burden is to be lifted from their backs.

The question may well be asked: how will this be achieved? The most fundamental measures that need to be taken are the abolition of restrictive practices and unnecessary regulation; more cost efficient delivery of communication and transport services-I was very alarmed to hear Senator Powell say a moment ago that she did not consider that that type of efficiency was either necessary or desirable; and increasing flexibility and competition in both the public and private sectors. People must realise sooner or later that profit is not a dirty word. Without profits there are simply no jobs, less income, and more hardships for many people, and that cannot be allowed to continue. The Hawke-Keating Government has talked long and hard about micro-economic reform, but has failed to deliver anything remotely like it. The Australian newspaper was correct when, on 10 November, it stated:
No previous government has been better informed about Australia's economic sclerosis.

This Labor Government has only substantially implemented three of the 14 reports that have been received from the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) and that have pointed the way to micro-economic reform. One may say that it does not have the know-how or that it is simply lacking the courage. Whatever excuse it might be, there is a real need for micro-economic reform today and in the very near future.

It is not only the word of the coalition that such reform will benefit Australian families. The Industries Assistance Commission in its 1988-89 report makes it clear that, if reform of transport and communications, together with reductions in protection, were to be implemented, then the $16 billion improvement in our gross domestic product-how much Australia produces-would translate into an average increase in household income of $1,600 annually. That is no small amount. The amount of $1,600 annually means that every household would increase income by at least $30 per week. This amount is not insignificant when a middle income family is confronted with bills such as $50 to $60 per pair of school shoes two or three times a year for every child, plus uniforms, sports clothes, books and transport-just to name a few.

Women want more flexibility in the work force. Senator Powell said a little while ago that women want more wages. That is not necessarily what many women want; they want more flexibility to be able to work the hours that fit in with their family structure. She just does not understand what we are all about. That is not amazing. It is not insignificant either when a survey of a lower income Perth suburban street showed in the wake of the August Budget that one family with two small children had only $30 in the kitty for the food bill for the weeks ahead.

I found it most disturbing this afternoon to listen to Senator Giles when she said that there had been no decline in living standards during the period of this Government. I thought Senator Giles was one who ran around Australia saying that she supported the cause of families and women. Clearly, she does not understand what they are going through and how much of a decline there has been in living standards. It is also not insignificant either when the Support, Information, Education and Referral Association of Western Australia says:
There are more kids in poverty now than there ever has been and this prostitution is a result of it.

That is another sad element of where this country is heading. There are more and more young people heading towards prostitution and actually indulging in it just to stay alive. Yet in three weeks' time, supposedly, we are not meant to have any child poverty in this country. I do not know about the children-I do really. Let us face it; there will still be hundreds of thousands of children in poverty, to say nothing of their parents who also will be in poverty.

It was even more alarming this afternoon to listen to Senator Button's answer to a question in Question Time. The Leader of the Government in the Senate quite clearly demonstrated that he did not understand what was going on out there in the real world about the cost of living. I would like to know how recently it is that Senator Button has been into as grocery store, a supermarket, or a clothing store to buy clothes for children-just to find out how much it costs. People do not understand that until they have done that exercise. It is not insignificant when charities are telling us that there are more people needing help this Christmas than ever before. The reality is that there are fewer people contributing to their cause.

The IAC has predicted a gain of 35,000 jobs if its program of micro-economic reform were implemented. That, of course, would make an enormous difference to the lives of many individuals and families. But the Government is walking away from it. There will be many people in the suburbs, country areas and the like who would be wanting to get more employment. More employment would be available if micro-economic reform were implemented. It is worth remembering that some estimates put the household cost of protection to the car industry under this Labor Government between $170 and $250 annually. That is another amount that the Government is putting onto the backs of Australians. When we add all the bits and pieces Australians must remember that the debts they have are not only their own but debts the Government is running up on their behalf. If the levels of industry assistance were to be removed and industries were to become more competitive, it would be possible to have an additional and desperately needed increase in gross domestic product of approximately $4 billion annually. The coalition will not shirk its responsibility in the way in which the Hawke-Keating Government has done. We are all about providing less encumbrances on individuals whereby they can personally benefit from their hard work.

Senator Alston earlier in the debate described how the Telecom Australia monopoly inefficiency makes our national communications system unnecessarily expensive. I reiterate that what we are talking about is a cost of $30 per week per business employee when, in 1985, Telecom manning levels had 69 main lines per employee compared with an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) average of 135. If that does not point to inefficiency, what does? Again, it is the view of the IAC that improved efficiency in the postal, telecommunications and electricity sectors will deliver savings of $6 per week to each Australian household-another saving to the household.

When we consider the fact that the STD charges are twice what they should otherwise be, we should consider that in practical terms a 10-minute call only 50 kilometres away from a major city currently costs $2.40 and should only cost about $1.20, to say nothing of those private individuals who wish or need to keep in touch with relatives interstate, and to say nothing of the companies that need to have telephone communication interstate at a time of day when the highest charges apply. A 10-minute call for them at worst is $6.50 and, at best, at limited times, is $3.20. Once again we should be looking at about half that cost, which would be a further saving to families. The policies of this Hawke Labor Government are the only reason that those charges are not much less today. This Government has allowed costs and monopolies to run riot without any consideration of how it impacts on ordinary Australians and business. There are very few ordinary Australians who appear to have a privileged position with the Government's stance other than the waterside workers. Would it not be a very comfortable situation if all people who were retrenched had $300m to spend on redundancy payments for 3,000 people? That is what the waterside workers are being offered.

Then we hear Bill Kelty of the Australian Council of Trade Unions promising his members a 30 per cent productivity gain with no timetable or prerequisites. Would not every other Australian worker like a piece of that cake! But it is not going across the board. Let us not forget that micro-economic reform is all the more urgent when we consider that for many Australians, disposable income has been eroded under this Government. The effect of the increase in the consumer price index in combination with Labor's taxation bracket creep and the level of family support measures has meant that the real disposable income of a single income family with two dependent children has, in 1982-83 prices, fallen a massive 8 per cent. Yet Senator Giles said that there had been an increase. When we bear in mind that, with this reduced disposable real income, families have been struggling with spiralling interest rates, we realise that the need for courage to implement the structural reforms that will ultimately raise household income becomes overwhelming.

In four of the six years between 1983 and 1989 real wages have fallen, yet Australian have averaged a miserable 0.3 per cent rise in productivity compared with the 1.9 per cent OECD average. The coalition commitment to privatisation is another vital tool that will provide essential services more efficiently. This efficiency can only translate to better services, lower prices, and improved real incomes. That is particularly important for families. A couple may need to fly interstate for urgent reasons. The flight between Perth and Sydney would cost them about $2,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some very interesting conclusions are to be drawn from this debate. The terms of the matter of public importance before the Senate state:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's abject failure to deliver on its promise that micro-economic reform would be the centrepiece of its third term of Government with the inevitable consequences of declining living standards and increased social stresses for all Australians.

I saw that he was to be followed by the previous speaker, Senator Knowles, and I thought, `This is weird. We are going to have a very deep and serious debate'. Senator Knowles is one of the great contributions the west has made to this Parliament. I saw that next on the Opposition speakers' list was Senator Archer. I thought, `We are going to have a very serious debate about micro-economic reform. They will have their finger on the appropriate issues'. I thought that the reason this is being brought forward on 13 December 1989 is that on 15 December 1989 a report will be sent to the Industrial Relations Commission about reforms on the waterfront. I concluded that this must have arisen from the concern often expressed by the Opposition about what is happening on the waterfront.

I thought that the Opposition speakers-these brilliant people-would analyse the central issue of micro-economic reform. There has been a thunderous silence on perhaps the most important document with respect to micro-economic reform. Whey would these two outstanding figures from the Opposition-Senator Knowles and Senator Alston, who represent perhaps the cream of the Opposition-not even refer to the very central issue of the micro-economic reform debate, the in-principle agreement of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority?

TALK.START.PARA: —Aha!

—Perhaps Senator McKiernan can tell me why those honourable senators with their intellect and knowledge of the issue would get up and berate the Government without even mentioning one of the central planks, if not the central plank, of the reform processes put forward by the Government. The conclusion might be that they have nothing to say about it. Perhaps they admit by their silence that contrary to the implication in the subject put forward as a matter of public importance, they understand very well that the progress made by the Government in micro-economic reform cannot be answered. I draw that conclusion because they have not sought to deal with the most fundamental plank.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the in-principle agreement about? I will mention a couple of the subjects involved. Chapter 10.1 of the agreement, `Enterprise Employment', states:

In the ports of Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Fremantle and Adelaide and other ports as agreed, enterprise employment arrangements will be introduced within a framework of enterprise agreements and an Industry Award(s).

One of the great cries we hear from the Opposition day after day is that we ought to move to enterprise employment. Opposition senators have echoed that theme all this year and certainly since September 1989. The document setting out the agreement, the centrepiece of reform, shows that the Government, the unions and the employers are moving towards enterprise employment, but honourable senators have not mentioned the document. What sort of proposition is the Opposition putting forward when it raises issues without mentioning such reform? I cannot repeat enough that the very heart of the argument ought to be this subject. Senator Alston said, `Oh, well, the waterfront!'. He said that Tas Bull, the General Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, had a harebrained scheme and only wanted to give people more money. He said that the workers would put the money in their pockets and ask for more. That is Senator Alston's proposition, but it is not the reality. That is not what is proposed by Tas Bull, the Government or the employers. As evidence of that, on Friday next, if the Industrial Relations Commission sanctions it and if matters are taken to that point, they are going to the Commission to agree to an award based on the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority in-principle agreement. That agreement contains all the things that the Opposition wants: an increase in productivity, enterprise employment, and agreement between the parties, yet the Opposition either apparently does not know of the document, which I cannot accept, or just ignores it.

The Opposition has said that the labour movement, the unions, and the Government have done nothing. Let us leave the waterfront aside for a moment and look at the Williamstown dockyard where the Victorian Government, the Trades Hall Council and Mr John Halfpenny, who is often berated in this place, did great work in setting up the most efficient shipping yard in Australia. Amecon Ltd--

TALK.START.PARA: —He was against it in the beginning.

—No, he was not. It was through Mr Halfpenny that the number of unions in Williamstown was reduced to three and it has now become one of the great shipyards of the world. It will go from strength to strength, particularly as shipping is in short supply and there is more demand for it. So we go from the wharf to the Williamstown dockyard.
—What about a bit of foreign competition?

—The honourable senator says that there is no competition. The Williamstown dockyard recently handsomely beat the Newcastle yard for a very big contract, but no mention was made of that by Senator Alston or Senator Knowles.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the shipping industry around Australia and a record I obtained from the office of the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis. That record of shipping reform includes the establishment by the Government in June 1989 of a three-year reform strategy based on consensus and building on the progress of the Crawford scheme. the program of reform of employment arrangements at bulk grain terminals has resulted in the implementation of substantial reductions in shipboard manning levels at Fisherman Islands (Brisbane) and Port Kembla.
representing a 72% reduction in stevedoring industry manning at Fisherman Islands

Reform of shipping, the wharves and the turnabout of bulk cargo have all been achieved through--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying it is all good on the waterfront?
—Senator Parer interjects-and this is the whole problem-and puts up a proposition on behalf of the Opposition.
