The Opposition says that there has been an abject failure on the part of the Government to deliver on its promise of micro-economic reform. We are saying that under this Government much greater progress has been made than would have been made had the Opposition been in government. We are saying to the people of Australia, `We have delivered. We intend to deliver more. Had you picked the other side, you would not have got that'. Having pointed out all these great achievements we have made, Senator Parer comes in and says, `Look, I concede you have done all that, but we say that you should do more'. We have inherited a culture, an industry and an ethos from long periods of conservative rule which have unfortunately left a warp in Australian industry which has to be turned around. It is a massive job, but it is being done.
—When are you going to start?

—Senator Alston asks when we are going to start. I have just been through several of the great reforms that the Government has undertaken and carried out. Senator Alston should listen to what I say. If he listened to what I say, he would be much better informed and would be blessed with information that he could take on board. Having given him the opportunity to take all these things on board, he does not take it. Senator Alston has to listen to the evidence. It is no good Senator Alston dreaming about what he would like to see happen; he has to look at reality. If he does not want to accept what I say, he should go down on Friday-we will not be sitting on Friday-to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. If he sits in there, tries to say nothing-he might be tempted to get up and advocate-and listens to what is said, he will see that what I have said is absolutely true. People will be there from the shipping industry, employer bodies, the unions and the Government. Senator Alston should ask them, and they will confirm what I say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to support this matter of public importance that has been proposed by the shadow Minister for communications, Senator Alston. In case Senator Cooney is thinking of disappearing from the chamber, as seems to be the pattern with honourable senators opposite, I suggest that he stays because I can give him some of the information that he has been looking for so earnestly. I start by asking: Just what has happened to the micro-economic issues that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) nominated as being the basis of his third term in office? As yet, there is nothing of any consequence to show. We have had seven years of hard labour where the macro-economic measures of the Government have left us with impossible interest rates, very high inflation, a huge and uncontrolled debt, a fiddled dollar and crippling taxation. That is what the macros have done. There has been no change in that system over this seven-year period. Times have changed, but the policies have not. There has been no relief and no progress. All we have seen is a blind ideological, stupid commitment to these matters when it has been patently clear to every Australian that it is absolutely essential to change from these disastrous policies. But we have not had that change. With the macros so far off the track, the micros have been left alone. The Government has been totally beaten by the macros-it just has not got anywhere with them at all. The issues of the real world and of ordinary people just have not been dealt with. The Government cannot do it; it does not know which way to go.

SPEECH.PARA: One only has to look at communications, industrial relations, the airlines, housing, inflation control, the balance of payments and the wage levels. What has the Government done in any of those areas? What is the Government's reputation, and what is the result? It is essential at a time like this that we do not look only at the self-gratification that one of the previous speakers referred to when he said, `Oh yes, we have done this and we have done that'. What is important is where we stand internationally. I can give honourable senators a few facts in relation to that matter. In 1960 we ranked fourth in the world in terms of gross domestic product (GDP) on a per capita basis. By 1987 we ranked sixteenth. Are we proud of that? Between 1981 and 1988 foreign debt increased five-fold from 5 per cent to 30 per cent. By 1999, at that rate, the foreign debt will be 60 per cent of GDP. In 1987 the gross foreign debt was 38 per cent of GDP, the eleventh highest of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries. The interest on the foreign debt represents 16 per cent of the value of exports of all goods and services, which is the fourth highest amongst all OECD countries. In 1989 the export of goods was 13.5 per cent of GDP-unchanged since 1958 and down from 25 per cent in 1900. From 1980 to 1989 the export of goods and services fell from 18.1 to 16.1 per cent. In 1988 and 1989 the relative unit wage costs grew by 7.3 per cent against an OECD average of 3.5 per cent. That is how we compare internationally, and that is the test of whether the objects of this Government have been carried out or not.

I must give credit to the Government-I was going to do this in any event-for starting to talk about railways. After seven years the Government has discovered railways. On 6 December a statement was released by the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) which said:
Mr Brown said the Hawke Government was making rail reform a priority.
In other words, after seven years the Government has found a priority and has called it rail. He continued:
. . . micro-economic reform in the rail sector was important for industry in particular and the economy in general.

I am very pleased with that statement. Although the Government is teetering on the brink, we find that it is going to put its faith in railways. I also have to say that the Government has also discovered shipping. The Government has now found it necessary to have the twenty-fourth inquiry into shipping and the waterfront since Federation. I will say something about that later.

But has the Government any plan for micro-economic change? I do not care what the plan is. I would like to know whether there is a plan and, if so, which way it is heading. Where are we heading under Labor? There is no direction and no action. If honourable senators opposite would like to refresh their minds and read the Liberal Party document called Future Directions, they will find that the policy of the Opposition is the way to go. But we have not seen anything like that from the Australian Labor Party. I do not know whether it has got any plan; nobody does.

Let us have a quick look at industry. Where are we with industry? Are we going to reindustrialise? Are we a post-industrial society? Are we on the Argentinean road? Where are we heading? Who would want to establish a business of any consequence in Australia now? Would anybody like to start a pulp mill somewhere? How does anybody know what Labor has in mind? In short, does it want industry or does it not? In which direction should education go? Do we teach science or sociology? Do we concentrate on teaching dishwashing and bead threading? I do not know in which direction the Government is going, and neither does anybody else outside this place. Is there to be industry or is there not? Paul Cleary, writing in the Australian on the Australian Manufacturing Council report, very succinctly said:
There is no plan, no strategy to fill the industrial wasteland portrayed in the report.

That is absolutely correct. Why do we not have an on-processing plan or an import substitution plan? If problems exist in these areas, we should fix them and not just say, `Oh, it is too hard. There is a problem. We will leave it or go round it'. Problems exist to be overcome, and I expect the government of the day to try to overcome them. Look at the very fast train-and I use this analogy regularly. Everybody is just standing around, wringing their hands and saying that it is all terribly difficult. But one has only got to look at the road situation and the poor rail performance. Look at what we are talking about spending on an air service that may be unnecessary if we can get a decent train. Look at the deaths and injuries that are being caused by the state of our roads. Look at the costs and the time that is wasted. I urge the Government to get behind the very fast train project. I urge the Government to get behind anything. Let us see where we are going. We need national planning and national action. We need some leadership but we are not getting it.

Senator Powell raised the question of the accord. What a thing for anybody who is trying to support the Government to raise. What has the accord done for ordinary Australians? Wage earners generally are worse off than they were before. There are increased distinctions between the highly skilled and the less highly skilled. The accord has not overcome outside of award deals. It has forced the Government to grovel at the knees of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. There is no evidence that award restructuring has produced any significant overall increased productivity but it has seen wage rises above expectations. An article in the Australian of 11 December, just recently, was headed `Wage rises too fast for some'. I thought this is what we had the accord for. Let us look at the result of the accord. It has not been going long enough for us to at least look backwards. Has it made us more competitive? Are we exporting more? Is it putting Australia higher on the international scale of comparison? Has it resulted in fewer imports? The answer to every one of those questions is no.

I turn to shipping. Yes, the Government has found shipping. We have had the twenty-fourth inquiry into shipping and what did it tell us that we did not know before? What was the result of this inquiry? We are still at the stage where, according to the Australian editorial of 10 November:
Australia's coastal shipping is so expensive and unreliable that no general cargo is now carried by sea between Australian ports.

What an absolute disgrace. Australia, given its size and population and its general specifications, should have the best transport system in the world. Why do we not have the best transport system in the world? There are a variety of reasons, certainly, but there has been a lack of endeavour and this Government has done nothing about it-except to have another inquiry. The fact that there is is no competition is another real problem. We must remember that conditions on the waterfront are heavily padded. What has the accord done about these people who work 28 hours a week and who have an average income of 40 per cent above the national average? Is that based on their productivity? I do not think so. What does the Treasurer (Mr Keating) say? He washes his hands of it:
Opposition claims that reforms to ports and the waterfront would make all the difference to Australia's economic performance were `just bunkum', Mr Keating said.

What do other people around the world think about the situation? They might have a slightly different approach. A Mr Setchell, who was giving evidence to the Prices Surveillance Authority's public inquiry into the port congestion surcharge for cargo handling at Sydney, compared Australia's performance on the waterfront with that of Pakistan. I do not want to run down the Pakistanis but Pakistan is the country we are compared with on the international shipping agenda. In evidence to the Authority's inquiry, as reported by the Daily Commercial News, it was stated:
Average delay per vessel was 32 hours at Glebe Island and 41 hours at Port Botany . . .

What an absolute disgrace. I again ask Senator Cooney what has been done. I am not interested in what the talk is and I am not interested in what the plans for the next 10 years are; I want to know what has been done. An article in the same newspaper, the Daily Commercial News, of 8 December states:
The Conferences making this submission have sustained losses of approximately $16 million between January 1, 1988, to August 31, 1989 . . .

This is solely due to not being able to get in and out of the ports. There are absolutely and totally unacceptable delays, so much so that it is proposed to put a levy of $200 to $300 per box on all freight. I agree with the sub-heading of the article which says `Surcharge would only protect inefficiencies'. Putting a levy on these boxes would not solve the problem. We must not allow it to happen. We must think of the costs involved, the delays and our reputation, our unreliability. We must think about who pays. Nobody worries about who pays in Australia, but it is always the same person-the one on the end of the line. Overseas countries will deal with anyone other than Australia if they can possibly find a way in and out. What a reputation.

I do not know whether honourable senators saw Senator Button's program on Australian Broadcasting Corporation television called Overseas and Undersold. I found it very edifying. I do not know what Government members thought of it but I hope that they all saw it. It has not sparked any action. It has not even sparked a comment from the Minister. There is talk of ships bypassing Sydney. It costs them $500 a box to move their freight backwards and forwards. Cranes have been out of commission in Sydney for nine months. We can compare the situation with that in Hamburg, where, if the port does not turn trucks around in 10 minutes, the port pays a penalty. If the port workers do not load 40 boxes an hour there is a penalty. They get in and out in 12 hours and 700 boxes are loaded a day. There is one national union. The last strike lasted for one day and it was 10 years ago. We are talking about double the price and half the productivity. A ship in Hong Kong can do in 14 hours what it would take Australia five times as long to do. A visit can cost $50,000 less in Hong Kong than in Australia. Let us expose public enterprises to a bit of competition. How can we survive without an entirely new start?

I am a Tasmanian. It costs $72 a tonne to get milk powder from Tasmania to Taiwan and $82 a tonne to get it to Melbourne. Aluminium can be shipped from Bell Bay to most Asian ports more cheaply than it can be shipped to Sydney. Newsprint is cheaper to ship from Canada to Sydney than from Hobart to Sydney. Cars are a third cheaper to ship from Melbourne to Japan than from Melbourne to Tasmania. Cement costs $12 to ship from Japan to Darwin but $20 to ship from Adelaide to Darwin. And so it goes on. What are we going to do about this? I do not want to know what has happened or what the plans are. Where is the action? Where are the results? Australia's micro-economic position is absolutely disastrous. It must be improved. I do not think that this Government is in a position to be able to do anything about it. It has had the time and the opportunity to do something but the results are not there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government inherited a tremendously large deficit in 1983-some $8.5 billion, if I recall correctly. It was certainly not the figure that the Government of the time, prior to the Labor Government's taking office, was indicating. Our most recent Budget shows a $9 billion surplus. To me it is a fairly good effort by a government to have turned that deficit into a surplus over a period of some six to seven years. We had unemployment running at about 10 per cent and that has been reduced to 7 per cent. Of course, no mention is made on the other side of the chamber about the degree of private debt-the Elliotts, the Holmes a'Courts and such people. For instance, Bond borrowed almost $1 billion overseas to buy a thriving brewery in Brisbane, Fourex. All that resulted from that was the dismissal of some of the top executives and more profits for the Bond Corporation. So much for the question of debt. It is forecast by our Treasurer (Mr Keating) that by 1992 we will probably have no public debt.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous Government gave us bad industrial relations; there was no change for the better in sight; there was a confrontationist attitude; the unions did not trust the previous Government; and the unions could not trust it. The previous Government was opposed to all wage claims. History shows that; it is on the record. It suppressed workers' rights through penalties under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. It made union amalgamations difficult or impossible. Amalgamations are vital if we are to succeed in restructuring industry and jobs and at the same time develop career paths and better educate the work force in terms of the creation of wealth. Honourable senators opposite contributed to a framework in which no cultural change was possible. Without a cultural change in the industrial area we will not achieve the sorts of goals that we have set for ourselves.

Let us compare that with the record of the Australian Labor Party in government. It prepared its entry to government by reaching an agreement with the trade unions to bring about micro-economic reform and change, in the interests of all Australians. The accord enabled the containment of wage increases and the decrease of labour costs. Figures show that amount to be about 9 per cent. At the same time profits were increased. The accord contains a proposition that there should be a transfer of wages to profits. We did not do that because we felt that we suddenly liked the employers and entrepreneurs any better but because we knew it was an economically sound proposition and, in the medium and long term, we were seeking to create the opportunity for more jobs and a better and stronger economy. There has been a substantial increase in investment in machinery, technology and training but certainly not to the extent of the increases in profits.

People on the Opposition benches talk all the time about a reduction in living standards. I would not argue with that. There has been a small reduction because of the changes that have taken place. We know that and understand that. But, although it might continue in the near future, there is no reduction in the living standards of the Bonds and Elliotts. We are told by people using the correct facts that, if the capital gains tax is removed, Mr Elliott will be given another $18m. He is not suffering any particular reduction in his living standards. But the trade union movement and the Labor Party have gone out and talked to people about what their future should hold. We obviously need to be cooperative and not confrontationist. We need to create greater wealth, increase productivity and create and manufacture more value-added goods so that we will add to our gross national product.

The Government is justifiably proud of its achievements in micro-economic reform. It has provided leadership and a comprehensive strategy to make Australia more outward-looking and competitive. We have listened to the needs and problems of people in all sections of industry, including those within the award system, and have worked together to plan and implement necessary changes that will benefit all Australians. That is where we depart from the attitude and philosophy of the Opposition. To those in the Opposition people are just statistics. They are an extension of the machine they operate. Those opposite are motivated by profit. To them a good balance of payments means a situation where the dollar is reasonably strong. If one is able to sell one's products, to the opposition that is great, one has prosperity. It does not matter if half the population is out of work. They might be out of work as a result of the restructuring of industry, changed technological levels, changes in the way in which industry operates or as a result of the economy generally, but, even if they are out of work for no fault of their own, they will be called dole bludgers and told that they do not want to work.

Progress was virtually non-existent under three decades of conservative rule. We know that the Opposition was then, and is still, unable to bring all the major interest groups together to discuss, plan and implement changes for the benefit of this nation. The Opposition has always ruled with a heavy hand. This has led to mistrust in the workplace, with sectional interest groups competing for dominance. We in the trade union movement know that that has not always been beneficial, though on most occasions it has been impossible for us to work in any other way. But we are on another path now and realise the importance of working together with employers to create even greater wealth so that mutual benefits can flow to the community. We need to work cooperatively for Australia's benefit.

The Government has continued to place micro-economic reform at the top of the political agenda. It has continued to look at dozens of areas within the Australian economy and has systematically produced strategies to improve the rationalisation and effectiveness of industry, the industrial relations system, the award system, and productivity and employment levels. The Government is continuing its commitment to overhaul the industry infrastructure and services sector of the economy. I would like to refer to a small sample of these micro-economic reforms to illustrate the care and attention the Government has given. I will list them: coastal shipping, steel industry, waterfront, grain handling reform, award restructuring, and industrial relations. Earlier this year the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) made a speech in which he said about shipping:

Our work on shipping builds on earlier reforms introduced by this Government. In 1984, in response to the Crawford report, we introduced taxation incentives which led to new ships coming into service in 1984 with crews as low as 26, well below crew levels for such ships of an earlier generation which were in the low to mid 30s.
That is a one-third reduction in crewing. The Minister continued:

The Crawford scheme represented a critical turning point for the industry. It introduced a pattern for reform with shipowners and unions working together in a constructive way, for users and the economy as a whole.

That is a long way from the days when shipowners were pirates. I have some doubts about some of them having reformed their ways through the years, but the Minister's statement indicates a very good development. The Minister continued:
These reforms have been achieved in a period of unprecedented industrial harmony in the shipping industry. In 1982-
when the Opposition was in power-

4.1% of ship time or 1593 ship days were lost through industrial disputes. Last year only 0.2% or 72 ship days were lost. This dramatic change has been brought about partly by the reduction in demarcation disputes through union amalgamations and partly by the industry's determination to improve its efficiency and public image.

Of course, part of it is restructuring so that people gain multiskilling both vertically and horizontally. The Labor Government has embarked on a practical and deliberate program for change to reduce industry costs and to encourage the industry to make major investments in larger and more specialised vessels. As I have said, the program includes a reduction of staffing levels by more than one-third and the introduction of multiskilling. By 1992 the average crew size will be down to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average. Ten years ago the Opposition would have rolled around the floor laughing at that-and it would have been entitled to do so. But these changes have taken place.

What more does the Opposition want? Does it want ghost ships that go through the night with no crew at all? We might even eliminate all the consumers who will buy the goods they carry. Of course, the economy would be in a sorry state then. The industry is now in a position to inject the necessary funds into new and more appropriate vessels. The industry's costs have been reduced by our incentives to replace old and inefficient ships with new vessels. As a result, 25 new vessels have been ordered or introduced. This was confirmed to me some 18 months ago by a shipowner who, in reply to my question, said that industrial relations were the best they had been for some time and that people were able to talk together constructively.

Let us look at the steel industry, which was going out the door backwards, according to Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP), with a return of 2 per cent. It was looking to the day when it might even close down. There was a significant improvement in both the then current situation and our expectations for the future as a result of the completion of the steel plan, which encouraged rationalisation and modernisation, produced a favourable environment for the industry and required only limited financial assistance. Industrial agreements were established and productivity improvements, job security, training programs and job award restructuring occurred. Production in the steel industry has improved from below 200 tonnes per employee per annum to nearly 400 tonnes. This figure will rise to 500 tonnes in 1990.

So much for the Opposition's accusation about no increased productivity and the allegation that we have not embarked on micro-economic reforms. The situation in the steel industry is very clear. The figures are there, they are proved, and they come from BHP, a company that, in the past, has never been noted for good industrial relations or for seeking to be loved by its employees. As Senator Button said this week, only two areas exceed those sorts of production levels- Japan and some areas of the United States of America. We have the cheapest steel of its kind in the world, with exports up and increasing wealth for Australians. I have a document which states:

BHP Steel is undergoing a major capital expenditure program to expand capacity out to improve efficiency and quality . . . BHP Steel is aiming to export up to 25 per cent of its total steel production of 8.05m tonnes p.a. by 1992. This is double the average the company has been exporting in recent years, and increases the share of value-added steel product exports.

That has to be a plus for the whole community. I have given examples of the way in which micro-economic reform has been developed by the Government and of the framework we have provided. The companies themselves have brought about the changes, and certainly not with the Government having to stand over them. The Government has said to the companies, particularly BHP, `We have provided subsidies up to $550m over a period to help you maintain a market; you have got to do your bit'. BHP promised to do so, and has invested almost twice the amount it gave an undertaking about earlier.

On the waterfront there has been extensive consultation, and it has become clear that all major stevedoring operators should be responsible for their own work force rather than using the old pool system. The Government has developed plans to change both employment levels and procedures by 1992. It will introduce multi- skilling in the workplace and reorganise staff. Opposition senators talk as if there is real resistance by the waterside workers; as if they do not want to see any change; as if they are bloody-minded; and as if they really do not care about the community. That is not the truth. In June this year Tas Bull put out a statement to his members. He said, in part:
Australia's ports are at a turning point. To ensure their future viability in a competitive environment we need:
A younger, skilled and motivated workforce
Better management
Coordinated and comprehensive planning.

The waterfront makes a significant contribution to the Australian economy, representing about 0.8 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. More importantly it is the transport interface through which the nation's imports and exports must pass. In 1986-87 waterside workers handled a total of 7.6 million tonnes of non-bulk imported cargo and 10.3 million tonnes of exports.

There is somebody who is not worried just about when his next wage increase will come about; he understands the industry, he has worked in it and he is concerned about his members who work in it. He knows that changes have to take place if we are to have a viable future. He has a different view from that of the Opposition-again, he cares about people. He knows that changes have to take place but he wants them to take place in a reasonable, steady manner so that people who will forfeit their right to work, and will probably never get another job even if they want to-there are plenty of job advertisements saying, `If you are over 40, please do not apply'-will get some compensation. And he wants to ensure that there is cooperation.

In conclusion, the Australian economy has been placed firmly within the world economy by this Government. We have agreed that for Australia to become competitive in world terms we must also trade with the world on an equal footing. At the same time, the world economy is changing. This creates pressure on the Australian economy and our capacity to deal with this pressure is limited.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Press Release and Background Statement by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Reid)-by leave-agreed to:

That during debate a motion to take note of the pulp and paper industry package, tabled earlier this day the first speaker may speak for not more than 20 minutes and subsequent speakers for not more than 15 minutes each.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper and the attached statements.

In this matter one is tempted to commence by saying `better late than never'. This report entitled Pulp and Paper Industry Package is long overdue. It was promised to the Senate on or before 30 November but, as per usual, the Government has not been able to get its act together to consider matters even according to its own timetable. The need for this particular document derives essentially from the fiasco of the Wesley Vale development proposal where the Federal Government's latter-day intervention was a cause of so much trouble and confusion and was simply typical of the way in which this Labor Government goes about changing the rules of the game once play has started. As far as this Government is concerned, the new test, the now test, is `Will it adhere to those guidelines?'. Having promulgated these guidelines, will it now give an undertaking to stick to them and to allow industry to make decisions and allow the environmental movement to know what the ground rules are, or will it, in typical fashion, be prepared to change them again if political circumstances seem to its advantage?

I said that these papers derived essentially from the confusion over the Wesley Vale project and over appropriate guidelines. I go back for a moment to a comment made in March this year about the proposal for Wesley Vale. On 2 March the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) was asked to report on the Wesley Vale project. It reported to the Government on 13 March. The report stated:
In providing advice to the Government in relation to the proposed Wesley Vale Pulp Mill, CSIRO has focused its attention on two major issues.
Are the emissions from the proposed mill the minimum that can be expected using the most modern proven technology, and
What is the likely impact of these emissions to the environment?

Our response to the first issue is clear. CSIRO considers that, for the purpose of producing pulp for high quality printing papers, the Wesley Vale mill is proposing to use the most modern proven technologies incorporating advanced procedures to minimise liquid and gaseous effluents. In our view there are no alternatives to the proposed pulping/bleaching process that are commercially proven and that will produce a bleached eucalypt pulp with the desired properties for the export market.

In March this year this Government was told the truth. When we read the guidelines now, almost exactly nine months later, we find that the CSIRO's advice to Government, now accepted and incorporated in these pulp mills proposals, says precisely the same thing. It says precisely now what the Government knew the situation was in March this year. Nevertheless, for purely political reasons, it prevaricated and carried on about this issue to the detriment of Tasmania. Indeed, by the middle of March the Government was in a state of absolute embarrassment over this matter. On 16 March on the 7.30 Report Mr Keating admitted that the Commonwealth had failed to develop appropriate standards and should have done so at an earlier stage. Senator Button, as reported in the Canberra Times on 20 March, said exactly the same thing. On the Business Sunday program on 19 March, when asked by the reporter whether Commonwealth standards in this area were lacking, Senator Button admitted that they were lacking. Senator Cook put out a press release on 22 March, which stated:
The Minister for Resources, Senator Peter Cook, said today that the Federal Government had to move quickly to define the environmental guidelines for future pulp mill investment in Australia.

That was Senator Cook's own press release. It has taken him nine months to move quickly. He could have had a baby in less time for all of the urgency with which he has addressed this matter. When Mr Crean was asked about this matter on 15 March he said:
I think the fundamental problem is that the government has not got an overall environment strategy and it's environment strategy is to respond to complaints and issues around particular issues.
Finally, Mr Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, on the Face to Face program of 26 March, admitted once again that the Government had simply not got its act together.

The Opposition consistently called for the development and promulgation of these guidelines. We raised the matter in the chamber in May. Indeed, on 2 May Senator Button put down a statement here, by way of an answer to a question, which was so confusing that the then shadow Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Chaney and I put out a statement on 5 May once again calling on the Government to issue these guidelines as a matter of urgency. We repeated that in a further statement which I put out on 10 July.

The Government's eventual response was to commission an expert inquiry drawing on the resources of the officers of the CSIRO. I am glad that my colleague Senator Archer is in the chamber this afternoon. He will know, because of the particular interest he has taken in CSIRO, that the Government always returns to the CSIRO to get the Government out of the holes that it continues to get itself into over scientific questions at precisely the same time as it slashes and burns into CSIRO's budget, as it has done ever since its first day in office. In June 1989 the CSIRO produced a report entitled Pulp Mills: Modern Technology and Environmental Protection. I want to quote from one part of that report because I wish to come back to it. The CSIRO report stated:
The complete elimination of toxic substances from the effluent of a bleached kraft mill is presently not possible.

The Government was told that by CSIRO in June, but for purely political reasons it attempted to persuade the environmental movement and people around Australia that that was not so, that in fact it could produce a toxin-free emitting pulp mill somewhere in Australia. As I say, the Opposition now welcomes, at last, the production of these guidelines, presented yesterday by way of press release rather than being presented properly in this chamber. The guidelines would not have been debated in this chamber today had we not insisted. Again, this is typical of the way in which the Government behaves.

I shall now make a few comments about the precise guidelines. At the end of the day we will see that these guidelines, now adopted by the Government, have two remarkable features. The first is that they entirely endorse the guidelines originally laid down by the Tasmanian Government under the previous Liberal Administration. Secondly, in at least three areas, to which I shall draw attention, the guidelines proposed by these Federal regulations are, in fact, less than the environmental guidelines proposed by the Tasmanian Government at an earlier stage.

A criticism which can legitimately be made is that these guidelines and regulations do not adequately consider the alternatives to having bleached eucalypt kraft (BEK) pulp mills in Australia. It is possible over time to move away from the reliance on bleached eucalypt kraft mills and to move to the adoption of other technology relying primarily upon the use of plantation eucalypt as the source material to go into those pulp mills. Today, as to the technology being available to deal with mature eucalypt-to deal with that 4 3/4 million tonnes of eucalypt which we export by way of woodchips, worth something in the order of $370m a year-there is no way of going to the value added stage without the use of the technology of bleached eucalypt kraft pulp mills. There is no other way at all to add value to that 4 3/4 million tonnes currently being exported as woodchip. So to that extent we have to have these guidelines specifically for BEK pulp mills. But it is unfortunate that we do not have from the Government a strategy to move eventually to the use of other, more environmentally friendly technologies based upon plantation operations. I draw attention to the fact that the coalition's policy in relation to the development of the timber industry, again an area in which Senator Archer has been making a major contribution to the ongoing debate, puts a particular emphasis upon the development of plantation sources of material, and that in its turn will allow us to have a more environmentally friendly pulp mill technology.

The second point is that this document waxes lyrical about the question of consultations. In fact, if one looks at page 10 of the document under the heading `Need for wide consultations' and if one examines the process of consultation, one finds that at no stage were the Opposition or any of the Government's political opponents asked to be a part of the political consultative-or technically consultative-process. Indeed, one might understand that. But lest the Government thinks it will get mighty credit all- around, it is interesting to see that on 26 October Phillip Toyne, the Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and said:
The Commonwealth has failed to seriously consult with or address the concerns of anyone other than the paper and pulp industry.

I say both to Mr Toyne and, indeed, to Senator Richardson on this occasion that he who sups with the devil certainly needs a long spoon as far as these consultations are concerned. If they thought that they were going to lock in all and sundry by the phoney process of consultation that they went through, they have another political thought coming.

I turn now to the specifics, and in particular to the amount of egg that must be left today on the face of Senator Graham Richardson. Senator Richardson went down to Tasmania and appeared with Jana Wendt at some publicly stage-managed presentation. What did he say about the preferred Commonwealth option for organochlorine discharges? He said they would be, to use his words, `none, zilch, none'. This document is a stunning repudiation of the deliberate attempt to mislead people into thinking that that could be achieved. It was going to be a zilch option, a zilch outcome. That was what Senator Richardson promised everybody. This document is a stunning repudiation of that, known at the time not to be possible or feasible and now exposed by the scientific evidence to be precisely that.

The guidelines Senator Richardson criticised, which were produced by the Tasmanian Government and which he was seen to be criticising in his reported remarks in the Launceston Examiner on 25 February 1989, have been vindicated in every significant respect by this CSIRO report. I draw attention to three specific areas in which the guidelines proposed by the Tasmanian Government of the day were in fact stricter than the guidelines which have now emerged. The first of those relates to the discharge of organochlorins. If one looks at page 15 of these guidelines one will see that there is a permissible emission level for organochlorins of up to one tonne per year, or one kilogram per air-dried tonne, as an average figure. The Tasmanian guidelines set out in the schedule to the Northern Pulp Mills (Doubts Removal) Agreement Bill 1989 said that the emission level was never to be above one tonne. An average of one tonne has now been adopted by the Government, with an allowance of up to 2.5 tonnes in any one sampling-that is, 2 1/2 times the maximum discharge limit which the Tasmanian legislation put in place has now been found to be acceptable by the Government-and instead of the absolute limit proposed by the Tasmanian Liberal Government it is now an average over the course of the year.

Secondly, we have the question of tertiary treatment. On page 17 of this document we see that the only guidelines relate to primary and secondary treatment. There is no requirement for any tertiary treatment of the effluent from these mills. Yet the Tasmanian guidelines were designed to achieve 0.7 kilograms of organochlorins per air-dried tonne of pulp in terms of movement towards tertiary treatment, with up to 40 per cent chlorine dioxide substitution for chlorine in the bleaching process. Again, this was a far stricter attempt to get to tertiary treatment guidelines. This document makes no attempt whatsoever to get to them.

Thirdly, let us look at the question of what happens in terms of breaches of these standards. On page 13 of the document we see that in the case of the breach of an emission limit, the operator is supposed to notify the regulatory authority of the breach, provide a statement within 24 hours prescribing the reasons for the breach and the proposed methods of dealing with it, and reach an agreement with the regulatory authority as soon as possible on the method of addressing the problem. The document goes on to state:
The option of mill closure is available to State/Territory control authorities in the event of unacceptable breaches.

The Tasmanian guidelines provided that steps had to be taken to fix any breaches of emission standards within 30 minutes. It had to be decided whether it could be fixed completely within 24 hours or else there was an automatic shutdown of the operation. Again, that is a far stricter guideline than the present Commonwealth standards.
At last the Government has realised that economics matter. This document states on page 1:
The strategy being adopted by the Commonwealth to achieve these objectives is to:
(a) establish stringent emission limits based on the best available technology economically achievable (BATEA) and specify site suitability studies, baseline studies and monitoring prerequisites.

When Senator Richardson was in Tasmania he told people that he would not be diverted from doing the right thing ecologically by simple economic considerations. He is now repudiated. Indeed, the Prime Minister, in an appallingly loose and meaningless address that he gave at the opening of the Australian Conservation Foundation headquarters on 11 December, a couple of days ago, made this criticism of the Opposition:
The Coalition and their backers have learned nothing about the environment. They have pledged economy before ecology.

We have always said that those two things go hand in hand. Now the Government guidelines endorse precisely that. The Government says that the standards have to be based on the best available technology economically achievable-not the best in the world, not the best theoretically, but the best economically achievable. It has taken the Government nine months of effort to wake up to the fact that some of these things require a reasonable economic input. It is not surprising to read in today's Australian:
The Minister for the Environment, Senator Richardson, said the Wesley Vale project in Tasmania was likely to be resurrected under the guidelines, but not at the same site.

In other words, the standards proposed for the precise development at Wesley Vale, the standards proposed under the Tasmanian Government's environmental requirements, are absolutely vindicated by these guidelines. Yet we have had all of the delay and all of the loss deliberately occasioned by Senator Richardson in his pursuit of purely temporary political advantage. At least we can now say that in the Commonwealth's guidelines Senator Richardson stands condemned and repudiated-and so he should be.

As far as air emissions are concerned, again the Commonwealth is more demanding. The Commonwealth requires lower levels to be met for oxides of nitrogen, particulates, total reduced sulphur compounds, hydrogen chloride, opacity, sulphuric acid mist and sulphur trioxide. These emission limits will be met only by using the best available technology.

The most important point as far as Wesley Vale is concerned is that the guidelines do not just stop at emission limits. They also specify stringent site suitability criteria that must be satisfied. Anybody who proposes to build a pulp mill will be required to undertake detailed meteorological and hydrodynamic studies, using at least one year's adequate data to determine the suitability of proposed sites. I would have thought that the Opposition would have been quite devastated by the statement issued. In the past, Opposition members have tried to make great play of the alleged great differences of opinion on this matter between Senator Button, John Kerin and Senator Richardson. Let us compare that with the Opposition's position on this issue. The Opposition's position is similar to that of the State Government when the matter was before it. I would be the first to take the position that Senator Richardson took on Tasmania. Ideally there would be absolutely no emissions from any pulp mill. Failing that, we must take every possible precaution and set hard and fast guidelines that people understand so that there is adequate protection. The package includes a Commonwealth contribution of $7.7m to a joint Federal, State and industry research program aimed at: maintaining the capacity to research and monitor the environmental impacts of kraft mills; monitoring international developments in improved kraft technologies and alternative technologies; further reducing pollutants that may have adverse environmental impacts; achieving early reductions in organochlorines by a further 90 per cent; and, in the longer term, development of organochlorine free bleaching methods for eucalypt pulp. While that research into alternative technologies may not entirely satisfy environmentalists, it goes much further than the position we were in when the Tasmanian Government proposed to go ahead and build a mill. Believing that the previous Tasmanian Government would have instructed that mill to stop production if there had been some breach of the guidelines is the greatest joke I have ever heard.

The Industry Commission has been asked to produce two interim reports by 30 April 1990 assessing, firstly, the effects of Government policies on, and the environmental and economic cost benefit of, recycling and, secondly, the market prospects for unbleached chlorine-free paper products and the potential for non-wood feed stocks. Considering that the reports have to be produced by April 1990 and going back to Mr Paisley's statement, it is clear that in the 18-month period there will be ongoing research into the market prospects for unbleached paper and chlorine-free products. We may find in 18 months that there has been a dramatic change. There is no doubt that there is a move throughout the community to using more environmentally friendly products. That means recycled and unbleached paper. It is amazing how attitudes can change. I think there will be a reduction in demand for chlorine bleached paper and much greater use of unbleached and recycled paper.

Our big problem is that the Opposition is not in a position to come forward with any guidelines. If it were, it would never be able to abide by them and enforce them. The Opposition's problem could not be better summed up than by quoting from Bill Mandle's column in today's Canberra Times. He said:
The people of Australia show great sense in their reluctance to endorse the Liberal Party.
That would have to be the most ringing endorsement of the common sense of the Australian public. He went on to say:

The Liberals have, with rare exceptions-and they ignore the message of these exceptions-fallen into the trap of `me-tooism'. Our environmental policy is better than yours. So it might be: but no Greenie is going to vote for it.

Those comments express the view that I have put to the Senate-that is, nobody with any concern for the environment in this country could vote for the Opposition because even if it had a set of words which purported to be a policy on the environment, there is no way it could be trusted to enforce that policy. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Government's pulp mill guidelines are famous within the conservation movement for their failure to give adequate protection to the environment. Under these guidelines the Government is saying that it is perfectly acceptable for chlorine bleach pulp mills to dump up to 12 tonnes of organochlorine effluent into fragile waterways every day. However, there is considerable scientific evidence from studies of chlorine bleach pulp mills in the United States, Canada and Sweden that the dumped organochlorines poison the local marine environment and lead to dioxins entering the human food chain.

SPEECH.PARA: These Federal Government guidelines were based on the findings of an overseas delegation which had hopelessly biased terms of reference from the start. Senator Sanders has gone into that in some detail. It is time that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) team was sent on another fact-finding mission to seriously investigate alternative processes, this time accompanied by environmentalists. Only four pages out of the 81-page report that was presented yesterday referred to other available processes, to other feed stocks or to market opportunities for unbleached and recycled paper. It is absolutely ridiculous in the changing environmental global climate that this fact-finding team said that there was no market for unbleached paper products, either in Australia or overseas. Surely it is obvious that this particular team had commercial interests in mind in depriving consumers in Australia of the choice to buy unbleached paper products. It is absolutely true that there is a huge demand for unbleached paper products in this country which continues to outstrip ability for supply. Research with either of the major supermarket chains in Australia will give testimony to that.

Yesterday Senator Button claimed in his press release that the chlorine bleach method is the only pulping process that will attract serious commercial interest in Australia. I believe that this is a totally untested assumption, which is contradicted by that enormous consumer demand. It is time that the Government got into line with public opinion, which, I believe, will not accept kraft-chlorine bleached pulp mills under any circumstances. This is mainly because during the chlorination process chlorine and wood pulp combine to form hazardous chemicals called organochlorines. Two groups of organochlorines, dioxins and furans, are particularly harmful. The dioxin 2,3,7,8-TCDD is reportedly the most toxic synthetic substance ever made. To date, no safe level has been found for this dioxin.

Organochlorines are artificially produced substances which persist for long periods in the natural environment. Their affinity for organic compounds which occur in living things allows them to accumulate readily in plants and animals. It follows that animals at the top of the food chain, including humans, will accumulate the largest amounts. It is not surprising then that organochlorines, such as dioxins and furans, are common in human fat tissues and breast milk. Effects on humans include changes to the immune system, birth defects, interference with reproductive processes and organ damage. These substances are also know as carcinogens.

The study of the effects of chemicals on human health is in its infancy. The full effects may not be apparent for decades. Indeed, many health problems related to organochlorine contamination may not show up for generations. The document very interestingly titled `Pulp and Paper Industry Package', which was produced yesterday, is very definitely leaning towards the side of the industry that wants to produce these kraft-chlorine bleach mills. It mentioned one slightly good effect, which was that there will be a three-year base line study. At least that is some improvement on the draft guidelines which were so justly condemned by the environment movement. It is also commendable that the Industry Commission is going to be looking at the question of recycling and at the unbleached paper market as well. I look forward to its report next April. It is certainly important that we have that kind of information because the Government so far has shown a tendency only to look at one particular side of this question.

Industry and governments seem absolutely determined to build the kraft-chlorine bleached paper mills in Australia. As a result, we would have high export quality paper which will bring substantial economic returns, but largely undefinable environmental problems. Therefore, we must weigh up the short term economic benefits with the potential long term environmental problems which industries can cause, some of which may be irreparable. The depletion of our forests, increased soil erosion, the pollution of our rivers and seas by hazardous chemicals, and the human health risk posed by the incorporation of these chemicals in the human food chain are all part of the cost that we may have to live with if this type of paper mill is introduced.

The community has shown itself to be willing and eager to listen to and to participate in constructive proposals on environmental conservation. The Australian Government so far has not kept abreast with the community in the matter of paper production. The environment movement is not saying that we should have no pulp mills in Australia. Of course we realise that we must, but we also understand very clearly that we must look at alternatives to this potentially extraordinary damaging kraft-chlorine bleached method. The Government should be capitalising on the changes that are alive in the community. It should not leave itself so out of touch with community aspirations; it must change its way of thinking. Australians do not need eucalyptus kraft-chlorine pulp and paper mills in Australia, but generally the community will support more environmentally friendly methods of paper production. We must exert our right to a clean environment for ourselves and future generations.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the Aboriginal Development Commission's (ADC) annual report 1987-1988, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Initially the Committee on Finance and Public Administration hoped to report on this reference as part of a general report on the timeliness and quality of annual reports presented on 27 June 1989. However, the inquiry produced claims to which it was necessary to allow various parties to respond. This led to prolonged exchanges of correspondence and a public hearing. I believe that this report should be read in the context of the difficult times experienced by the Aboriginal Development Commission in recent years. It is a matter of record that 1987-88 and 1988-89 were turbulent years for the ADC. During 1987-88 the Government developed its proposals for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Commission (ATSIC). In May 1988, the Minister terminated the appointment of all but two of the commissioners then serving and appointed replacement commissioners. There were changes in senior positions in the ADC. In addition, the ADC was subject to a special audit by the Australian Audit Office and close scrutiny by parliamentary committees.

The terms of reference for the inquiry were directed at the delay in the tabling of the ADC's 1987-88 annual report, its consistency with annual reporting guidelines and five specific omissions. Further issues arose during the inquiry, including the extent to which the former ADC Chairman, Shirley McPherson, was responsible for defects in the report and the use of the name and signature of the former General Manager, Mick O'Brien. With regard to the terms of reference, the ADC argued that the delay in publication of the report resulted from audit delays and difficulties with its computerised accounting system. The ADC told the Committee that its report was `of good quality and consistent with all guidelines'. We were told that, while one of the specific omissions from the report was an administrative error by the ADC, the others were either matters which were not required to be included in the report or were not included because Shirley McPherson failed to respond to requests that she contribute to the report.

The Committee concluded, however, that the main reasons for late tabling, and indeed for other defects in the report, were the low priority accorded to its preparation by the ADC and management deficiencies within the Commission. Audit delays were not a factor in the late tabling and the Australian Audit Office was not responsible for the ADC's failure to meet the reporting deadline. The Committee assessed the report as, at best, barely meeting the statutory authority reporting guidelines. However, it would be fair to note that, to the extent that the report fails to meet the guidelines, it is possible that similar failings would be found in the reports of many agencies if they were subjected to the same detailed scrutiny.

There was some confusion as to which guidelines applied to the ADC, and the Committee took the opportunity to repeat two recommendations from its report on the timeliness and quality of annual reports. We recommended that the Government immediately commence development of a handbook of external reporting to consolidate annual reporting requirements and that the Government declare its commitment to the introduction of an annual reports Act in the medium term.

On the question of the omission of the chairman's introduction, we considered that it was ultimately the responsibility of the chairman to provide an introduction. But ADC management had administrative responsibility to arrange for its inclusion and, in its absence, should have ensured some other coverage of significant matters which would have been mentioned in a chairman's introduction. With regard to two other omissions, the Committee concluded that the annual report should have included references to the commissioners who served for most of 1987-88 and that recognition of their contribution would have been an expected courtesy in normal circumstances. In the absence of evidence to the contrary, the Committee accepts that the omission of reference to Mr Charles Perkins was an administrative error, though a serious one. It was a careless omission resulting from the rush of last minute preparation which would otherwise have been detected by proper supervision and proofreading.

On the last of the omissions specified in the terms of reference, the Committee concluded that, while there was no specific obligation on the ADC to report its advice to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) on ATSIC, it would not have been unusual for a statutory authority to have done so in the circumstances. A factual statement to the effect that the ADC had given advice to the Minister on alternatives to ATSIC should have been included, but in the circumstances it was sensible to avoid comment on the merits of the proposal. An annual report is intended to present a full picture of the activities of an organisation during the reporting period. Omissions, such as those referred to the Committee in this instance, detract from the overall quality of the report.

Much of the dispute between the ADC and others who gave evidence to the Committee focused on the question of who was responsible for the report. It became clear that the annual report was prepared by relatively junior staff, sent to the printer without clearance by the acting general manager or any member of the Board and then sent immediately to the Minister for tabling in Parliament.

The Committee concluded that responsibility for supervising the detailed preparation of the 1987-88 annual report lay with the ADC management. However, the chairman and the commissioners should have been more active in ensuring that the management of the ADC prepared a draft annual report and submitted it to them for clearance. The report contained a general manager's overview printed over the signature of Mick O'Brien, the former general manager. Concerns arose regarding the propriety of using Mr O'Brien's signature, or indeed his name, in that context, whether the overview faithfully reflected Mr O'Brien's draft and whether the overview should have been prepared by Mr O'Brien at all as he had left the position before most of the report was prepared.

The Committee concluded that the final text of the general manager's overview was very close to Mr O'Brien's draft, and that there was no improper motive behind the minor editorial changes that were made. The use of Mr O'Brien's name and signature in the report without his consent was extremely unwise, if not improper. The Committee believed that the occupant of the position of general manager at the time of report preparation was the relevant person to provide the chief executive's comment, not Mr O'Brien. However, we could understand that a decision to ignore the fact that Mr O'Brien was general manager during the period under report might have been misinterpreted.

The attitude of the ADC to the inquiry was most disappointing, at least until the acting deputy chair, Lois O'Donoghue, intervened in October. Ms O'Donoghue commissioned two reviews of aspects of the report preparation and promptly provided the results to Committee. This greatly helped to clarify the facts of the matter. The Committee found that, prior to the two reviews, the ADC had persisted in arguing positions which could not be supported by its own records. This was, as I said, most disappointing.

I thank everyone connected with the preparation of this report, and pay tribute to a the efforts of the Committee members and staff which resulted in a unanimous report. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, I would also like to make some comments on the annual report of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). I agree with the Chairman, Senator Coates, particularly when he said that this was a long and drawn out inquiry. That was brought about because there was a great deal of correspondence and toing and froing between the Commission, ourselves and other witnesses. I remind the Senate that the inquiry into this annual report followed an inquiry that the Finance and Public Administration Committee carried out into the timeliness and quality of annual reports. This report was a pretty fair example of an annual report that did not comply with too many aspects of the recommendations that we made or the recommendations of another report that was brought down by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts about the quality and timeliness of annual reports. If we took the recommendations from both committees, it would be fair to say that the 1987-88 annual report of the Aboriginal Development Commission was sadly lacking in most aspects of good annual reporting. It certainly did not meet the guidelines because it was inaccurate, incomplete and late.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of the inquiry I was disappointed to see that officers of the ADC tried to shift blame for the inadequacies of the report to other people and for other reasons. For example, one reason used for the lateness of the report was that its delay was caused by the Australian Audit Office when evidence given to us suggested that that was not the case. During evidence officers tried to blame the former chairman of the ADC for the quality and lateness of the report, because she purportedly was supposed to be totally responsible for providing the annual report when evidence did show that it was the responsibility of the general manager or the acting general manager and that the operational responsibility fell on the manager of public relations.

I make the point that as a result of our inquiries-the Chairman referred to this in his tabling statement-what really did help us was the initiative of the chairperson designate of the Aboriginal Development Commission, Lois O'Donoghue, instructing investigations into two important matters that surfaced during our inquiries. The first matter-this was referred to by the Chairman-was the purported forging of a signature of the general manager's overview which was reported upon by an officer from the office of the Australian Government Solicitor. I think the Chairman has already stated that the review that this officer carried out did clear the person involved, but it certainly did not help the report. The other inquiry was conducted internally on the evaluation of the report. This inquiry certainly confirmed the concerns of members of the Committee. Some of those concerns were that work on the report did not effectively start until the Chairman sought a draft copy in November 1988. It also came to our notice that there was very little evidence that preparation of the report was pursued in a cohesive, planned and purposeful manner after that date. As I said previously, it was proved to us beyond doubt that in overall terms the general manager was responsible for the production of the report. It was also brought to our attention that the Chairman had directed that the report not be cleared until it was finalised with the commissioners. That was not done. It was also proved to us that the operational responsibility lay with the manager of public relations during part of the compilation of the report.

I think the Chairman summed up the matter when he quoted from one of the Committee's findings. It became clear to us that the people responsible certainly did not give the report the appropriate level of priority that they should have done and did not give it as much attention as they should have done. There were several specific procedural defects in the arrangements for the preparation of the report. Paragraph 98 of our report states:
The Aboriginal Development Commission Annual Report 1987-88 fell short of meeting the ADC's accountability obligation to Parliament.

As the Chairman has said, it was well known at the time that the ADC had severe internal problems. I think that is really understating the situation. `Internal feuding' I think was another phrase that was used. Quite frankly, even allowing for that, it certainly was not any excuse for this inadequate report. However, as the Chairman said, we investigated this report in a very searching manner. If the same effort went into some of the other reports that come to this Parliament, perhaps we could make the same complaints. That does not get away from the fact that this was a very poor report. It certainly did not measure up to most guidelines that we would see as necessary for good annual reporting. One of the recommendations of the Committee stated:

The Committee recommends that the Government immediately commence development of a handbook of external reporting to consolidate annual reporting requirements. The Committee further recommends that the Government declare its commitment to the introduction of an annual reports act in the medium term.

I know that my colleague Senator Hamer also has a notice of motion before the Senate to strengthen the power of the Parliament to ensure that annual reporting becomes a more important issue as far as this Parliament is concerned and as far as the requirements that should go into good annual reporting are concerned. This exercise was well worth doing. It has been a case study of the types of things we have been looking at in our previous inquiries into annual reporting. I know from what we have been told already that the report for this year is well in hand. The ADC seems to be complying and putting its best foot forward in this case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Tambling I have only just received a copy of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the annual report of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), so it will be very difficult to offer many comments on the report in the few seconds I have had to peruse it.
