DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure entitled The Organisation and Operations of the Federal Airports Corporation and Civil Aviation Authority, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report and to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
The statement read as follows-

The inquiry into the organisation and operations of the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority showed that as two relatively newly created authorities, they are both still in the process of developing and reviewing their structures and functions.

The evidence the Committee received also demonstrated that in the aviation industry there are sectors, particularly the General Aviation sector, which disagree with certain policies and operations of the authorities.

Two aspects of both FAC and CAA operations which the aviation industry finds unpalatable are the level of charges imposed and the perceived lack of consultation with the industry before new charges are introduced.

During the conduct of the inquiry the Committee referred to the FAC and the CAA the matters of concern to the industry and in response both authorities acknowledged that there were still operational problems to be resolved with their clients. However, the Committee was assured by both that these matters are under review and the task of finding solutions is being given a high priority. This report deals with the various aspects of FAC and CAA operations which require attention and resolution and the Committee, accordingly, has drawn conclusions and made recommendations on these matters.

It is evident that both authorities have organisational and operational problems to overcome and it is vital for them to improve their relations with the aviation industry. Until this is achieved progress and growth in the aviation field will be hampered.

It is obvious that a healthy aviation industry is vital to this country's social, economic and strategic needs. The FAC and the CAA have prominent roles to ensure the viability of the industry. To fulfil their obligations they must establish sound working relationships with the industry based on mutually acceptable policies and procedures. These policies and procedures must be fair and justifiable and must be evolved through open and full consultations with all their clients.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has just had tabled the report entitled The Organisation and Operations of the Federal Airport Corporation and Civil Aviation Authority, which report is a result of an inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. I was the person in the Senate who moved the motion to set up this inquiry. I was seconded to the Committee, along with several of my colleagues, to increase its size for the duration of the inquiry, and I thank the Senate for the courtesy it showed me in having me as a member of the Committee on a temporary basis. I also thank my colleagues for the help and courtesy they showed me while I was on that Committee. It is rather strange that, as a guest member, I was the only person to make a dissenting report as part of the main report, and I wish to speak to that later.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that I moved quite a long while ago that we look at the organisation and operations of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) was my knowledge of the great concern in the Australian aviation industry at the way these two bodies were going about their tasks. The Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation are two new creations, relatively speaking, within the last three years of the present Labor Government. The aviation regulatory system in this country has been allowed to run down very much in the seven years that the Australian Labor Party has been in power. Very little money has been devoted to, ploughed back into, the industry and very little of that money has gone on maintaining the infrastructure-navigational aids and the rest of it-on which aircraft depend for accurate and safe navigation around the country.

The fundamental problem is that the Labor Party simply does not have any policy on aviation. It is not interested in aviation and just did not want to know what was going on. In the face of mounting criticisms, it decided to sidestep the issue by setting up the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority as statutory bodies, allegedly free of political interference, although in reality, of course, the Minister for Transport and Communications can direct and guide the bodies in what they do. It was most important, of course, to get aviation off budget, and that is really the key to what the Government set out to do. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, with his usual accounting sleight of hand, thought that this was a way of avoiding some costs and transferring costs from the Budget to the general community. That was the real reason behind it.

But a change was made to the pre-existing aviation section of the old Department of Transport and Communications, a body that was in very poor shape. Starting in the Whitlam years, back in the 1972 era, the old Department of Civil Aviation, which was a very good professional body with a very high professional esprit de corps and a very good standing around the world as a regulatory authority in the aviation field, was merged with what became the Department of Transport. Later on it again became the Department of Aviation, then it went back to being the Department of Transport, and ultimately it became the Department of Transport and Communications. There have been five changes of title since the Whitlam years. This had an absolutely devastating effect on morale in the old Department of Aviation because people did not know for whom they were working. They would come to work one day and find a different sign over the top of the door, and it just went on and on. The morale of the body just ran down.

In setting up the FAC and the CAA, which are statutory authorities, the Government said to them, `You will be self-funding', and the way they discharged that self-funding capacity was by using the user pays doctrine. One of the great mythologies in Australia is that aviation is a very select pursuit followed by a few very rich individuals. Nothing could be further from the truth, because aviation is an integral part of Australian society. Quite enormous indirect benefits flow to everyone through an efficient and effective aviation service. One has only to look at the hundreds of thousands of people who lost their jobs as a consequence of the pilots dispute, and the billions of dollars that the Australian economy has lost as a consequence of the pilots dispute, to recognise the very great importance of aviation to Australia and its indirect effect on the food suppliers, the moteliers, the people building motels, the transport industry on the ground and many others. Aviation alone in Australia as a section or sector of the economic pie has been carved out and subjected to this user pays doctrine.

We do not do that with other forms of transport. We very heavily subsidise road transport. In this city of Canberra, the last time I looked at the reports for the Australian Capital Territory in the Estimates committee, I believe that buses were losing-and this would go back five or six years-$15m or $16m a year, and the buses have a straight subsidy from the taxpayer. What the railways lose in Australia runs into hundreds of millions of dollars a year, and no-one worries about that. We subsidise health care through Medicare and through the hospital service. We subsidise education, despite the fact that some tertiary students pay fees. Of course, social services are a straight subsidy. Almost everything in Australia gets some degree of support, but the poor old aviation industry does not get a cent, and I think that we can see that most clearly with respect to education. Pilot training, which is enormously expensive, has to be done out of an individual's own pocket. It gets no support from the tertiary sector at all under the education programs.

Whenever the aviation industry questions increased charges being put on it, the industry is told that it enjoys a massive subsidy from the taxpayer-and nothing could be further from the truth. Just to give one example, honourable senators would be aware that aircraft use relatively huge amounts of fuel. Avgas-aviation gasoline as opposed to avtur-has a high excise component, all of which goes into Consolidated Revenue, and there is no compensation for that under the user pays doctrine. The user pays doctrine really is not a user pays doctrine at all. We have two monopoly services in the form of the FAC and the CAA, and they are providing services which are not cost efficient. In fact, they are quite dictatorial and rapacious in their charges. If we have a user pays service in place, the user should say what he or she wants and be prepared to pay for that. But the inverse situation applies with the CAA and the FAC. They decide what the user needs and then charge for a very inefficient delivery of a service-and one really has no choice because the CAA is a monopoly.

I want to spend a moment looking at the Federal Airports Corporation before I turn to the Civil Aviation Authority. The Federal Airports Corporation started off very badly because it was saddled with an enormous debt. The Government transferred to the FAC the assets for about 17 airfields originally-now up to about 23-at grossly inflated prices and said, `That is what you are starting with. You have to earn a return on it'. That was a very dishonest move. It was dishonest because those airfields were paid for by the Australian taxpayer and, furthermore, having been paid for, have been depreciated over the years. If they were to be transferred to the FAC the correct accounting procedure was for them to be transferred at the depreciated value. Had that been done, it would probably have been done at $200m, $300m or $400m, not the figure in excess of $1.2 billion that the FAC picked up to start with. So the FAC had this very large debt, or asset capitalisation, to start off its operation.

The second difficulty the FAC faced was that hardly anyone in it has any knowledge of how the aviation world in Australia operates commercially. That is not to say that there are not people on the Board of the FAC who have good commercial backgrounds. Some of them have, but they have very limited experience at a personal level of how the aviation industry goes about earning its living and paying its bills.

The third problem for the FAC was that the Board decided that every one of its airfields would be individually profitable. Given the commercial facts of life, that was not possible at all. Some airfields never can be profitable. They just do not have the traffic through them and they will never generate the funds in the fullness of time. Other airfields, such as the primary airports in the capital cities-Perth, Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane-do have the potential to make a profit. As I will argue later, they should cross-subsidise the less financially successful fields because the less successful fields have a very important place in the overall scheme of the provision of airports in this country.

The FAC set about raising money by putting charges on everything. It has gone to really absurd lengths. The most absurd example I have ever heard was of an electronics technician on one of the airfields in this country who operates from his home, who has his office and workshop there, who drives onto the airfield with a van on occasions and who probably spends about four hours a week in total time on the airfield. When he is on the airfield he is working in hangars, the lessees of which pay rent to the FAC. Yet he got billed a very high amount to get a certificate to be a supplier to the airport. That is absolutely absurd.

The most contentious thing that the FAC has done is to introduce the general aviation infrastructure tariff (GAIT), which is probably illegal and which is yet to be challenged in the court, but I do not intend to waste the time of the Senate debating the legality of that. Basically what the GAIT scheme did was to put a tax, according to the weight of the aircraft, on users of FAC airports on a daily, weekly, monthly or annual basis. That is very difficult to police. It is manpower intensive and cost intensive to police. It is also very inaccurate. It is grossly unfair because one can have aircraft owners or operators who lease hangars from the FAC on an airfield and who are paying a very high rental for that hangar. Their aircraft might not be used-they are locked up in the hangar-yet they have to pay the same fee for being on the airfield as if they were flying continually and using the runways, the taxiways and all the other services that the airfield supplies.

The GAIT scheme has been a failure. When the FAC went to the industry and tried to debate it, all the meetings they had around Australia-and they had a series of meetings; there must have been more than six or eight of them-rejected the idea. All the users, or the people who would be affected by the GAIT scheme, told the FAC that they would not accept that system. All the FAC did was to halve the figure it had been talking about originally, and then it went ahead and imposed it. At present, the great majority of people who pay GAIT are those operators who are fixed on the fields in the commercial world, doing things such as running flying training schools or charter operators where they are in the public eye and cannot avoid it. The great majority of the users of the airfields, the business community, people flying themselves around the place in small company aircraft, simply will not pay. The whole problem is that it is unenforceable. It is a nonsense from an administrative point of view. But that does not avoid the problem that somewhere or other the FAC has to get some money to run its operations.

I believe that, instead of looking at every airport on an individual basis, the FAC should look at the whole lot. If it is not prepared to look at the whole lot-and I said this in my dissenting report-it should at least look at capital city aggregations. In the capital cities there are both primary airports and secondary airports. The throughput through the secondary airports simply cannot generate the base to be profitable in the forseeable future. The primary airports can because they have tens or hundreds of thousands of fare-paying passengers going through them all the time with the airlines and it is quite possible to put a small tax on each person to generate enough money to supply enough profit to cover both the primary and the secondary airports.

The secondary airports are important in the system. They are places where a lot of the charter and supplementary airline operators can operate into and take the pressure off the primary airports. We all know the confusion and overuse that occur in Sydney at present. The secondary airports are the places where flying training takes place. The great bulk of Australian flying training takes place at the secondary airports, as do a whole lot of other things. They perform a very essential function. If the fees for using those airports escalate in the way they have under the Federal Airports Corporation, people will just go away from them. A vicious circle will be set up and we will not be able to maintain secondary airports at all. There will be a whole heap of problems downstream as a result of the loss of those airports. Not the least will be the proliferation of small private airfields with the difficulties of enforcing standards on them and, more importantly in this environment-conscious age, the noise pollution and things like that which would result from a multitude of small private fields scattered around the capital cities' perimeters.

My proposition is that the Federal Airports Corporation should be combined with the CAA. We have two authorities now which provide complementary services to the aviation industry. They are not discrete, independent services. The fact that we have two of them leads to a huge explosion in costs. Both bodies have boards. Both bodies have senior executives or a management stream in place. Both of them have major headquarters. When one gets to the airfield side of it, one finds that the CAA has an office structure and the FAC has an office structure. If one goes to Bankstown today and drives into the main part of the field, one will see the great big structure that is being built by the CAA. The FAC and CAA will share nothing. There is dual involvement in capital equipment, in buildings, in plants, in typewriters and in everything else. All of this leads to a great deal of waste through duplication. It is all unnecessary.

Furthermore, there is a lot of bad feeling between the two bodies. In my judgment, that bad feeling stems principally from their different salary structures. The Civil Aviation Authority, although it is a statutory authority, is still confined to Public Service pay scales and promotion procedures. The FAC, allegedly, is on a free commercial basis: it can pay its employees whatever it likes. The Civil Aviation Authority's traffic controllers, airworthiness surveyors, examiners of airmen and all the rest of the people who move around the airfields naturally feel disadvantaged when they see FAC employees driving around in new, air-conditioned cars doing the sort of work that a parking attendant would do, a traffic attendant in a city, seeing whether aeroplanes are paying their GAIT charges and things like that and being paid a great deal more for doing a job that carries a lot less responsibility than the CAA has.

The long term solution to the problem with the FAC is not only that it should be combined with the CAA, in my judgment, but also that it should go out of business. The best and most successful airfield in Australia today is Cairns Airport, which is run by a local group, the Cairns Harbour Trust. It is the most progressive and modern airfield in this country and by far and away the most efficient. I believe that all the primary airports in the capital cities of Australia should be run by corporations drawn from a local community and answerable to them. If that happens, then we will get a modern, efficient airport service in this country with airports competing, particularly for international traffic to come in, as gateways to this country. The whole of the Australian community will benefit from that.

The Civil Aviation Authority is a much bigger body than the Federal Airports Corporation and it has much more onerous responsibilities. The sad thing about it is that it is very badly run down at the moment. It has lost direction and lost a huge number of its experienced staff, particularly on the piloting side-examiners of airmen and airways surveyors-and, on the engineering side, engineering surveyors. These sorts of people are the heart and soul of what the CAA is about.

I believe that the Australian Aviation industry is vastly over-regulated. Last week Mr Dick Smith appeared before another committee I was on. He said that Australia has one of the most outdated, illogical and incomprehensible regulatory systems in the world. He is a board member of the CAA. I agree entirely with his views on that matter, as anyone who has listened to my speeches over the years on aviation regulation in this country would be aware. I do not agree with Mr Smith's views on safety, but that is another matter. We are vastly over-regulated. The consequence is that the Australian community must bear some very high costs. There is hope in the future. The CAA has initiated some inquiries such as that into the legal framework for air safety regulations. If the findings of that committee are implemented, they will do a great deal to streamline and modernise the regulatory system with respect to safety in this country.

One of the problems with the Civil Aviation Authority is that it tries to do everything. To give one example, it grants approvals for modifications which require a degree of engineering expertise. If someone wants to change an aeroplane and the manufacturer does not have an approved modification for it, approval has to be sought from the Civil Aviation Authority. That involves a very tedious and high cost program, because the CAA charges very highly for its services. I believe strongly that the Civil Aviation Authority should not be in the field of trying to work within the aviation industry. Those sorts of things should be done by consultants or specialised people within the industry.

The Civil Aviation Authority should only do two things. It should set standards like safety standards, airfield standards and so on, and should see that those standards are applied. The Authority should audit the industry. It should delegate powers to commercial interests in the aviation industry to perform the functions that need to be performed to guarantee the standards that are laid down by the Civil Aviation Authority. It should have enough staff to run an effective audit system on the whole industry to see that maintenance is carried out as per the laid down standards, that air traffic control procedures are followed and that other necessary things are done. They are the only two fields the Authority should be in. It should leave everything else to the industry, with the sole proviso that it should set up realistic and attainable access paths so that other people can come in and do the things that need to be done in the industry. At the moment the CAA is trying to do everything and some enormous costs are involved.

I will give the Senate an example of a case that has recently been brought to my attention by one of my constituents. He has three children, all of them pilots. One son had a student pilot's licence. He learned to fly, passed all his exams and flying tests and was entitled to get a restricted private pilot's licence. The only barrier to him getting that licence was his age. On his birthday, as he was entitled to do, he went into the CAA office-it happened to be on a Friday afternoon-presented all his documentation, paid his $20 fee and said, `Will you issue me with my restricted pilot's licence?'. The clerk behind the counter said, `Yes, we will do that but there are 14 people ahead of you and you will have to wait two or three weeks'. This is absolute nonsense. This is a fee for service matter. The boy's father happens to be a pharmacist who gets paid $4.50 by this Government to dispense a prescription yet the boy could not get a rubber stamp-which is all that is required-on his pilot's licence to transfer from a student licence to a restricted licence. This is the sort of thing people meet all the way along the line. They are being charged very high fees but must wait a very long while for indifferent service.

My constituent, the boy's father, wanted to transfer one of his aircraft from one company to another. He had to pay a fee of $80, which again is just a matter of money for old rope because the form is filled in, submitted to the Department with a cheque for $80 and the Department just transfers the name from one company to another. That sort of business could be done even by professional accountants for a fee of about one-third of the amount charged by the CAA. So it goes on. There is no commercial reality in what the Civil Aviation Authority is doing. It is involved in so many fields that it is dissipating its efforts and creating a bad climate between itself and its customers. The constituent I have just mentioned would have over $1m tied up in aircraft in Australia for his own personal use. He has three children who all fly. He flies a lot. The Civil Aviation Authority is saying that it is a commercial authority. If that is true, it should look after its customers. But here is one customer who has been given the run-around.

But the biggest problem the Civil Aviation Authority is facing at the moment is the loss of specialised staff. For example, it has only 12 examiners of airmen for regular public transport out of an establishment of 21. This gets back to the point that I made earlier about paying Public Service salaries. The CAA has never paid the salaries it needs to pay to attract and retain examiners of airmen, who are pilots by profession. Because the CAA has paid them so little, the most common applications for positions in these postings are pilots who have retired from the Royal Australian Air Force, who, with their service pension, can afford to accept a lower income than they would get in other appointments. That shortage of pilots is now quite acute. The answer to the problem is for the Civil Aviation Authority to be able to be free of the restraint of the Public Service salary scales and to be able to pay engineers and pilots what the market demands.

The Civil Aviation Authority also needs to get into its senior management ranks people who are involved in the aviation industry as pilots. I have never before known a time in my life when fewer people with personal experience in the aviation industry are employed in the upper echelons of the civil aviation department. Sir Richard Williams, who was one of the first directors of the department, would turn in his grave if he saw the bureaucrats who now infest the highest ranks of the Civil Aviation Authority and saw their lack of personal experience in an area that requires a high degree of personal involvement to understand and regulate properly.

We will always need a Civil Aviation Authority. I do not believe we will always need a Federal Airports Corporation, but we need a CAA to define standards and maintain them through an adequate audit program. The report before the Senate today is very comprehensive and shows the problems being faced by the two authorities. We received something like 122 written submissions. While I did not count them, well over 100 of those would have been highly critical of the two statutory authorities which were the subject of the inquiry. That speaks for itself. I commend the report to the Senate and to the general public because it gives people an insight into how the two authorities operate and it makes some suggestions as to how problems can be alleviated in the future. Australia must have an efficient transport industry. Within that efficient transport industry the place of an efficient aviation industry is absolutely paramount. One cannot have an efficient aviation industry unless regulatory bodies such as the Federal Airports Corporation and Civil Aviation Authority are running at a much higher level of efficiency than they are at the moment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY (PHOTOGRAPHIC FILM) BILL 1989CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (ANTI-DUMPING) BILL 1989CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1989CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 October, 23, 24, and 29 November, on motions by Senators Robert Ray and Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is dealing with a package of six Customs Bills: the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill 1989, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1989, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, and the Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill 1989. The final Bill, the Bounty (Photographic Film) Amendment Bill, will be dealt with by my colleague Senator Lewis later in the debate. There is a longstanding view that customs Bills are always run through in the dying hours of a session so that no one can get a chance to examine them. There is also a view around that this is a conscious act of government policy.
—It is a custom of the Senate.

—I see the Whip confirming that. I can assure the Whip that, as shadow Minister for customs, I have examined all these Bills in considerable detail and I certainly have a view on all of them. The first point to be made about these Bills is that they continue the practice of this Government of legislation by press release-a practice that this Government has made into an art form. A press release is put out indicating a change and months or even a year later the legislation is introduced. The consequence is that the Parliament becomes just a rubber stamp. Also of concern to me-and these comments relate to much of the customs legislation-are these three things: first, the amount of discretion given to the Comptroller-General by the Government; secondly, the difficulty associated with working under customs legislation because of the complicated nature of the definitions involved; and, finally, the ever-increasing amount of litigation being caused by poor drafting and ineffective definition. On the matter of poor drafting, I just instance for a moment the valuation provisions of the May customs legislation. Properly defining a transaction value involves working through over 140 subdefinitions, about four of which involve reference to other statutes. In the same legislation, the valuation provisions alone allow for about 90 instances of discretion for the Australian Customs Service, a practice which is growing and to which the Opposition is opposed. The discretionary powers of public servants should be limited and confined to the smallest number possible. It is for the Government to incorporate in legislation how an Act and the Public Service should operate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Customs Service has been subject to greater public accountability for its actions since the administrative law package was introduced in the mid-1970s. That accountability has meant that the actions of Customs officers have been questioned. Customs has been required to explain its decisions and engage in reviews of its decisions by external authorities. Customs has not been coming off too well in these encounters. Recently in the Federal Court, in an appeal for a refund of duty paid which the Australian Customs Service had refused to pay, Customs' action was labelled not as `high-minded' but rather as `a shabby thing or a dirty trick which the court would not allow'. In the Corinthian Industries case the judge made the comment that a couple of sections of the Act which were under scrutiny were `not ambiguous' and that `they should be applied having regard to the words used, not according to some background philosophy'. Let us be perfectly clear where the blame for this lies. It does not lie with the conscientious officers of the Australian Customs Service but with the poor management and poor policies of this Hawke Government. The question of litigation will be very important if the Government's amendments to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) proceed. But I will deal with that Bill later.

The first of the Bills in this package which I wish to look at is the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2). This is a straightforward matter and gives legislative authority to the decision announced in March that excise duty on naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas is to be at a rate of free. This decision reflects the fact that the excise threshold of $147 a tonne has not been reached through the preceding six months. The Opposition supports this Bill.

The next Bill-the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill-owes its existence to the Air Caledonie case in regard to section 55 of the Constitution. Whole sections of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 are transferred to the Customs Act 1901 by repealing them under this Bill. These sections are then transferred using the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill 1989 as the vehicle.

These Bills seek to remove any difficulties which might occur as a result of the High Court's deliberations during the Air Caledonie Case. This is done by transferring sections of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 to the Customs Act 1901, by repealing them under the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill. The High Court in Air Caledonie International v. the Commonwealth, which case arose when the Government sought to impose a fee for immigration clearance in respect of international airline passengers entering Australia, dealt at length with section 55 of the Constitution. Section 55 of the Constitution provides that laws imposing taxation deal only with the imposition of taxation. It was considered in the past that the prohibition on mixing taxing and non-taxing acts was not infringed when an Act dealing with the imposition of customs duties amended a principal Act which contained provisions concerning non-customs duty matters. The High Court decision in this 1988 case now construes section 55 as extending to laws in the form in which they stand from time to time after amendment with the requirement that such laws deal only with the imposition of taxation or duties of customs. The companion Bill also allows a profit margin to be included in the matters considered when a normal value is being constructed-that is section 269tac (2) (c) (ii)-except where sales in the country of export have been at a loss for an extended period of time, covered by new section 269tac (13).

Dumping occurs when the export price is less than the normal value of goods in the domestic market in the country of export. Sometimes, because the goods are not sold on the domestic market of the exporting country or because of a centrally planned economy, the normal value on the home market is not available and a normal value has to be constructed. The Opposition supports these Bills.

Next in the package is the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989. This Bill amends the Customs Tariff Act 1987 through a series of amendments contained in nine schedules of the Bill. These amendments to the 1987 Act reflect a housekeeping of the tariff. A number of the amendments relate to correcting anomalies created through the adoption of the harmonised tariff. Some of these amendments are Australia's obligations under the Australia-New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement are being met by a number of amendments which implement unrestricted duty free access for footwear of New Zealand origin; duty free importation of certain New Zealand fabrics; the removal of tariff rates applicable to tender extension provisions for goods from New Zealand; and an acceleration of the move to free trade in apparel. Additionally some changes recommended by the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority are implemented through schedules 4 and 6. These amendments basically correct the effect of sloppy classification by the Government.

Also under this Bill the metal parts for footwear have their quota removed and a 15 per cent duty rate imposed. Following the November 1986 decision these goods were joined in with other footwear parts, which meant they were subject to quota and attracted a base rate of 40 per cent. A similar situation arose in regard to certain protective garments used by firefighting bodies and persons involved with harmful chemicals. Prior to 1986 these goods were subject to a classification order and as such were imported at minimum rates. However in 1986 the Australian Customs Service changed its classification. The result was that those suits without breathing apparatus were entered under quota and at a base rate of 55 per cent. The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill also makes changes which relate to the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission report into the mining, construction and agricultural equipment industries. A number of products are afforded duty free entry. Items of major interest include mining shovels, electric walking draglines, rock cutters, tunnelling equipment, certain loaders and excavators.

I would like to comment on some of the existing anomalies. We still have the situation in Australia where some fully assembled imports of machinery are duty free or come under a speedier regime of tariff reduction. But when they are imported as components, or if components of them are required for Australian manufacture, they either attract a heavy rate of duty or are programmed for a slower rate of reduction. This is absurd and has a significant consequences for a number of Australian manufacturers, such as Waltanna Tractors. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) seems to be intent on driving that company to Canada by giving it no support at all. This tractor manufacturer is producing a crawler tractor, but a crawler with rubber tracks instead of metal tracks. It is regarded as being a world class tractor-better than the Caterpillar design, which is the only other rubber-tracked crawler tractor on the market today.

Waltanna produces in Victoria and some of the components required for the manufacture of these tractors have to be imported from overseas. It pays a very high duty on those. If it imported an entire tractor it would pay no duty at all. The Government has been aware of this anomaly for years and it simply has refused to do anything about it. That is one of the irritating things about the present policy of this Government in relation to customs, which manufacturing industry in Australia finds quite intolerable. However, reverting to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, the Opposition will support it.

Finally, I turn to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989. This is an omnibus Bill which proposes changes to six pieces of customs and excise legislation. The amendments contained in the Bill cover the termination of manufacture in bond; new requirements for bottling bulk potable spirits; the repeal of various unproclaimed sections of the Customs Act; and changes to the commercial tariff concession system. Manufacture in bond was introduced to assist local manufacturers by allowing them access to imported goods without paying import duty. Manufacturing must take place in Customs-licensed warehouses. However, little manufacture has been undertaken under this scheme. Over the past couple of years the number of warehouses using this system has fallen from 14 to only four. There will be alternative schemes available to manufacturers to import those goods duty free.

The amendment covering the bottling of bulk spirits creates a requirement that first of all limits the availability of spirits in bulk. It also requires bottling in licensed premises and therefore under supervision. Both the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) and the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts have recommended these changes, principally on the grounds that they ensure that there is no evasion of excise duty. The Opposition supports these amendments.

We are not prepared to support in their entirety the changes to section XVa of the Customs Act which deal with tariff concession orders. In the past, Australia has erected high tariff barriers to protect its own manufacturing industry. Tariff concession orders have been granted by Customs to allow entry of goods which are not produced in Australia. The principal beneficiaries of the tariff concessional order have overwhelming been manufacturing industries, because in respect of goods they need in the manufacture of products in some cases they can apply and get a concession granted to import those duty free.

It is necessary to go back a little in history to understand how we got to the present system. I said that we had high tariff barriers in the past and that was true of the era after the Second World War. It is now Government policy, and it is the policy of the Opposition, to reduce those tariff barriers that we have in place to levels that apply in other countries. Steps have already been taken in that direction and they will be continued in the foreseeable future.

About 10 years ago we had a system which, unlike the system under section XVa of the Act at the present time, was really a set of by-laws, controlled very stringently by the Australian Customs Service. Of course, in the operation of those by-laws guidelines were used. It was a very difficult system to administer and it was very hard to get consistency and predictability. There were a large number of anomalies and manufacturing industry was not very happy about it. In 1982 the Fraser Government set up an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry to investigate the by-laws system that had been in operation up to that time. It recommended some radical changes, which came into effect in 1983 and really form the basis of section XVa of the present Customs Act. If honourable senators have not read that Act, it is really quite large, at about an inch thick.

The changes recommended by the IAC that were incorporated in the legislation were a series of very precise requirements that had to be met before goods could be imported duty free. It talked about definitions for things such as identical goods, particular goods, goods serving similar functions, cross-elasticity of demand, and goods capable of being produced or repaired in the normal course of business. In the old days when someone sought a tariff concession to enter goods duty free, a manufacturer who had the capability of producing those goods, even though he was not prepared to produce them and had never produced them in the past, could block the importation of goods by saying, `Look, there is my plant and equipment. I can produce the goods'. The amendments that were incorporated into the Customs Act after 1983 dealt with that matter very specifically. They defined `normal course of business' in words that stated that the manufacturer had to be in the position where he was ready to take orders for those goods. The notional concept that he could provide them if he needed to was not adequate.

The Government is proposing to get rid of the whole of section XVa. I concede that the current legislation has its problems-that is undeniable-but it is workable and it has been in place now for something like six years. It is accepted by Australian industry and by those people who have to use it. Furthermore, we now have a body of case law developing to guide people into how it should be interpreted. Over and above everything else, it is an infinitely better system and an infinitely better piece of legislation than that which preceded it prior to 1983. Defined in the Act are a series of requirements that have to be met, and very clearly defined, before someone gets a tariff concession entry. Apart from that, there is a provision that the Comptroller-General can grant, in the national interest-and the national interest is rarely invoked; it is a very special case with special connotations-a tariff concession order to someone to import goods duty free if he believes the circumstances are so exceptional that it is justified in the national interest, even though it does not meet the requirements of the Act. So there is a safety valve to these provisions.

If the proposals before the Senate today are passed, the very basis on which tariff concession orders are at present granted which are precise, predictable and stable, will disappear. All the definitions which define the circumstances under which a concession may be granted are going to disappear. What we will get in their place is a system of guidelines. Under the proposed legislation, the guidelines will be proclaimed by the Minister but they will be written by the Australian Customs Service and its officers. So they will write the things, the Minister will proclaim them, and then the Australian Customs Service will act as judge, jury and arbiter on the implementation of the system. The very fact that they are in guideline form, even though there will be a disallowable instrument and it will be tabled in Parliament, leads to unpredictability and uncertainty, and, quite clearly, to enormous problems of definition and argument as to what will be required. The predictability and stability of the current legislation will be thrown out.

One of the most important changes that will take place is the abolition of the precision of the definition of particular goods and the substitution of that for a class of goods. In simple terms, that means that using the examples of a suture needle for surgical application, if a person wants to import a surgical needle because none is made in Australia the opportunity will exist under the proposed legislation to compare surgical suture needles not with other surgical needles which might be available in Australia but with a whole class of goods, which would include all sorts of needles. The same situation could apply with earth moving equipment, where shovels may be compared with bulldozers. The very fact that we are moving from the particular to the general opens up a whole range of goods which really should not be compared with the particular good which the importer seeks to import.

The Government argues that these proposed changes are necessary to give the Customs Service increased flexibility so that more tariff concession orders can be granted. The logic of that evades me. I simply cannot see the point at all. My reading of the changes proposed is that the end result will be that a lot of tariff concession orders--

SPEECH.PARA: In the middle of last week I received a letter from the Joint House Department under the signature of Mike Bolton, Secretary. The letter pertains to some actions of mine to attempt to get the Joint House Department to acquire some photographs of the construction of this building in which we are housed. The photographs were taken by a person who worked on the House during the construction phase and who had an exhibition of his photographs in the House shortly after its opening. I refer to Jack Clarke. On the strength of the photographs that Jack took over a period, he was awarded a scholarship to the Canberra College of Art and has been studying there for the past two years. I have briefly seen his exhibition and I have a couple of copies of Jack's photographs in my office.

Jack Clarke attempted to get the Joint House Department to acquire the collection that he had gathered, by whatever means, over the years. He was running into some difficulty and approached me in the middle of this year to see whether I could assist in getting an answer to his queries. I in turn wrote to you, Mr President, and got a fairly speedy reply, but not necessarily a resolution at that time. The letter that I received on, I think, Wednesday of last week, did not particularly please me. It stated:
Dear Senator,
I refer to your letter of 8 June 1989 to Mr President concerning the photographic works of Mr John Clarke.
Honourable senators will notice that I have been talking about Mr Jack Clarke. I continued:
The Presiding Officers have considered your request and have asked me to pass on to you the advice provided to them on this matter.

The Parliamentary Artworks Coordinator has inspected the sample pair of Mr Clarke's photographs which are currently located in your office. It is the Coordinator's opinion that the collection has some historical merit, however the quality of the works is not considered to be of the same calibre as Ms Sandy Edwards' works (known as the BLF Collection) which currently hang in the Non-Members' Bar. In addition, similar works exist in the Parliament House Construction Authority collection which is currently being prepared for archival action, but which will be available to Parliament from January 1990.
I have no problems whatsoever with the letter so far. However, it continued:

The Parliament needs to be mindful of the precedent which may be established in accepting works prior to the finalisation of acquisitions policy. I mention also that State galleries do not normally accept works into their collections from students to avoid the onslaught of works offered by artists who are endeavouring to make a name for themselves and to avoid being seen to give an advantage to one student over another. It must be remembered that acquisition of works from artists validates their work and the Parliament cannot be seen to be playing favourites and accepting works that do not meet its thematic and aesthetic criteria.
Under these circumstances I recommended to the Presiding Officers that the Parliament not accept or acquire the collection at this stage.

As I indicated earlier, it was signed by Mike Bolton, the Secretary of the Joint House Department. I take exception to the second last paragraph which talks about a precedent that may be established by accepting such works of art. I suppose we have here a reason or an excuse for some of the pieces of art displayed around this building. It could be interpreted from that paragraph in the latter that the works of art in this building have been acquired with the name of the artist in mind rather than on the artistic merit of the pieces involved. I am not sure of that, but I certainly put that interpretation on the paragraph in that letter.

That is the bad news. I want to conclude my short speech tonight with some good news. Last week the Canberra College of Art held its 1989 graduating students exhibition, which is a culmination of the work of 60 students who have completed either a two-year full time associate diploma course or a four-year course at the College. One of the schemes operating within that exhibition is the emerging artists support scheme, which is supported by a number of corporate patrons which include Mallesons Stephen Jaques, the Lend Lease Group, Canberra, the Australian National University, the National Recording Studios and the Parliamentary Library.

Last week the Parliamentary Library attended the exhibition. It did not look at the names of the artists; it selected the work on merit. I am very pleased to record in Hansard that the work of Jack Clarke was chosen by the Parliamentary Library under its acquisitions program. I am very pleased that that has happened and that Jack's work will get some recognition. Because of the pleasure that he has received from the acceptance of his work, he has in turn donated his collection to the Parliamentary Library. This is a very generous gesture by Jack Clarke, who put a lot of his life's work into the making of this very comfortable building.

I have no hidden agenda in raising this matter tonight. It may be interpreted that way by some people, because I have previously sought to take Mr Bolton to task over a particularly bureaucratic document which was circulated around the Parliament, although I understand that it was not meant to be circulated to senators. I received a personal apology from Mike and an explanation of what happened at that time. There is certainly no vendetta on my part in raising this matter tonight. But I am pleased to put on the record that a degree of justice has been done. I also record that, during my contribution tonight, I noted a number of exclamations made by honourable senators assembled in the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —A triumvirate of Ministers has just issued a joint statement on pulp mills and the paper industry. There is little new in this package; it is basically a recapitulation and expansion of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) report issued in June this year and it attempts to address some of the basic needs identified in that report. The Ministers have had the benefit of the advice of the authors of the CSIRO report. Tonight I want to look at some of the likely effects of the implementation of these guidelines. We are being told that large local kraft process mills not only will replace with a domestic product the considerable volume of our paper and pulp imports but also will enable Australia to break into the international pulp market.

SPEECH.PARA: I will put aside for the moment and consideration of the barriers that Australian exporters of value-added products always seem to encounter and examine some of the domestic costs for the establishment of a kraft process pulp mill in the Grafton area. Daishowa International did indicate an interest in establishing a mill in this region but this proposal seems to have been shelved for the time being and the State Government has called for new `expressions of interest' after the completion of the New South Wales paper and pulp industry strategy and the Federal Government's environmental guidelines. There has been strong local opposition to the siting of a large world scale pulp mill in the Grafton district. A survey in July this year indicated that over 75 per cent of respondents were opposed to the construction of a mill; while fewer than 6 per cent said that they were for a pulp mill. Concerned citizens in the region formed the Clarence Valley Conservation Coalition to examine the pulp mill proposal and decided that the negative impacts of the proposal--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the fact that the paper to which Senator Dunn is referring is currently on the Notice Paper. The matter was addressed today and Senator Dunn had the right to speak at that time. As it is on the Notice Paper, it is not appropriate for her to address it at this time.
—It is a matter that was debated today and it is listed on the Notice Paper. There have been rulings both ways in the past. We have tended to be flexible, so I will allow Senator Dunn to continue.

—Thank you, Mr President. I am talking about one particular pulp mill at Grafton rather than the report itself. As I mentioned, concerned citizens in the Grafton area, many of whom are National Party voters, have examined the pulp mill proposal, with the assistance of conservationists in the region, and have decided that the negative impacts of the proposal would well outweigh the benefits. At several rallies to oppose the pulp mill thousands of people have attended. At one I spoke at 5,000 people were present. Among the opponents of the pulp mill at Grafton are the Clarence River Professional Fisherman's Association, the Clarence River Fishermen's Cooperative, north coast apiarists, a number of sawmillers and many other organisations. Business people, builders, local councillors and farmers are among the cross-section of the community actively concerned about the mill proposal. One of the reasons why the fishermen are concerned can be illustrated by quoting from the June CSIRO report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that bleached kraft mill effluent contains a variety of compounds that exhibit chronic toxicity-some at very low concentrations-to aquatic organisms. The important question is to what extent are they likely to be produced in a modern eucalypt mill, or find their way from a given pulp mill into aquatic organisms in concentrations sufficient to cause significant deleterious effects? A fully satisfactory answer is not available-nor is likely to be available-in the foreseeable future.

That was taken from Fandry's document. This cannot be discounted by the new guidelines, even though the organochlorine emissions allowed are low by world standards. However, the release of organochlorines is not the only reason why the fishermen are concerned. There are many other possible effects on the marine life of the area that do not relate to organochlorines. There will also be other environmental effects even if the predictions for minimal organochlorine emission and rigorous monitoring are realised.

One of the concerns expressed many times by the local fishing industry that is not addressed by the guidelines is the inevitable increase in siltation that will follow large scale pulp logging. As far as I can tell from a cursory reading, the Federal Government's guidelines would allow a mill similar in scale to those previously proposed for Wesley Vale and Grafton to be built at Grafton. The locals feel that they have been getting very contradictory messages from the Government on this point. It depends which Minister one is listening to. A spokesperson for John Button was quoted in the Grafton Daily Examiner as commending plans by the State Government to establish a chemical pulp mill in northern New South Wales. But a different impression was left by Senator Graham Richardson when he visited Grafton in July this year. Locals are complaining that they have not heard much from him since then, despite written submissions and his promises of a detailed response.

Perhaps the most concrete indication of the attitude of the Federal Government-and the attitude of the State Government-is its permission for the woodchip quota from the north coast through the port of Newcastle to be increased from 350,000 to 500,000 tonnes per annum, and a new quota licensed through the port of Brisbane, without any environmental impact statement or the implementation of appropriate management techniques. The Federal member, Mr Ian Robinson-Mr Causley's National Party colleague-said just a few weeks ago that he continues to oppose construction of a pulp mill unless it can be proved that it will not harm the environment. It will be interesting to hear Mr Robinson's response to the new guidelines. Similar `responsible' sentiments have been expressed by Grafton's Mayor and local National Party Leader, Mr Mike Emerson. However, Federal National Party Leader, Mr Blunt, said on Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) radio that a future Peacock-Blunt government would be likely to stick with the environment guidelines established by the Hawke Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I draw your attention to the fact that Senator Dunn is flaunting the Standing Orders of the Senate by reading her speech.
—I remind Senator Dunn that she should not read her speech. I take it that she is referring to copious notes. I will allow her to continue.

—Thank you, Mr President. The honourable senator opposite is quite flattering in claiming that I am reading my speech. I only wish that I had that fluency. It has been claimed by many that the proposed mill at Grafton would provide considerable employment for locals. However, the reality is that modern pulp mills are highly automated and provide few jobs. Numerous statements by proponents of the Clarence mill have greatly exaggerated the employment possibilities. For example, Mr Peter Went, Daishowa's Eden Manager, claimed on ABC radio 2NR on 1 February this year that the mill would create up to 1,000 direct jobs. Dr Wal Gentle claimed in the Daily Examiner of 11 February 1989 that up to 3,000 jobs would be created. The Sydney Morning Herald of 18 March this year reported a similar claim by the local member for Clarence, Mr Ian Causley. On radio 2NR on 11 November 1989, Mr Causley stated that such a mill would provide 4,000 jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aanekoski mill in Finland, which is a prototype for mills such as this, provides permanent employment for 280 people. A slightly more realistic assessment came from Tasmania's Wesley Vale consortium which claimed that it would provide 410 direct jobs, even though 200 were to be lost at Longreach and elsewhere in the sawmilling industry under an agreement with the Tasmanian Government. That means a total gain of only 210 jobs. The reality is that likely job losses in existing industries, including fishing, tourism and sawmilling, would more than offset the few jobs that a pulp mill would provide.

The New South Wales pulp and paper strategy was drawn up by a task force comprising industry representatives, including Harris-Daishowa and Amcor Ltd; two industry union representatives; and two industry departments-that is, Wal Murray's Department of State Development and Ian Causley's Forestry Commission. The task force failed to include any of the Government's own environmental planning authorities or any community or environment group. There was no consultation with industries such as fishing that have registered strong concerns. The terms of reference failed to refer to environmental considerations, the likely impact on the community or the losses that the pulp industry would impose on existing industries, such as sawmilling, which is already in decline in this region.

Without any comprehensive study of timber availability, the report calls for the establishment of a `world scale' chlorine bleaching mill on the north coast and in other locations throughout New South Wales. The strategy stresses that subsidies will be needed and that the Government should educate the public to understand the benefit of these mills-in other words, that the Government should put out propaganda to persuade the public of the desirability of having these mills, despite all the arguments against them. A good deal of public money has already been spent by the Forestry Commission and Messrs Causley and Murray attempting to do just this. The report also makes it clear that the industry expects to continue to consume our forests and despoil the environment at a very low cost. With the present industry thrust, it seems Australia will be internationally competitive only when we are willing to treat our forests as poorly as the worst international performers and continue to subsidise the industry by the pollution of our environment.

The proposed mill at Grafton would require some 1.6 to 1.8 million tonnes of timber feedstock annually. This would be drawn from a 250 kilometre radius of Grafton-that is, an area north of Taree to the Queensland border and west into the tablelands. The total tonnage of all timber types from crown and private land on the north coast was approximately 450,000 tonnes last year. To suggest that this tonnage could be quadrupled without major environmental damage strains credibility. This is about twice the tonnage presently being taken from south-eastern New South Wales forests for woodchipping and it would be, at best, a massive ecological experiment and, at worst, an environmental disaster. Half the timber would come from private land. The 1975 north coast woodchip inquiry found that there were very few environmental controls for the removal of timber resourced from private land. This is still the situation today-14 years later.

One of the problems that the fishing industry is particularly concerned about is that, when the trees are removed from private land, the siltation caused by the removal of the top soil will be massive and there will be no redress by the fishing industry. This year we have heard a lot about the severity of the land degradation problem, and it would be naive to assume that this vast quantity of timber could be removed without really severe impact. There is already considerable erosion along the Orara River, which borders on private land, and that shows very clearly the consequences of private land degradation. It can be seen from aerial photographs.

The fishing industry on the north coast employs 700 to 800 people, and fish products from Coffs Harbour to Ballina earn approximately $26m annually. The north coast timber industry provides 1,500 jobs and has an annual turnover of $40m to $50m. There are approximately 860 north coast apiarists, with total annual earnings of $7m. The fishing industry-not normally a radical greenie industry-is concerned about chemically laden mill effluent and the increased siltation, as I have already mentioned.

Many of the sawmillers are apprehensive that the huge amount of timber required to feed a pulp mill would deplete their resource almost entirely and threaten their livelihoods. The sawmill industry in the region is already operating at 30 per cent less than capacity. It seems extraordinary that the needs of the existing industry are not being met before the introduction of a huge competitive industry. The contrast between a forest industry with a large sawmilling component and one based primarily on woodchips can be illustrated by Forestry Commission figures for the north and south coast industries. At a time when there were 1,512 people employed in the north coast region with a 450,000 tonne output, 416 people were employed in the south coast region with a 750,000 tonne annual output. Meanwhile, the apiarists on the north coast are complaining that the destruction of the mature age forests will ruin their industry and that Mr Causley, supposedly their protector, is doing nothing to protect their interests. Growth industries, such as tourism, are also increasingly concerned about the likely adverse impact of such a highly polluting industry.

Noise and traffic would also be a problem. At least 72,000 laden vehicle journeys each year would be required for the supply of timber feed stock to the mill. Input and output would mean that, if the mill operated day and night, there would be at least one truck to or from the mill every two or three minutes around the clock. The local roads have not been made for this type of usage. There will be a high additional cost for road maintenance and replacement. A common estimate puts road damage by one truck as equal to 10,000 times the damage done by a single car.

Estimates based on the Wesley Vale mill proposal indicate that the Clarence mill would have a solid waste dump of approximately 35,000 tonnes a year. This is equivalent to the garbage output of a town of 20,000 people. The solid wastes would include numerous chemicals that could leach and run off into the watertable and waterways. Such problems would be compounded by the frequent high rainfall and flooding experienced on the north coast, which appears to be getting more serious year by year.

Emissions are also a major concern. Not only are these mills foul smelling, but also the experience in British Columbia-which I saw on the ABC television program 7.30 Report on 8 February 1989-and elsewhere indicates that acid rain results from such mills unless very expensive scrubbing plants are installed. This does not seem to be anticipated by the guidelines, and whether the odour can really be controlled is another matter. The Swedish consultant to the Tasmanian Government has reported that it is impossible to have a smell-free pulp mill. Finnish expert Kaj Granberg says of such mills: `You can taste them on the wind 40 or 50 kilometres away.'

The siting of the mill and the prevailing atmospheric conditions would influence the severity of this problem. If the emissions are not strictly controlled, the sulphur dioxide alone could have a substantial impact on agricultural production throughout the Clarence district and possibly beyond. The solution proposed for Wesley Vale was to construct a 100-metre tall chimney to help disperse the problem, that is, to get rid of it further up in the atmosphere. These emissions have led to an increase in respiratory ailments near mills overseas. The usual burning of sludge to generate power at such plants can release organochlorines as well as sulphur compounds in the emissions. The new guidelines do address this area of operation, but I am yet to be convinced that the problem can be controlled completely with current technology. Mr Trevor Brown, who is the Director of the Tasmanian Department of the Environment, admitted that it was possible that dioxin may be formed at Wesley Vale. The Tasmanian Government decided not to monitor for dioxin in the emissions, but said that if there were effects it would look into them.

There are still considerable problems in monitoring these toxic outfalls. Until a eucalypt processing plant is actually in operation, the impact on indigenous marine life cannot be established. The processes involved cannot be adequately reproduced in the laboratory and the reactions of individual marine species to minute traces of toxic materials are very variable, so the experience of large kraft processors of eucalyptus overseas can be only a partial guide. Particular conditions prevail in Australia and we need to do our own research for Australian conditions. The Wesley Vale consortium was unable to give an assurance that toxic effluent from the mill would not adversely affect marine life in Bass Strait. The question is: How much harm will they do? The onshore currents which affect the New South Wales north coast make it likely that any adverse effect from the proposed mill outfalls would affect the proposed marine park area south of Coffs Harbour and possibly areas north along the coastline up to Byron Bay.

There are indications that the chlorine bleaching process will soon be superseded. Tetra Pak (Australia) Pty Ltd, part of the world's largest packaging manufacturer, and Proctor and Gamble, the United Kingdom nappy manufacturer, have indicated that they will no longer use bleached board because of concerns regarding dioxins. There are other examples of a change in attitude towards the use of paper products produced by non-chlorine based mills. The original CSIRO report and the new guidelines underestimate the strength of this development. Unbleached and recycled papers are becoming more generally available, as Senator Vallentine said earlier today. Bleaching with oxygen is an option that is becoming more competitive economically. Studies on this are currently being done overseas.

Do we really need to use all the paper and packaging that we now consume? I think it was Senator Sanders who made the point today that perhaps some male members of this place are not aware of the unnecessary packaging of many products because it is their wives who do the shopping for their families.

Once established, it would be virtually impossible to win the closure of such a plant even if our worst concerns were realised. The failure of governments and environmental agencies in North America to monitor and force compliance with environmental standards there adds doubt to the situation here. The likely impact of the mill on existing industries in the Grafton district would serve to greatly reduce the economic diversity and resilience of this region's economy, which is flourishing. It may also restrict the future growth base of the local economy. That is why the locals are so very concerned, and that is why they are going to vote Mr Causley out of office at the next State election.

Woodchip operations at Eden have received large sums of Federal and State moneys. During an interview on the ABC radio program AM on 14 February, Senator Richardson revealed that the Wesley Vale mill would have received over $100m of direct and indirect Federal Government subsidies. State and local government infrastructure provisions would have accounted for further tens of millions of dollars. Our taxes should not be used to bolster up the profits of overseas multinational companies, be they from Japan or elsewhere.

Much has been made of the potential export earnings from such an industry. The extent of our foreign indebtedness will not be reduced by government subsidies to foreign corporations, which have a propensity to contribute little to the local economy and to decimate our existing industries. We will merely inherit the debt burden of a company such as Harris-Daishowa an be further strained by the need to expatriate profits to the foreign owners. The Business Review Weekly dated 21 April 1989 indicates that Daishowa is a highly geared corporation that already owes 339 billion yen in bank loans. In the year to September 1988, 80 per cent of its net earnings went to paying off loan interests. The need for caution is furthered by the fact that the pulp and paper industry is highly cyclical and is going through its longest sustained expansion since the 1960s. Once a mill was established, our local economy would be subject to the future booms and busts of the pulp and paper industry.

There is another troubling aspect about new, large mills. Australia will find it hard to escape from its commitments to provide woodchips to the Japanese market. This may mean there will be pressure both to fulfil existing quotas and to provide the feed stock for new Australian mills. This means that the strain on the existing old-growth forest resources of this country would be massive, and we would still not have the plantations to supply them. The question of plantations needs to be addressed by the Federal Government as a matter of urgency-and it seems to be one point on which the Government, the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and the independents all seem to agree.

TALK.START.PARA: —I trust that I raise a subject close to your heart, Mr President. As a long time visitor to the African continent, you would be acutely aware of the conflict that has been raging in the Horn of Africa for about 28 years and which, hopefully, is getting much closer to resolution than it has ever seemed before. I want to speak in my capacity as a sponsor of the Eritrean Relief Association generally to express approval and encouragement for the peace process, which I think has already produced some very significant results. What was resolved in Nairobi on 28 November last is very positive. Following on from the Atlantic conference only three issues were outstanding issues: the question of chairmanship; the status of the observers; and the extent of the secretariat.

SPEECH.PARA: All of those issues having been resolved, there would not seem to be very much left to divide the parties, but one should not express premature optimism. I note from correspondence that I have received that there are still allegations of lack of good faith which, on their face, need to be taken seriously and particularly given that, once again, there would be seem to be an imminent threat of drought which in the past across the Sahel has wreaked enormous devastation and extensive loss of life. It has been suggested to me that there is still an unwillingness on the part of the Ethiopian authorities to discuss common measures that might be taken to alleviate that suffering. That is a matter of concern, and I hope that the Australian Government will be prepared to urge the Ethiopian Government to enter into sensible discussions about long term development and short term assistance and not simply address the mechanics of the peace process. Ultimately, if assurances can be given about the future in terms of assistance, both internationally and domestically, there is much more likelihood that the parties will resolve those final outstanding difficulties.

One other matter which seems to have caused some agitation is the participation of the United Nations as an observer. It seems to be quite clear that the United Nations has agreed to accept that role and that both sides have made it clear that they will accept a United Nations nominated observer. Again, there are some allegations that the United Nations has declined to accept the proposed role and that some undermining is going on. From the information available to me, I simply want to say that that does not seem to be the case. I hope that the Australian Government will fervently urge that both sides accept the status of any United Nations appointed observer and encourage the United Nations through the General Assembly to ensure that that observer is well received. We should be grateful for the roles being played by a former President of the United States, Jimmy Carter, and former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere. I hope that their involvement will mean that all of the outstanding concerns can be speedily resolved.

It has been a very long and bloody conflict. If one can draw any consolation from a struggle as protracted as this, it is that the spirit of the Eritrean people remains undiminished. They have certainly shown amazing courage and ingenuity. All of those people who have visited the region, from Thomas Keneally in recent times through to Senator Schacht, who was there last year, and a number of other people with whom I speak from time to time, are continually amazed at the positive approach that is adopted in the face of unremitting attack from the Ethiopian army and air force. As much as one could ever imagine it, life seems to go on almost as normal, even though most of the education, which is compulsory, is conducted under ground; most of the eating and sleeping is conducted under ground. It is only the fighting that seems to be done up in the real world.

It seems amazing to me-I just felt the need to put it on record-that the Eritrean people can have been so united through such a very long crisis, in which the majority of the population probably were not born when it started. I hope that the Australian Government will do all that it can to expedite the conclusion of that conflict.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 24 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many compensation claims for industrial deafness were lodged in Australia in the years: (a) 1986-87; (b) 1987-88; (c) 1988-89 (if available).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 10 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a study of Australian exporters by the Australian Trade Commission (AUSTRADE) which reveals: (a) that only 2 per cent of Australian exporters can be described as global competitors; (b) only about 100 companies have sales of $50 million or more and exports of at least 25 per cent of turnover, even including the large agricultural and mineral commodity exporters; and (c) 75 per cent of exporters have total sales of $10 million or less than in general reflect low commitment, in that domestic surplus capacity is allocated to export from time to time on an opportunistic basis.

(2) In view of the seriousness of the position revealed by the report and subsequent comments made in a media release dated 31 August 1989 by the Chairman of AUSTRADE, Mr Bill Ferris, what options are open to the Government to bring about an improvement in the position, given the urgent need to increase exports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the profile of Australian exporters by the Australian Trade Commission (AUSTRADE). This profile is set out in AUSTRADE's submission of May 1989 to the Committee for Review of Export Market Development Assistance.
(2) The Government is addressing the need to improve Australia's export competitiveness.

AUSTRADE is charged with developing and delivering services to exporters. This assistance is directed at all stages of the export process, starting with motivating Australian firms and industries to the profit potential of export and other forms of international business. It continues through export planning assistance, market intelligence, support in the field and progressing the internationalisation of Australian business, including encouraging two-way investment.

Fundamental to Australia trading its way out of its present trade imbalance is the inculcation of an export culture in the manufacturing and services industries. It was one of the recommendations of the report of the Committee for Review of Export Market Development Assistance (the Hughes Committee). The report stated that the importance of international competitiveness in the production of goods and services for Australian living standards needed to be understood in the community.

AUSTRADE is playing a major role in developing an export culture through strategies designed to promote the importance of export in key, interrelated audiences and fostering new networks of key players in business, government, unions and the community.

AUSTRADE is representative of the Government's determination to create an environment in which Australian companies become and remain internationally competitive. The Government recognises that macro and micro economic policies are important determinants of the long term success of Australia's export performance. It is pushing on both fronts to improve macro economic management and micro economic reform.

Australia's international competitiveness is dependent on internationally competitive companies. The Government is committed to developing new programs and tailoring existing support measures to meet this objective.

The internationalisation of Australian business, involving as it does the two-way exchange of management skills, capital, technology, distribution and marketing, is an important part of the Government and AUSTRADE's efforts to integrate Australian industry into the global economy. It is integral to the Government's thrust to make Australia a nation with a commitment to export, a nation imbued with an export culture.
